The sociable companions, or, The female wits -- The presence : scenes ... design'd to be put into the Presence, but by reason they would make that play too long ... print[ed] by themselves -- The bridals -- The convent of pleasure -- A piece of a play.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

figure.figDesc: likeness of Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle
figure.l: Here on this Figure Cast a Glance,
But so as if it were by Chance,
Your eyes not fixt they must not stay,
Since this like Shadowes to the Day
Her Beuty's found beyond the Skill
Of the best Paynter, to Imbrace,
Those louely Lines within her face,
View her Soul's Picture, Judgment, witt,
Then read those Lines which Shee hath writt,
Which Peece but Shee, Can justly owne.

div.p: WRITTEN By the Thrice Noble, Illustrious, and Excellent PRINCESSE, THE Duchess of Newcastle.
LONDON, Printed by A. Maxwell, in the Year M.DC.LX.VIII.

div.head: TO THE READERS.
div.p: IT is most certain, That those that perform Publick Actions, expose themselves to Publick Censures; and so do Writers, live they never so privately and retir'd, as soon as they commit their Works to the Press. Which should perswade wise Persons to be very cautious what they publish; especially in a malicious, and envious Age. I do not say, that this is so; but if it be, I can truly say, that I am sorry of it, meerly for the Age's sake, and not in relation to my Self, or my Books; which I write and disperse abroad, only for my own pleasure, and not to please others: being very indifferent, whether any body reads them or not; or being read, how they are esteem'd. For none but poor and mean spirits will think themselves concern'd in spightful Censures.

Having observ'd, that the most Worthy and most Meritorious Persons have the most envious Detractors, it would be a presumptuous opinion in me to imagine my self in danger to have any: but however, their malice cannot hinder me from Writing, wherein consists my chiefest delight and greatest pastime; nor from Printing what I write, since I regard not so much the present as future Ages, for which I intend all my Books.

When I call this new one, Plays, I do not believe to have given it a very proper Title: for it would be too great a fondness to my Works to think such Plays as these suitable to ancient Rules, in which I pretend no skill; or agreeable to the modern Humor, to which I dare acknowledg my aversion: But having pleased my Fancy in writing many Dialogues upon several Subjects, and having afterwards order'd them into Acts and Scenes, I will venture, in spight of the Criticks, to call them Plays; and if you like them so, well and good; if not, there is no harm done: And so Farewell.

list.item: Roger and Tom, Get-all's two Men.
Two other Men, one the Serjeants, the other the Doctors.
Mistress Peg Valourosa Sister to Captain Valour.
Mistress Jane Fullwit, Will Fullwit's Sister.
Mistress Anne Sencible, Harry Sencible's Sister.
Mistress Informer, an old decay'd Gentlewoman.
Mistress Prudence, Daughter to Master Save-all.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: NOble Spectators, Our Authoress doth say,
She doth believe you will condemn her Play.
Here's no design, no plot, nor any ground,
Foundation none, not any to be found,
But like the World's Globe it hath no support,
But hangs by Geometry: nor hath it fort
To make it strong, nor walls to keep out censure,
Yet she will valiantly stand the adventure.

div.head: THE Sociable Companions; OR, THE FEMALE VVITS: A COMEDY.
SCAENA I.
div.stage: Enter Colonel, Captain, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: COLONEL.
sp.p: What News, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is an old saying, That ill News hath wings, and good News no legs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hath thy News wings, or no legs?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It hath wings; for it is reported for certain, that the Army shall be disbanded, and all the Soldiers Cashiered.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: So, then the Army will be a flying Army.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But yet we must beg upon Crutches.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p:
I believe we should have been stronger, if we
had been of any other Profession, having had a better employment to have busied our minds and persons with; for Soldiers for the most part, their time and lives are idle, having no great employment or business, but when they march or fight, which is not every day or week; and when we are in Quarters or Trenches, we have nothing to do but to watch by turns; and therefore we are forced (for want of better employment) to pass our time with the Wenches in the Suburbs, or the Baggages that follow the Army, with whom we get the Pox.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But how shall our Pocky bodies live, if we be Cashier'd?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: We must endeavour to get into some Hospital for Cure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That will be more difficult, then to get into a Court for Preferment, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The truth is, we may more easily get into a Court, then to have a Cure in an Hospital; and we may more easily be cured in an Hospital, then get Preferment in a Court; for Soldiers are never regarded in time of peace; for when a War is ended, Soldiers are out of Credit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And in time of War Courtiers are out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, Soldiers regard not new Modes, no more then Wars give ear to Flattery.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But Courtiers do oftener turn Soldiers, then Soldiers Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Faith, Lieutenant, much alike; for Courtiers are
too weak to make Soldiers, and Soldiers are too rough to make Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: How, come Courtiers weak, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As Soldiers come weak; for Courtiers bring the Pox into an Army, and the Soldiers carry it out of an Army; for there is no resemblance between a Courtier and a Soldier, but by that disease; for the Pox make Courtiers and Soldiers like unto like.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, leaving the Pox to the Courtiers, how shall we that are Soldiers, live?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: We must rob on the King's high-way.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So we may chance to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If we be, the care of a livelihood will be at an end.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But I would not venture my life for a little mony.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: How ignorantly you talk Captain! for do not all Soldiers venture their lives in Battel for other mens sakes or Quarrels, and have no reward for their venture and danger? and will such Soldiers be afraid to venture their lives for themselves, and their lives maintenances?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But there is hope to escape death in a Battel, but there is no hopes for a man to escape death when as his neck is in a nouse.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p:
There is as little hopes to escape death when as we have no means to live; and for my part, I had rather be hang'd then starv'd; but howsoever, I am a Soldier both in spirit and profession, who fears not death; and you seem to be a Soldier in name, and not in nature; you
have the title of a valiant warring man, which is a Soldier, and the nature of a Coward; otherwise, you would not talk of escaping death, which shews you fear death.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you were not my approved friend, you should find I were no Coward as to fear to fight with you; but I am afraid to die a base death, as a thief, and not like a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How strangely you talk, Captain! are not all Soldiers thieves? Do not all Soldiers Plunder? Do not they take the Spoiles of their Enemies? As first, kill their enemies, or take them prisoners, and then seise on their goods, and all by Force? and all Force is Hostility, and Hostility Robbery; and do not only the common Soldiers, but we Commanders, nay, our Generals do the same? and yet you name Thievery and Robbery base, which baseness you and many more of all degrees and qualities have practised and lived with this dozen years to my knowledge, and it hath been a practise ever since the world began: for Adam and Eve robbed Gods Apple-tree, for they were forbid to take, or eat, and yet they did both; and did not Cain kill his brother Abel? and was not the Devil an enemy from the beginning? Thus Robbery, Malice, Murder and Disobedience begun from the worlds Creation, and will last to the worlds Dissolution; by which we may see, that our profession, which is to rob, fight and kill, is the most ancient profession that is.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Dear Colonel, you have spoken most learnedly and truly.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But yet there is difference between a Robber, a Murderer, and a Soldier; for it is Honourable to Kill our Enemies in the open Field: and it is Lawful to possess the Spoiles.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Many times we Kill our Friends, especially in Civil Warrs; and when we Fight with Foreigners, they never did us hurt, injury, or malice; but what do you talk of such Honour as Warring-Honour, which is a fair Name to a foul Act; and of such Martial Law, as is Lawless and most unjust, as to take away other Mens Rights? 'tis all one to call black white, or white black. But there is no such thing as Law, nor no such thing as Honour, but what Man feigns or makes; but the truth is, that which Men call Law and Honour, is Power and Force: for, the Strongest give Law; and Power makes Honour as it pleases.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Your learned discourse, Colonel, shall not perswade me to Rob on the High-way.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: What will you do then, Cap. to get a living?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I will think of some honester way to live.

sp.speaker: Colo.
sp.p:
You had best Trade, and cozen your Customers, that is a very honest way of Living; or serve and Cozen your Master, or deceive your Mistriss, that is an honest way of Living; or to Flatter some great Lord, or Lie with some Old Lady, that is an Honest way of Living: or betray, or accuse some Rich Man, to get a Morsel of his Estate for a Reward, that will be an honest Living: or Debauch a young Heir to live on his Luxuries
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
and Riots, or Corrupt young Virgins and Married Wives with Pimping, that will be an honest and honourable Living: or be a Broker for the Courtiers, to help them to sell their old Clothes: or a Rook: or be a Huckster for the Courtiers, to bring them Suters and Petitioners for a share of their Bribes, that will be an honest Living: or frequent Taverns and Ordinaries that are customed with Noble Guests, and leave them to Pay thy Share, that will be an honourable Living; and an Hundred such waies there be, to get an honest Living.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, I will go to Plow and Cart first.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: What? will you be a Slave to a Horses Tail?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, I will tell you a better way for You, and the Lieutenant, and my Self to Live, than that: Let us get some of our Poor VVhores that followed the Army; and go into some New-found Land, to help to increase Plantation.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Content Colonel, but let me tell you, it will be but a rotten Plantation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Faith all Plantations are but rottenly begun; but the more rotten the Planters are, the better; for rottenness doth, like as dung, help to Manure the Land.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Faith Colonel, I like your Proposition so well, as I would be there.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So do I, wherefore let us fit and provide for our Journey presently, and sing this Song.

lg.l: Capt. Let's go to our New Plantation;
Let's go to our New Plantation;
And there we do hope,
No fear of a Rope;
Nor hanging in that Blessed Nation.
Lieut. Let's go to our New Plantation;
Let's go to our New Plantation;
For here's no Regard,
Nor Soldiers Reward,
In this most Wicked Nation.
Col. Let's go to our New Plantation;
Let's go to our New Plantation;
Each Man with his Whore,
Although We be poor,
And Rottenness is our Foundation.

div.stage: At the end of the Song, Enters Peg Valorous.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Then the Captain sings the burden of an old Ballet.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Get thy coat Peg, and go away with me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You seem to be very merry Brother, that your Officers and you sing so cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: By your favour Mistress, some for Joy do weep, and some for Sorrow sing; witness the Lamentation, and the Poetical Swan; and Tears are often produced by Laughter.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What is the the cause of your sorrowful singing?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Army is Cashiered, and so the Soldiers are undone.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It were better the Soldiers should be undone, than the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Will you speak against your Brother's Profession?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, if it be for the general Peace of my Native Country.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But now there is Peace, how shall we live?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You must live in Peace by your Wits, as you lived in the Wars by your Valours.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But all the Cavalier Party lost their Wits when they lost their Estates.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Then you must Petition the State of this Kingdom to build so large a Bethlam as to put in all the poor mad Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Your advice is good, and you shall deliver
their Petition, Peg; but before I go to Bethlem I will go tell Harry Sensible and Will Fullwit the News.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: And the Cornet and I will go drink some Cordial Waters to revive our Spirits.

div.stage: Enter Anne Sensible, and Jane Fullwit.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Do you hear the News of the Cashiered Army?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: And are not you troubled at the News?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No; for I had rather my Brother should be poor with Safety, then rich with Danger; but your Brothers, although they have not been such Active sufferers, yet they have been Passive sufferers.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes, faith, they have had their shares of Losses; but now my Brother is poor, he begins to study.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What doth he study, his Losses?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: No, he studies Books.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What books? the Crumbs of Comfort, and the Soveraign Salve, for the Cure of the Soul?

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: All our Brothers had need to Study and read a Cure for their Estates; but let us go and bear them Company. Exeunt Anne and Jane.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Prudence to Peg.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: Cousin Peg, where is your Companions, Nann and Jane?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: They are in their Chamber, envying your good Fortune, and repining at their own ill Fortune.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: What good Fortune do they envy me for?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: For being the only Child, and so the only Heir to a rich Father.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: If their Brothers had been as wise as my Father, not to have been so vain to have show'd their Valour, they might have been so prudent as to have kept their Estates; and so you and they would not have lost your Portions by the folly of your Brothers.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It was not through their Folly, but through their Loyalty that they entered into the action of VVar.

div.stage: Enter Nann and Jane.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O Mistress Prudence! 'tis a wonder to see you abroad, or at home without a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: VVhen I come to see great Beauties, such as you are, I dare not bring any of my Gallants, for fear you should rob me of them.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: It would be a Charity to bestow some of the richest of your Suiters among us poor Virgins, to make Husbands of; and to chuse one of the poorest of our Brothers to be your Husband.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: Indeed it would be a Charity to your Brothers, but no Charity to my self.

div.stage: Enter Master Saveall, Mistress Prudence's Father.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Save you young Beauties.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: VVe know not whether our Beauties will save us; but we shall hardly save our Beauties long; for old Father Time will take them from us.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Then you must get good and rich Husbands in the time of your Beauties.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
There are three difficult things to get; as first, to get a Husband; next, a good Husband; and last, a rich
Husband; for Men care not for handsome VVives, but rich VVives; for had not my Cousin Prudence, your Daughter, VVealth as well as Beauty, she might have many Lovers; but not a Husband amongst them all.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Cousin Peg, you may get a rich Husband, not only by the means of your Beauty, but by your VVit.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I have heard, that in former Ages, that many Men did live by their VVits; but in this Age Wit is out of fashion, and so out of practise, and so poor, as 'tis almost strange

div.stage: Enter Captain.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I am talking to your Sister my Cousin Peg, and I perceive she despairs of getting a Rich Husband.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: She hath reason, being poor her self; wherefore Peg, and her two dear Friends, Mistress Anne, and Mistress Jane, must lead Apes in Hell.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: If the Devil hath as many Apes as Mens follies, we shall never be able to lead them all.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: For fear my Daughter should lead Apes in Hell, I will go and get her a Husband.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter William Fullwit, and set at a Table with many Books about him. He reads. Enter to William Fullwit, Captain and Harry Sensible.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: BAccus and Mercury help thee, and have mercy on thee, for I perceive you are falling into Perdition, as from a Drunkard to a Student; from a merry Companion, to a dull Stoick; from a Wit to a Fool.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I pray thee Harry leave me, for I am studying to be a wise Man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith Will, VVisdom is not learned by the Book, but by Practise, which gets Experience; for Wisdom lives with living Men, more then with dead Authors: But prithee tell us, what Books are you reading?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I am reading Plutarch's Lives, Thucidides, Machiavel, Commineus, Lucan, Caesars Commentaries, and the like.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Why such Books, since you are neither Greek nor Roman? So that those Histories, or Historians of other Nations will not benefit thee, nor thy Native Country for their Laws, Customs, or Humours; for what are the Laws, Customs, Humours and Governments of the Romans, Greeks, Turks, or Persians to thee, or thy Native Country?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You say true, Harry; and what are their Wars, or Peace to us, unless the same Cause, the same Places, and the same Men, were again in our time? For put the case you were a General, and were to fight a Battel, and would make Caesar your Pattern, it were a thousand to one but you would shew your felf rather a Fool, then a Caesar; for first, the Causes of War would be different; the Scituation of War different; the Humours of the Soldiers different; the Habilements, Postures, and Breeding of the Men different; the Means, Supplies, Supports, Armes, Time, Place, and Seasons different: So that if later Commanders should follow the Precepts of former Commanders and old VVarriers, they would be losers; and instead of being fam'd good Soldiers, get the reproach of being ill Conductors.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: You say right, Captain; and as for Foreign Government, History is of no use, unless you would bring an Innovation; for which, had you power to make Combustions, you would sooner ruine the Kingdom, then alter the Government; besides, in all Alterations, Fortune hath greater power, and is more predominant then Prudence: wherefore leave thy impertinent Studies.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I will take your Counsel.

div.stage: Enter Lieutenant Drunk, and comes Reeling in.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Captain—Captain—I would fain speak, very— fain speak a speech—but I shall be out of my speech, before I begin, and that would be a very fowl disgrace— to a man of parts.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Lieutenant; but a drunken man hath no parts, for he is a departed man, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But I would have declared the strange effects— the Magical effects—the Mystical effects—and the Tyranical effects.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: All which Effects meet in one Effect, which is to be drunk, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: That is true Captain—but the strange Postures, several Humours, senceless Brains, and disabled limbs— is that which I would declare.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: They will declare themselves, Lieutenant, without the help of Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: You are a fool, Will; for they will want help, as you may perceive by me—up—

div.stage: He Reels as he speaks.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But Words are too weak to support them.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But Words may excuse them.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Brother, there is a Gentlewoman without, that came with the Lieutenant, who says she will not go without him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lieutenant, there is a Gentlewoman stayes to support thee to thy rest.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: It is a Cousin of mine—newly come out of the Country—but I will go to her—up—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We will help to lead thee to her.

div.stage: They lead him forth. Exeunt Men.
Enter Mistress Jane, and Mistress Anne, to Mistress Peg.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Where is the Lieutenant? 'tis said, he is so drunk, he can neither stand nor speak.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: The truth is, he doth both, but ill-favouredly.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Informer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mistress Informer, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: I know that, otherwise I would not visit you; but I seldom fail seeing you once a day, unless I be out of Town; but now I came out of Charity, knowing you were all alone.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: How did you know we were all alone?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Because I met your Brother, Captain Valour, and Harry Sencible, Mistress Ann's Brother, going up the Street.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Was not my Brother with them?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: No; I saw Will Fullwit go to the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: What Play-house? the Gaming-house, or the Acting-house?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: The Acting-house.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Our Brothers might be so kind, as sometimes to carry us to Plays.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: So they would, if we were such Cousins as the Lieutenant had here; but being their Sisters, they will not be troubled with us.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Now you talk of the Lieutenant, it puts me in mind, I met him in the Street leading a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I believe she rather led him, then he her.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
I know not which, led which; but neither of
〈…〉
them did walk steddily, for sometimes they went towards the Wall, and then presently towards the Kennel.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It was a sign they were both drunk. But Mistris Informer, have you brought the new-fashioned Hankerchief to see.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Yes, but I have left it in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come let us go see it. Exeunt all but Jane.

div.stage: Enter Will Fullwit mufled in his Cloak.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sister Jane, is Harry Sencible within?

sp.speaker: Jane,
sp.p: I cannot tell whether he be returned; but he was abroad?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pray see; and if he be return'd, bid him come to me.

div.stage: Enter Harry Sencible, Will Fullwit upon the Ground, he groans, Harry Sencible runs and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Harry,
sp.p: Dear Will, what is the cause you lie so sadly?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I am wounded, wounded.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: VVhere? where? tell me dear VVill.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I am kill'd, I am kill'd.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I die, I die.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Hold Life a little time, so long to tell thine Enemy, that I may sacrifice him on thy Tomb; Oh he is dead: dear VVill, I wish to die, since thou art gone.

div.stage: Exit Harry Sencible VVeeping.
After he was gone out, VVill Fullwit rises and Dances,— then enter Harry Sencible, with Captain Valour, Lieutenant Fightwell, and Cornet Defendant, all stand as in a Maze.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Harry, did not you tell us, that VVill Fullwit was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I thought him dead.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then how the Devil comes he to be alive again!

div.stage: Enter Mistress Anne Sencible as in hast.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O, where is Mr. Fullwit's body?

div.stage: He Addresses to her.

sp.speaker: Will.

l.hi: Dear Lady, I, for thy dear sake,

sp.l: Will travel to the Stigean Lake;

l.hi: There let us meet, and then imbrace,
And look each other in the Face.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O the Lord, what doth he ayle?

div.stage: Enter Mistress Peg Valourosa.

l.hi: For you the Goddess are of Light,
She's a fiend that governs Night.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: By heaven he is stark mad.

div.stage: Will Fullwit draws his Sword.
The Ladies run squeeling away.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: You have frighted them away.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Dear Will, put up thy Sword, for we are all thy Friends.

l.hi: You are my Foes, I say,

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: This madness is worse, far worse then death.

div.stage: Harry Sencible, VVeeps.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: What Harry, do you weep in earnest?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: How can I chuse, to see my friend in a mad distemper?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why Harry, I have only acted an Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox of your Intrigue; for you have frighted the Ladies, and disturbed your Friends.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Nay faith, he hath disturbed the Ladies, and frighted his Friends.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But how came you to be in this humour?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: With seeing a new Play.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: But you have not acted an Intrigue yet.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: That's true, by reason the Ladies went away, and Harry's Tears would not suffer me to make more changes; besides I had not time to express, or act my Intrigue; but if you will call the Ladies again, you shall see me act an Intrigue and Catastrophe, as it ought to be.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Hang Intrigues and Catastrophes, and play the fool no more.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prithee Will, go with us to a Tavern, and there we will have several sorts of Wine, changes of Musick, and variety of Mistresses, which are better Intrigues and Catastrophes then are acted upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Content, let us go, to dry up Harry's Rhume with Sack, and to let him see I am still a merry Companion.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: If I had known you had dissembled, I would not have discovered my love.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why? Love and Deceit is an Intrigue; but the truth is, I did this, that you and the Captain should not believe that I was a dull Stoick.

div.stage: Enter Dick Traveller, as newly return'd home.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Dick Traveller, art thou return'd, old blade, from thy Foreign Travels, to thy home-Friends?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I confess Foreign Travellers are apt to lose home-Friends.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But you have not lost us, for thou art heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign that your Travels have been as cold as far, for you have brought white Hairs home with you.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: He could not avoid a white head; for he hath been at the North Pole, which hath turn'd his Hairs to Snow.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I have been near the Pole in Greenland.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Is that Country fertile?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes, of Frost and Snow.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Is it Populous?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: 'Tis very populous of Bears and Foxes.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Is it a good place for Plantation?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes faith, for if there were a Colony of Adulterers sent thither, they might Plant Chastity; and if a Colony of Drunkards were sent thither, they might Plant Temperance; also if a Colony of Prodigals were sent thither, they might Plant Frugality.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But might not a Colony of Fools plant Wit there?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: It were excellent Policy, to send all the Fools thither.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Those Parts of the World would not hold them, if all be sent; for most Men are Fools.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: VVhy fools in what part of the VVorld soever, they live in Twilight; and neer the Pole is Twilight half the year.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Prithee let's leave talking of such cold Elements; for the very hearing of the North Pole hath chil'd my Spirits, as if they were hard frozen, and all my thoughts are turn'd to Snow; wherefore let's go to a Tavern, and drink Sack to thaw them.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I shall bear you Company.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Faith thou hast reason to drink ten Fathom deep to melt thy frozen body, and thaw thy cold blood that is turn'd to Ice, that Spirits of life may swim in full large Veines.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: You are full of Poetical fancy.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign I did never travel to the North Pole, for fancy lies in East and VVestern brains; the truth is, every Poets brain is a Torrid Zone; wherefore let's go to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: That is under the Ecliptick Line.

div.stage: Enter Peg and Anne.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Are you come to see the Intrigue?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, but we are come to see, whether VVill Fullwit be not dead again.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: No; but I am not so well, but that these good fellows, are going to give me a Cordial.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: To me these Ladies are Cordials.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You have not tasted them yet.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: May I presume to salute you, Ladies?

div.stage: He Salutes them.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: How do you like them?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: It is not a question to be asked, nor I to give an answer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prithee come away, and leave Complementing.

div.stage: Enter Jane.
Exeunt Men.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Did you see Dick Traveller.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes, I met him, and all the crew of them.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I have seen thy Brother stark mad.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I never knew him otherwise.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: He did only shew an Intrigue.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Informer.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mistress Informer, you are welcome; but what News brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Hearing Master Traveller was to see you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He was so.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Pray what new fashions hath he brought from the North Pole?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I do not perceive any new fashion.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
Lord, how reports prove false! for I heard he had a strange fashioned Suit of Clothes which he did wear, made all of Ice, and a great thick Cap of Snow, which he wore over his head; and that the motions of his Body
and Behaviour were trembling and shaking, as if he were affrighted, or in a cold fit of an Ague, and that his language was such a stuttering and stammering language, as not any man in these parts could understand him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I saw no such Clothes or Cap that he wore, nor heard no such stuttering, stammering language.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Indeed, as to his Garments, I did not believe reports; for I said to those persons, that told that report for a certain truth, that I could sooner believe he was accoutred in a Suit of Fire, rather then of Ice; but they replyed, That those parts of the World, so neer the Poles, would not permit Fire; for the extream cold did put out all sorts of Fire; but pray tell me whether he doth not look very pale, wither'd, dry and old.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He doth not look as if he were a very young man, because he is in some years; but he looks well for his age.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: What kind of Men, doth Mr. Traveller say, are the Natives at the Pole?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I did not hear him say, there be either native Men or Women.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: If not, how did he get a Mistress?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Such colds Elements do not require Courtship.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: But are there not any living Creatures there?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, there are Bears; and in some of the Islands near the Poles, there are white Bears, with red Patches on their heads.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: That is very fine, and surely very becoming; wherefore I will inform the Ladies, who I am sure will follow that fashion.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: How can they be in the Bears fashion?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Very easily; for they may have a white Sattin Gown, and a red Velvet Cap; and so be like the white Beares, with the red Patches on their heads.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: If they imitate nothing else of the Bear but that, it will not be much a miss.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Fare you well; for I long to carry the News of the Fashion. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Will Fullwit.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Is Harry returned?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: No. Exeunt Women.

div.stage: Enter Harry.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I was going to the Tavern, believing you and the rest of our Companions, were gone to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I stay for Dick Traveller; but Captain Valour, Lieutenant Fightwell, and Cornet Defendant, are gone before to the Tavern, to provide us good Wine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: They will be drunk before we come.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Surely they will forbear drinking until we come.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: How should they forbear drinking, if they went to tast the Wine?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: They went to bespeak good Wine, and not to tast it.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Hang them, they will tast pint after pint, and quart after quart; for they have not so much Temperance as to stay.

div.stage: Enter Dick Traveller.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Dick, a Pox take you for staying, for the Captain, Lieutenant, and Cornet have drank all the Wine in the Tavern by this time.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: They cannot drink all.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Yes but they can; for they will pour in and out so fast, as I am confident they have not left so much as the droppings of the Tapes.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Come, come, let us make hast to them.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Yes, when all is drunk up.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I will warrant you there will be enough left to quench our drought.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I hate quenching of droughts; I would be like a Ship, to swim in an Ocean of Wine.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Informer.

sp.speaker: Informer.
sp.p: Are your Sisters within?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Yes. Exeunt Men.

div.stage: Enter Peg, Jane and Anne.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mrs. Informer, what is the reason you are returned so soon?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: The reason is, that I had forgot to tell you of the good company I was in the other day.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: We heard that you were in Sociable Company.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
I was so; and the Company hath past their time with all the delightful Recreations that could be devised, for the time they associated together; for sometimes the Ladies, and their courting Servants, play'd at Cards, and sometimes danced, and sometimes feasted, and some of the
fairest Ladies sat to have their Pictures drawn, whilst their Lovers or Friends gazed on their Faces; which was an occasion to cause those Ladies to put their Faces into their best Countenances; and some of the Gallants did make their Mistresses Portraictures, both in Verse and Prose; whilst the Painter did draw their Pictures in Oyle or water-Colours.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It seems the Gallants were Courtly to the Ladies,

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: They were so.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Doth the Men court the Women publickly or incognito?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: They Court both ways; for every Man hath, his particular, which he doth usher; but if they like each other's Lady and Mistress better then their own, or Love's variety, or would be liked, or loved by more then his own Woman: They make Love incognito, as in a Mistical or Allegorical way; which Allegorical-Love's making, or woings, pleases the women infinitely, as by feered eye-glances, languishing looks, smothered sights, and metaphorical speeches; as also wrying their Necks, with their eyes fixt on the ground, or falling, or stumbling upon them, as if it were by chance; and many the like Behaviours, Garbs, Motions, Countenances and Discourses, as I cannot remember to repeat all; and some are so excellent and well experienced in the Art of making Love incognito Allegorically, or Metaphorically, as I have known or observed one Man to make half a dozen Women at least at one time, believe he hath been deeply in Love with each of them.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: And do the Women receive these fashioned Courtships in the like manner?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Yes, for they are as expert as the Men in those ways; the truth is, that although every Man and every Woman hath a Staple Servant, and a Staple Mistress, yet they traffick all in common.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: It seems they are common Wooers: But farwell, I must go speak with my Brother Fullwit.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: You must go to the Tavern then.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: VVhy, is he gone to the Tavern?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear him, Mr. Sencible, and Mr. Traveller say, they would go unto the Crown-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am sure my Brother and his Officer are there before them.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: It is not to be endured they should spend so much, and we want so much as we do.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: If I might advise you Ladies, I would have you go and bear them Company.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: VVe will take your advice, although not to drink, yet to quarrel, and you shall be our Conductor.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Those that see us will believe that Mrs. Informer is a Bawd, that conducts three young VVenches to some Gentlemen in the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Come, come, for if I be, it is not the first time I have been taken for a Bawd. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Captain Valour, Lieutenant Fightwell, and Cornet Defendant, as in a Tavern, who drink whilst they talk.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: CAptain, let us not stay for Will, Harry and Dick, but drink in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Content, let us sit close, and drink hard; for here is the best Wine; it was drawn out of Bacchus Cellar, wherefore it is divine Wine.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If it be divine, we should pray before we drink.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No you must drink first, as into a drunken humour with divine Wine, and then pray when the Spirit is strong in you.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: It is unnatural, Captain, at least unusual for Martial men to pray; in so much, that if a Soldier should be seen or heard to pray, he would be thought a Coward.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That is not so, for we were beaten by those that Prayed.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: But some of our Party prayed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If they did, it was so softly, as Jupiter could not hear them: But I have drunk my self into a loving humour, I wish I had a Wench.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: We will knock for the Chamberlain.

div.stage: Enter Chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Chamberlain, get us some Wenches.

sp.speaker: Chamb.
sp.p: There are none to be had, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are a lying Rogue; for there hath been no age, nor there is not a Kingdom that is not fully stored with them.

sp.speaker: Chamb.
sp.p: There is store in the Kingdom, if it please your Worship, but they are not for Soldiers in this age.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You lie, you Rogue, they are for Soldiers in all ages, even in the worst of times; for they will venture their lives to follow the Army for the pleasure of a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Chamb.
sp.p: An't please your Worship, it is for the hopes of gaining some of the Soldier's Plunder; but now that your VVorships can neither get Plunder nor Pay, they defie you, and will not come near you, but laugh at you, and say you are like old rusty Armes out of fashion, and that they are now for the Court, not for the Camp.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dam'd Fortune, shall the Court rob us, both of wealth and pleasure?

div.stage: Enter VVill Fullwit, Harry Sencible, and Dick Traveller, the Captain drinking when they came in.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Captain, what a Devil, are you mad to drink before we come?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are mad to stay so long, would you have us choakt for thirst?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Come, come, we shall overtake them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But you shall not, for we will, now you are come, sit and drink healths, as health for health.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Is there VVine enough to drink Healths?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Enough, Will, enough.

div.stage: They sit down and call for Wine.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dick, you are not returned as a Traveller a la mode.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: VVould you have me a la mode de Bear, or a la mode de Fox.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: VVhy not as well as other Travellers, that return a la mode de Ape, and a la mode de Ass?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, leaving the Bears, Foxes, Asses and Apes; here is a health to the North Star.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: That is a very cold Star, Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Therefore I will drink the health in Sack, to heat it into a Sun.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: And I will drink a health to Virtue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You had better put Ice into your Wine then Virtue; for she is so cold, not any heat can thaw her; but I will drink a health more proper, for Dick Traveller's company, which are the seven deadly sins.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: They belong more to the Courtier then the Traveller; yet I will pledge them, were they seventy seven sins, and drink them all at a draught.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But that is unconscionabe to drink them all, leaving not any for your Friends.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: All those I account my Friends, that have wit enough to get, or invent more; for new-fashioned Sins are as easily devised as new-fashioned Garments.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Who is the maker of new-fashioned Sins?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: The Devil.

div.stage: Enter Jane, Anne, Peg, and Informer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But what the Devil makes these VVomen come hither?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ladies, this is boldly done, to come and drink healths with us.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis but changing of Sisters, and they will serve us for VVenches, and Mrs. Informer, my Cornet or Lieutenant shall pay her for their Company.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: VVe came not to drink, but to complain that our Brothers should be so unkind, unworthy and unnatural, to sit drinking to fill their Heads, and empty their Purses, when we want Meat and Clothes.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You can be Jovial, but we must be Melancholy; you sing Catches, when we shed Tears.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: You have many Bottles of VVine, when we want Smocks to our backs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But you have silk Gowns.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes, such as you buy at the second hand, or at some Broker's shop, which are more rotten then the Jews Clothes in the VVilderness.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: VVhy, what would you have us to do?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Not to sit drinking in a Tavern most of your time; but to seek and endeavour to get some good Offices and Employments that may help to repair your ruins, and to maintain us according to our births and breedings.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, we may seek, and not find; beg, and not get.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But yet you shall not need to spend that little which is left, in drink.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If it were not for drink, we should run mad; but drink drowns all sorts of sorrows.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Leave your Caterwouling, and get you hence.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: We will not go home, unless you will go with us.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, so it will be thought, you are our Wenches, not known you are our Sisters.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: We care not what people think, knowing our selves honest.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Come, let us go, otherwise they will scould so loud, as all the Street will be in a hubbub to know the cause. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Father and his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: DAughter, you being now Marriageable, I am resolved to provide you a good Husband.

sp.speaker: Daught.
sp.p: I am willing to be a Wife; but pray pardon me if I ask you what you mean by a good Husband?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: A good Husband, is a prudent Husband.

sp.speaker: Daught.
sp.p: That is a miserable and jealous Husband.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: No, no, mistake me not, for miserableness and jealousie are extreams, but Prudence is a mean.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p:
If I must marry according to a Moral mean, which is between extreams, then I must Marry a man of a mean Birth, mean Breeding, mean Estate, mean Wit,
mean Judgmenr, mean Understanding, mean Esteem, mean Behaviour, and the like.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: No Daughter, I only desire you not to be an extream fool, as to marry to extream misery; but since you dispute for wisdom or discretion, I'le give you leave to make your own choice, which will tend either to my grief or comfort; to your own happiness or unhappiness; and I shall see whether you can act as wisely, as you plead wittily. Exit Save-all, and then enters a Suiter.

div.stage: Enter the young Lady, and a young Gentleman a Suiter to her.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Madam, your Beauty is the Gaze or Blaze to all the World; nay, 'tis not only a mortal but an immortal Light, and as the soul, not of one humane Creature but of all the World; which immortal light and soul I am very desirous to enjoy, and to make you my VVife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Sir, I shall readily consent, upon condition you make me a present of the Alkahest, and a jointure of the Elixir.
Exit Lady, Suiter Solus.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: This Lady is not to be won with Complements of Learning.

div.stage: Enter another Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: VVell met Sir; have you seen the Lady?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And how do you agree?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Just as Chymists and Fire.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: That is, they do not agree at all, but delude and cross each other.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Nay, faith, if she be in a cross humour, I will not plead and present my suit to her to day.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Harry, and walks in a Musing Posture. Enter Captain.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: VVHat is the cause you walk in such a musing posture Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I have lost my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, and too much.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Have you any Wit?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Because you are Melancholy for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: It would make you or any man Melancholy, to lose such a Woman as my Mistress is.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, not unless my Mistress were the only Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: She was the only Woman in my affection.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
'Tis a sign thy affection is a poor, mean, low, narrow, and little affection, that hath but one Room for one Mistress; whereas, my affection is as large as the Grand Signior's Seraglio,—for it will hold Hundreds of Mistresses,
with all their Maids and Slaves attending upon them; the truth is, my affection will hold all the Women in the VVorld; for I love all Women-kind, in so much as I can never want love so long as there be VVomen, or a VVoman; and surely I can never want a VVoman so long as the VVorld doth last; for the VVorld doth not increase any thing so numerously as Women; for all Armies, Nations, Cities, Towns, Villages, Houses, Churches and Chambers are for the most part filled with Women; and since there are so many Women, it were a madness for to be Melancholy for the loss of one woman: wherefore put off this whining humour for shame, and get another Mistress; and if I might advise you, I would have four and twenty Mistresses, at least, at one time, and so you will have a Mistress for every hour of the day and night.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But my Mistress is a woman that doth excell all her Sex.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: In Beauty, Wit and Virtue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, if you talk of Virtue in a Mistress, you are mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: May not a Man have a virtuous Mistress?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
No, for it is against the rules and nature of virtue, to live in a Mistress; for virtue is an humble Servant, when as a Mistress is an imperious Tyrant; for Women are insolent and imperious so long as they are made Mistresses, which is to be flatter'd, attended and served with Mens
estates, bodies and souls; but when they come to be wives, which is to be slaves, perchance, they may have so much of Virtue, as to be somewhat humble, when as they are forced to serve, and cannot command; but a wise Man will never have a Mistress, although he should live unmarried, but he will keep a Maid-servant for his use, and so take and turn away so often as he pleases: But is thy Mistress dead?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No, but she is Married.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why then, she may be her Husband's servant, and thy Mistress still?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But she is too Virtuous to be my Mistress now she is another Man's Wife.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I prithee be not so wedded to the opinion of Womens Virtues; for that will hinder thee from pursuing a Lover's design.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I will endeavour to forget this Mistress, and get another.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now you speak like a wise Man.

div.stage: Enter Will to the Captain and Harry.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Captain, and Harry, I was even now wishing for either of you.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: If you be as fortunate in all your wishes, as in either of our being here, you will be the most fortunate and happiest Man that ever was; but tell us whether it it was your affection, appetite or reason, which was the cause of your wish.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Not any of them; for it was my wit that caus'd
that wish; for I have made a Copy of Verses, which I would have you both read, and then give me your opinion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: For my part, I had rather your appetite had wished for our good fellowship; for I had rather drink a health, then read a Copy of Verses; the truth is, I cannot endure Verses.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But if they were a Copy made in your Mistress praise you would like them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I should hate my Mistress, throw the hate to the Verses, were she never so worthy, or the Verses so witty.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: That makes thee love mean common Women.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: They are fools that will wooe a nice Lady with flattering Verses, when they may have a free Wench, with plain Prose; and as the old saying, Jone in the dark is as good as my Lady.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Nay faith, but they are not; for all common Wenches are unwholsome Sluts.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Well, leaving Jone and a Lady at this present, I would have you read a drunken Song, which I made to sing between every glass, for singing dries the Throat, and drought requires drink, all which will make us drink with more gust, and the wine will tast the quicker.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Faith, I hate verse so much, as the Song will make me vomit up my drink; besides singing brings down rhume, and to have salt rhume mixt with sharp wine, will cause such an unpleasing tast, which will make us more sick then Crocus Mettallorum, and spoile the wine; wherefore burn
your Song; besides, let me tell you, as your friend, that 'tis very dangerous for a Drunkard to be a Poet; for the vapour of VVit, and the vapour of Wine, joyned together, will overpower your brain, and may make a man so mad, as to be past recovery; but when the brain is only muddl'd with the vapour of drink, sleep cures it, and drink causes sleep; whereas Poetry banishes sleep from the Sences, and heats the brain into a Fever.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But the hotter the brain is, the quicker the Wit is, and Poets drink VVine to heighten their fancy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Poets drink Wine to please their Pallats; and it is an old Saying, That when Drink is in, then Wit is out; wherefore burn thy Verses.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Do, Will, take his Counsel, and burn them.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I will follow your advice, and burn them to light a pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That is worse then if you should read them, or sing them; for you will suck them back into your brain, with the smoak, through your Pipe, and so have your Verses to return smoking hot, which will either smother your brain, or give your brain such an appetite, as you will never leave versifying. But come let us go and consult how they may be destroyed.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Content.

div.stage: Enter Peg.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Peg, have a care, and stay at home.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Jane Fullwit, Mrs. Anne Sencible, to Mrs. Peg Valorosa, who walked in a Melancholy posture.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Always Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Who can be merry, that is poor?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Who lives more merry then Beggars?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But our Birth and Breeding will not suffer us to beg.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: No, but we may live by our Wits.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But Wit was kill'd in the VVar.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: You are mistaken, it was only banished with the Cavaliers; but now it is returned home.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I cannot perceive it; for though I see many Fools, yet not a true natural Wit amongst them; for there is the Rhiming-fools, the Intrigue-fools, and the fine-languaged fools.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: The truth is, the multitude of Fools obscure the Wits, like dark Clouds that obscure the Sun; but let us endeavour to shine through those Clouds.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Let us try for our profit.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But Word-VVit will not make us rich.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.p: I grant it, but Deed-VVit will do us good, wherefore let us endeavour to get rich Husbands.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: VVe may endeavour it, but not obtain it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But if we could get them by our ingenuity, we know not where they are to be had.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Madam Informer will give us Intelligence.

div.stage: Enter Harry.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Is your Brother within the House?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I think he is, I will go and see.

div.stage: Exeunt Women.
Enter Will Fullwit.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, I shall never trust any man more for your sake, nor never believe in Friendship.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Do you ask why, when you who I did believe was so true a friend, would never forsake me at a time of need, when not only my Life, but my Honour was engaged in a quarrel, for which I chose you for my second, and then to fail me at the appointed time, was base; for had you been my Enemy, your Honour should have brought you into the field.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, I was so engaged in a Company of Ladies, I could not come.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Can there be a greater engagement then Friendship, Honour and Honesty?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Can there be a greater friendship then the love of Women, or more honourable then to serve the Female sex? and as for honesty, 'tis not worth any thing, besides, it is a fool, it brings a Man to ruine, at least a Man can never thrive by it.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: O judgment, how hath it erred, to chuse a Knave for a Friend, a Coward for a Second!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So I perceive, rather then you will want an Enemy, you will quarrel with your own judgment, you had best fight a Duel with that.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Go, go, and kiss a Mistress, and leave talking of Duels.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I marry, this is friendly advice; for in Kisses there is life and pleasure, in Duels death and danger; but let me tell thee, Harry, I have done thee a more friendly part, in not appearing, then ever I did thee in my life; for I have saved thy life, at least thy estate, and have kept thy Honour pure and free from stains, and I have increast thy honour.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thus; I have let thee go into thee Field for thy Honour, and have kept thine Enemy out, not by force, but by perswasion; which perswasion hath so wrought on him and his Second, as they will both meet in the same place you quarrel'd in, where shall be the same Company that drank, and was drunk there, and before that Company he will confess his fault, and ask pardon, which is as much satisfaction as an honest or honourable Man can desire; and it would be against the Laws of good fellowship to fight a sober Duel, for a drunken quarrel; wherefore agree, and be friends with our drunken Comrade.
sp.stage: Enter Captain, Cornet, Lieutenant, and Dick Traveller.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: VVe heard you very high in words, I hope you two dear friends will not quarrel?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: VVe shall not quarrel like Enemies; but Harry is angry, because I will not let him fight.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Fight, with whom will he fight?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: VVith Tom Ranter.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Hang him, he will get no honour with fighting with him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, come, I will conduct you to a better pastime then fighting vain Duels; for there are a Company of Ladies which I am acquainted with, that have made a merry meeting, only they want Men to keep them Company.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Let us go; come Harry, will you go?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I will but speak a word to my Sister.
sp.stage: Peg stands as if she were Musing.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: What are you thinking of now?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I was reasoning with my self, why those Women that was neither factious, ambitious, covetous, malicious nor cruel, should suffer in the Wars with the men.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: The gods would not be just, if the Women did not suffer for the Crimes of the Men, since all Men suffer for a single crime of a particular woman, witness our Grandmother Eve.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O Madam Informer, have you made an Inquiry?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Yes, marry have I, and find the Mass of Wealth is in the possession of Usurers, Lawyers and Physicians.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p:
I believe Usurers and Lawyers may be very
rich, for the Civil War hath made those sorts of Men like as Vultures, after a Battel, that feed on the Dead, or dying Corps; but I cannot perceive why Physicians should be the richer for those times.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: There is great reason why they should gain the more; for both Men and Womens bodies are corrupted, and weakned with Melancholy, Grief, Malice, Revenge, Envy, Wrong, Injustice, and the like; so that their bodies are full of the Scurvy, which their Misfortunes hath bred.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But have you found amongst these rich sorts of Men, any Widowers, or Batchelors?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Yes, that I have, three Batchelors; the richest amongst them, is one Mr. Get-all an Usurer; the other Serjeant Plead-all a Lawyer; the third Doctor Cure-all a Physician.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Which is the richest?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: The Usurer; for he is worth Two hundred thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Well, we will imploy our VVits to get these Men.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: But VVit without Assistance, will do no good; wherefore you must get your Brothers, and their Friends to help you by their industry.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Your Counsel is good.
sp.stage: Exeunt,—only Peg meets her Brother, Captain, as coming in.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Brother, are you well, you look so Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
In body, but not in mind, Peg.
Exit Peg.
sp.stage: Enter Will and Harry, the Captain, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Captain, what makes thee so sad?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That which would make any Man sad, want of Money.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We may be as sad as you for that; but to be poor and Melancholy is a double misery.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Life cannot be merry, when it hath not any thing to live upon.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dick, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I have been peeping through a Key-hole into a Room, where your three Sisters are in serious Councel with Madam Informer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pray God she is not instructing of them to be Wenches.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, I fear it; for she would make an ingenuous Bawd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I will go and part them.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Pray do not; for perchance the Womens Wits may do you more service then your own; for I heard them say, their Brothers must assist them; and surely they do not believe you would be their Pimps.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No, for they know we shall rather be their Murtherers then their Pimps.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then let them alone; and whilst they are in a Councel, let us go to the Tavern and drink.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But we have no Money.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I have a little credit to run on the Score.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Faith, if we go to the Tavern, the Girls will come crying after us.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I tell you they are so busie about some Female-design, as they will not miss us.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: I must stay to tell a lie, because they shall not follow us.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Ladies, your Brothers bid me tell you, they are gone about some serious business; but they will return soon.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: When they will. Exit Cornet.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mrs. Informer, how shall we three agree in the choice of the three Rich Men?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: You must draw Lots, and I have made them ready.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I pray Jupiter, I may draw the Rich Man.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray Jupiter, I may draw him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: We must take our Lot, let it be what it will. Jane draws first. They Draw.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Which have you drawn?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: I have drawn Serjeant Plead-all.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I have drawn Doctor Cure-all.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Jove, I thank thee in giving the Ʋsurer to me.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Now go to your Brothers, and inform them of your designs.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Faith, they will rather laugh at us, then help us.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: But yet we dare not do any such thing without their knowledge.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am confident my Brother will assist me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Come, let us go to them. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Captain, Harry, Will, Dick, Lieutenant and Cornet; as in the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: VVEll, this Wine is so fresh and full of Spirit, as it would make a Fool a Poet.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Or a Poet a Fool.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to the most Fools in the World.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then you must drink a Health to the whole World, that is one great Fool.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Prithee Dick do not drink that Health, for it will choak thee; for the World of Fools is too big for one Draught.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to the wisest Man.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: You may as well drink a Health to a drop of water in the Ocean.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith Dick, that health is so little, it cannot be tasted; besides, I do not love droppings.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to the Honest'st man in the World.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: That Health is more difficult then the last? for it is as rare to know an Honest man, as to see a Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Dick:
sp.p: Then I will drink a Health to the Chastest Woman.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: You might as well drink a Health to the Queen of the Faries, which is an old Wives-tale; for Chastity lives only in the Name not in Nature.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to a Common Courtesan.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: A Pox of that Health, I will not pledge it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is ashame for a Soldier to drink a Health to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: The truth is, I hate a Poetical Soldier.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Is it not lawful for a Soldier (Captain) to have Wit?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No; for Wit makes the minds of Men soft, sweet, gentle, and effeminate; insomuch as those that have VVit, are not fit for Soldiers; for Soldiers should have resolute minds, cloudy thoughts, hard hearts, rough speeches, and boisterous actions.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: The truth is (Captain) there is as much difference between a Poet and a Soldier (which is VVit and Courage) as between a Calm and a Storm.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You say true, Cornet; for certainly the best Soldiers are born and bred in the uncivillest Nations.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: No doubt of it, Captain.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then here's a Health to the Graces.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That Health is three times worse then the former, which was nine times too bad; for when did you know a Soldier to have Grace?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: The truth is (Captain) it is unnatural for a Soldier to have Grace.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You say true, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Setting aside, the Muses and the Graces, here is a Health to the Furies.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I marry Sir, that Health sounds like a Soldier's Health, and I will pledge it were the Glass full of Wounds. Here Harry, here's the Furies Health.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Faith, Captain, we shall be furiously drunk with the Furies Health.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: It will give fire to your brain.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, and burn out my Reason.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now I will begin another Health; Here Gentlemen, here is Death's Health.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Good Captain, do not drink Death's Health, for it will make our Wine so cold it will never warm us; besides, dead Wine will never make us drunk; and if we had not a desire to be drunk, we should not have come to now the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dick, you must drink Death's Health, for Death's Health will make you dead drunk.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then I will drink it, and invite you and the rest of the Society to my Funeral.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then we will carry thee to thy bed with Ceremony, as to thy Grave, sounding a dead March with empty Pots, trayling our Tobacco-pipes instead of Pikes, and spew out VVine instead of Tears.
sp.stage: Enter Peg, Jane, and Anne, as to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Did not I tell you they would come.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What come you for now?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Not to complain or chide, but to desire your assistance to our Designs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Let your Tongues and Tayls assist you.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No, our VVits and Honesty shall assist us.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pray Jove you have either.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: VVell, let us hear your Designs.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It is to get us Rich Husbands.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Sister
• eg, tell me truly, is the Design so honest, and honourable as only to get a Rich Husband.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: There is no deceit in the end, but only in the way or means.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, let us go, for perchance our Sister's honest VVits may get us Honourable Means to live with.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter Lady, and her Second Suiter.

sp.speaker: Suiter.
sp.p: MAdam, I was here some little while ago, to tender my duty to you; but hearing you were not in a pleasing humour, I durst not venture to present my Suit, for there is a nick of Time for Lovers to speed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, I perceive you are well learned in old Observations.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: As for Learning of all kinds and sorts, I defie it, in so much that I cannot read the Horn-book; neither am I able to remember the relation of any Discourse, if there be words in it that consist but of two Sillables.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How will you make Love then?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Thus Madam, I love you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: VVhat Jointure will you make me?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What maintenance will you give me?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can Love feed, Cloth and maintain me?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Love is the true Elixir, and above all price, being above Gold; it is a Creator, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If your Love be a Creator, then my Love shall be your Creature. Exit Lady, Suiter Solus.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: The Devil himself cannot work upon a Womans Nature.
sp.stage: Enter the Lady, and a third Suiter.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Madam, I hear you are Rich.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: And I am poor.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Therefore I desire you would be pleased to marry me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: To mend my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am no Cobler, Sir. Exit Lady, Suiter Sol.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: The Devil take Women's Tongues, for they make Men Fools.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Harry, and Doctor Cure-all.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: DOctor Cure-all, hearing of your fame, hath caused me to fend for you, to assist me with your help.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: What is your Disease?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: That you must tell me; but my pain lies in my bones.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I understand your Disease; you must be put to a diet, and you must sweat, and bathe, and something else, if need require it.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I hope I have not the Pox, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p:
You may say it is a Cold, or so; but do you
not feel a tenderness in your Nose, or a weakness in your Legs?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My Legs are somewhat weak.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Do you spit much?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Sometimes, but not much.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: It were well if you did; for that Evacuation is good for young Men. Gives him a Fee.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: By no means Sir.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Pray Doctor take it.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well Sir, I shall prescribe some Remedies.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I shall come to your House, and Visit you sometimes, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: You shall be welcome Sir; if I am not mistaken, your Name is Mr. Sencible.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: It is so Sir, your Servant Doctor.
sp.stage: Enter Captain and Will to Harry.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Harry, it seems you are sick, for we met the Doctor; but what says he to thee.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: He says, I have the Pox.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Plague of him, but he hath the Money.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I lent him two Pieces upon Interest.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: For the hopes of thy Cure: But Will Fullwit, have you got your Sister into the Serjeant's service?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, and he likes her Service very well.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But Harry, how doth your Sisters design go on?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Faith slowly; for this is the first time I ever saw the Doctor, but I hope it will come to a good issue in time; but how far is your Sisters design gone?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: SO far as I am almost ready to summon him to a Spiritual Court, and yet I have neither spoke to, nor seen the Usurer Get-all; but when a business is well laid, it is half done.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But if it be to appear before the Spiritual Court, it will be cast forth.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I will warrant you I shall get such a Judg, as will end the cause on my side; but both of you must be assistants; wherefore let us go to Dick Traveller, where we shall meet my Lieutenant, and Cornet, whom I have well instructed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O, you have prevented us; are you ready for the design?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But do you understand the cause well?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: So well as I shall not need any further Instruction; but where's my Fee?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But stay, the Cause is not ended; for though a Bribe go before, a Fee comes after.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If Judges and Lawyers should not be Fee'd before Causes were decided, they would not be so rich as they are; but Doctors usually have their Fees after their Prescriptions and Advice; wherefore, Will Fullwit, that must be; Doctor Feel-pulse must not be fee'd before hand.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I only fear Will is not learned enough to play the part of a Doctor of Physick.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Never fear me, for I shall out-argue the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Harry, and your Lieutenant, and Cornet must act as under Officers and Clerks.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: Let Harry act the part of a Clerk, and leave us to be under Officers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no, Harry must be a Pleader; but I never thought Soldiers should turn Judges, and Lawyers before now.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why not as well as Priests turn Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, let us go about this great affair.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Peg, have you got your Child ready?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Have you Confidence to outface the Court?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I can face the Court; but I fear I cannot outface or out-case the Usurer Get-all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Never fear it, Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Pray Jove we speed, for the good of the Common-wealth of Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well Peg, be ready against I send for you.
sp.stage: Enter Anne, and Informer, to Peg.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: How is your Design like to prove?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Well I hope; but Mrs. Informer, have you seen Jane Fullwit since she went to be a Lawyer's Clerk?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
I have, and she told me, that her Master is much pleased with her service; but I going often to visit his Clerk, the Serjeant having notice of it watched when I was with him, and was very angry, and said I
was such a Bawd as corrupted all the Apprentices, and Lawyer's Clerks in the City. But I fear for all your industry, your Designs will not come to that effect you desire.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Why, what hinders them?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Why, those three rich men, that I informed you of, do eagarly wooe the old Lady Riches.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Are the men young, or old?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Neither; they are of a middle age.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Then she will never marry any of them; for old Women love young Men; besides, she can marry but one.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, come, it is impossible, but we shall be preferred before the old Lady.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: I wish you may.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I will warrant you, we shall have good success if you act your part well.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: Never fear me, for I shall out-act you all.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Come, let us go to the Child, to put a dry Cloath to it, and to wrap it warm with a Mantle, for fear it catch cold; for if it get Cold, my Brother will be angry.
sp.stage: Get-all the Ʋsurer sitting casting up Accounts, Enter his Man Roger.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Will your Worship give me leave to speak freely to you?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Yes, Roger, freely.

sp.speaker: Roger.
