sp.p: I wonder your Worship will starve your life, to fill your Purse.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: O Roger, when the Purse is full, the life cannot starve for want.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he that is Rich may eat if he have a Stomack; but you will neither eat nor sleep, but wear out your life in casting up the Accounts of your Riches, and yet have not an Heir to leave it to.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Wealth never wants Heirs.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Indeed such Heirs, that will give no thanks for what they do receive?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But I can make the Meritorious my Heirs.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: You may make Heirs, but not Merit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Do you think there are not Men of Merit?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith Sir, Merit died many years since, and left no Posterity.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, there is one Captain Valour desires to speak with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: These poor Cavaliers haunt me like Spirits, they will not let me rest in peace.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith Sir, they are like Hounds, that hunt an after-Game.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But they shall not catch my Wealth; for they have no Lands to Mortgage, nor Goods to Pawn.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I believe they have not any thing to pawn or Mortgage, unless it be their Honesties.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But poor Honesty will pay no Debts; wherefore tell the Captain, I am not to be spoken with.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But your Worship said, you would leave your Wealth to Men of Merit.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Yes, Roger, I may leave them my Wealth when I die; but not give it them whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But if the Cavaliers be Men of Merit, they may be starved before you are like to die; for you are not fifty years of age, and healthful and temperate, whereas they are weak with want and disorders.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Want and disorders seldom go together; wherefore we'l endeavour to get the old Lady Riches.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: What, to be disorderly?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: No, to be Rich.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But would you Marry this old Lady Riches in earnest?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Yes; but I would not see her before I am Married, for fear I should dislike her; and that would disquiet my mind between two Passions, Dislike and Covetousness.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But you have a Mass of Wealth already, so in my judgment you should desire no more.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: You are a Fool; for I would be as Rich as the Indies, and then I should be more then half as Rich as the King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But what would you do with it, if you had it?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I would fight with the Great Turk.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But you said, That you would give your Wealth to Men of Merit.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Why so I shall, if I give it to Valiant Soldiers, to fight against the Turk.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But would your Worship head your own Army?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Truly that would be a kind of a Miracle; for I never heard of an Usurer that was Valiant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Captain Valour is without still, he will not go away.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I cannot speak with him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He bids me tell you, That he doth not come to borrow Money, for he knows you will lend him none; but he says, He came to inform you of a business that highly concerns you.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Well, bring him in; but be sure Roger and Tom, that both of you be in the next room, for I do not love to be with a Soldier alone.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But you dare trust your self at the head of an Army.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but that is against the Turk; but hold your prating and send in the Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Mr. Get-all, I am come to inform you, that there is a young Gentlewoman brought to bed.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: What is that to me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is to you, if it be true what they say, which is, that you got it.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p:
If she can prove I got it, I will not only keep
the Child, but marry the Woman; but I did believe I was always insufficient.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You speak as an honest Gentleman, and I shall tell her what you say. Exit Captain.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Roger, I am provided of an Heir, for I have a Child laid to my Charge.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Of the Captain's begetting.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I believe so; but the Wench lays it to my charge.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I never saw any thing like a Woman, near your Worship, since I came to be your Servant, which is above Twenty years; as for your old Cook-maid, she is nothing like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Why, what is she like then?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Like a Spirit, whose substance is wasted in Hell-fire.

sp.speaker: Cet-all.
sp.p: Well Roger, but I must be careful to avoid this Wenches plot against me, and there is no way, that I can perceive, to avoid it, but to marry as speedily as I can; wherefore carry the old Lady Riches that Present, and let her into my Chamber, and if it be possible speak to her self and wooe her for me.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I am as bad a wooer as your self; for I never wooed any Woman but your Cook-maid for a Breakfast, or to make me a Bag-pudding; and how such kind of Wooing will fit a Lady, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But you can tell her, how Rich I am.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: That I can, and in my Conscience that is as good a wooing-Plea as any is.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: And you may tell her that one of my age is fitter to match with one of her age, then a younger man.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Those two Arguments will spoile all, especially that of mentioning her age, for Women cannot endure to hear of their age, were they as old as Methuselah.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Well, use what Arguments you shall think fit.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Shall I Wooe as the young Gallants, in Court Language?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: What Language is that?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Fine Phrases, and Mode-expressions, which is a mixture with French words, and high Complements.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: How high?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: As high as Non-sence, which is beyond Understanding.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Prithee use what Language or Expressions you will.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But put the case I should wooe so courtly, as to get her for my self?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: If you do Roger, I shall wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. Exit Roger.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sir, there is a young Gentlewoman come in a Coach, who desires to speak with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I'le pawn my life it is she, that desires to lay her Bastard to my Charge.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Certainly, she is none of that trade, for she is come in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Why a Hackney Woman may ride in a Hackney-Coach; there is no Law against it, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But in my conscience this Gentlewoman looks as modestly, as if she were honest.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But a modest Countenance is oftentimes made use of only to cover the face of Adultery.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Then you will not speak with her?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: No, for there is Antipathy between me and VVomen-kind, since this Accusation.
sp.stage: Tom was going out, and returns back.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sir, here is the Captain.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: VVhat would you have now?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am come to summon you to the Spiritual Court.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I shall obey; but how shall I find the Court, for I was never there?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I will go but to the next house to speak with a friend, and I will come and direct you to the place.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I pray do. Exit Captain.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I am glad you are not gone to the Lady, for I am summoned to the Spiritual Court.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: The Captain's coming made me stay, but what are you summoned for, a bag of Money?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p:
Indeed that is the design, but the pretence is,
for getting the Child, I told you was laid to my Charge.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Why, this is the misery of Wealth, a man can never be quiet; and you being very rich, it will be the policy of the Spiritual Court, to make you maintain all the Whores, and their Bastards, in the City.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: And if there be an overplus, you may leave that to the Meritorious; so then you will maintain Vice in your life, and Virtue when you are dead.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But surely my Innocency will defend me from the injury of Injustice.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith, Injustice is too prevalent for Innocency, in these days.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Well, let us go, for I must obey the Laws.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But Sir, you are not provided of Lawyers to Plead on your side.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I shall not need them, for I can declare my own Innocency. Exeunt Get-all and Servant.
sp.stage: Enter as in a Court of Justice, Dick, as prime Judge of the Spiritual Court, the Lieutenant and Cornet as two Clerks, Harry Sencible as a Lawyer, or Pleader, for the Plaintiff; Will Fullwit as a Physician; Mrs. Peg Valorosa the Plaintiff; Informer, as a Midwife and Witness; and Captain Valorous as their Friend; when all sit in Order.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Most Reverend Judge, here is a Gentlewoman come, who desires Justice.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What is her Cause?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Her Cause is, That she being a virtuous young Woman, hath behaved her self modestly, and hath kept a good Reputation in the World (which all her Neighbours know) until such time as this Mr. Get-all got her with Child, which Child he will neither own nor keep, nor marry the VVoman.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Have you any VVitnesses?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: VVe have such a VVitness as the Law allows of, which is a Midwife.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I require the VVitness to be heard.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: VVill you witness that the Child is Mr. Get-all's.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: I will witness the words of the Labouring VVoman.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Declare them.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
About Twelve a Clock at Night I being in bed, and fast asleep, there comes a Man, and raps, and raps, and —raps at the Door, as if it had been for life, which in truth proved so; for it was to fetch me to bring a sweet Babe into the VVorld; but I hearing one rap so hard, I was afraid, my Door, being but a rotten Door, should be broke to pieces; I ran to the VVindow to ask, who knockt so hard; but the man knockt on, and I call'd out; which knocking and calling took up half an hours time; but at last, my Tongue being louder then the Clapper, he heard me then; I asked him what was his business? he said, I must go presently to a young Gentlewoman that was in Labour; upon which summons I
did rise and put on my Bodise, but did not half lace them; also my Petticoats, but did not tie them fast enough; for when I came into the middle of the broad Street, my Coats fell quite down from my hips, but as good luck would have it, it was a dark Night, but the ill fortune was, that my Coats fell down, when I was striding over the broad Kennel, in which posture I stood a great time, until the man helpt me over; but my Coats were all wet.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But what is all this to the Confession of the Labouring Woman?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: It is of concern; for Circumstance is partly a declaring of truth.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: You say true Mistress, wherefore go on.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: But as I said—stay, I have forgot; where did I leave?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You left at the wet Coats, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p:
'Tis very true, I humbly thank you Sir; The Coats, as I said, being wet, I was loth to put them on, not only for fear of catching cold, but for fear I should endanger the Womans miscarriage by my retardments; so I went with never a Coat on me, the Man carried them for me; but the night was pretty warm, so that I got no Cold, I thank Jupiter; but being more nimble, as being more light, I was soon at the house of the Labouring Woman, whom I found in painful throws, and she groaned most pitifully; and I comforted her, and prayed her to have
patience, and at last she was brought to bed of a very lusty Boy.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But what did the Gentlewoman confess?

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Inform.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman hath confest that she was never got with Child, nor never had a Child, but what Mr. Get-all begot; and this I will take my Oath of.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: How can you clear your self Mr. Get-all?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I will take my Oath that I never did see this Gentlewoman, about whom I am accused, in my life; and I have a Servant here that can witness for me.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What can you witness?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I can witness that I have lived with my Master these Twenty years, in all which time I did never see my Master converse with any thing like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Doth your Master keep no Servant-Maid?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: There is one we call the Cook-maid, but whether she be Maid or Woman, I'le take my Oath I know not.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Then your Master may converse with Women you know not of.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But I will swear my Master did never converse with this Gentlewoman that hath the Child.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: And I will take my Oath, as I said, that I never did so much as see her before now.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But may it please you, most Reverend Judge, this Gentlewoman hath seen him.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But the bare sight of me could not get her with Child.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That is to be proved; wherefore we require so much justice of this Reverend Judge, that Mr. Feel-pulse, a most learned and expert Doctor of Physick, may prove it by Argumentation.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Let Mr. Doctor prove it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Then be it known to this most Reverend Judge, and to Mr. Get-all, and the rest of this Assembly, That our Famous Doctor is of opinion, (as also the heads of our Schools and Colledges) That the production of Animal kind, is by an Incorporeal motion; and the famous Doctor is also of opinion, That the Soul of Man slides from the Stomack to the heel, and in that journey makes a production: And all the Platonicks do affirm, That there may be a Conjunction of Souls, although the Bodies be at a far distance; and I am absolutely of that opinion; and that the Idea of a Man, by the help of a strong imagination, may beget a Child; which is sufficiently proved; for she seeing Mr. Get-all enter into the house of Mr. Inkhorn the Scrivener, viewed his person so exactly, that when she was in bed, a strong imagination seized on her, by which she conceived a Child.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: It seems the Child was begot like the Plague, by conceit.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: You say true, Mr. Get-all; wherefore you must marry the Woman, own the Child, and keep them both.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Is there no avoiding your Sentence, Mr. Judge?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: No, the Decree is past.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Why then as she was got with Child by Conceit, so I will marry her by Conceit.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: But you must take her, and her Child home, and maintain them.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Cannot I maintain them by Conceit?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: No, that must be done Corporally.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: If there be no remedy, I must be content; come my Conceited or Platonick Wife and Child, let us go home.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We wish you all Happiness. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the Lady and a Fourth Suiter.

sp.speaker: Suiter.
sp.p: MAdam, I suppose my Name is unknown to you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis probable Sir; for I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Then I'le tell you, Madam, my Name is, Monsieur Vanity.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your Name shews that your Humour is Foolish, and your actions Prodigal.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p:
My Humour is noble, Madam, and my Actions generous; for I usually cast away a hundred pounds
at Dice, and run away a hundred pounds at a Race, and give away a hundred pounds at a Visit to a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This last kind of Prodigality has some resemblance to Generosity; but yet it is as different from Generosity, as a Bribe is from an Uninteressed Gift. But pray Sir, give me leave to ask you, what design brought you hither to me?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: A very good design, Madam; for I being vain, and you rich, 'twould be very convenient we two should joyn as Man and Wife, that one might maintain the other.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas Sir, the Wife would soon die in her Husbands arms; for Riches consume in Vanity; therefore, I will as soon marry death, as you. Exit Lady.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Sol. Death take her, if I cannot get her.
sp.stage: Enter Three Gentlewomen to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am glad you are come to release me from the importunity of my Suiters.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: You are in a good Condition, Madam, that you can have Lovers that seek you, when as we for want of Wealth, are forced to seek them.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: You mean Husbands, Madam, for Lovers are never sought, because they are never lost; for a Lover will always be at the tayl of his Mistress.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: I wish I had as many as would make up a Train. Exit Suiter.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Daughter, have you made your choice of a Husband, since you have so many Suiters?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: No truly Sir, for the number confounds my choice, or rather there is no choice in all the number, by reason none exceeds the other, but they are all Fools alike.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Indeed Daughter, if you be so long a chusing, you will be past choice your self.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: I had rather be old with Judgment, then young with Folly; and since you have been pleased to trust to my discretion, I would not willingly betray that trust, by the hast of my choice.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: You speak well, Daughter; Heaven grant you do well.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: But pray Sir give me leave to ask you one question.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: I would fain know, whether my Lovers do first address their Suits to you, or to me?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Their Suites they address first to you; but their inquiries are made first to me; to wit, what Portion I would give you, and whether I intend to settle all my Estate upon you.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: It seems they consider my Wealth before my Person.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes, and all Wooers do the like.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: But not Lovers Sir.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for they wooe first, marry next, and love last.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter the Fifth Suiter to the Lady, being an ancient Man.

sp.speaker: Suiter.
sp.p: MAdam, I see you are a Beauty, and Report speaks you Virtuous and Wise; which if so, I hope you'l chuse an ancient Lover before a young one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No question Sir, but an ancient Lover expresses more Constancy in his Love, then a young one doth; but ancient Love requires a great deal of time, and my Father may die before I make my Choice.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: You mistake me, Madam, I mean an ancient Man that loves you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There is great difference between an ancient Man, and an ancient Lover: But Sir, by your Discourse I perceive you pretend to be a Lover.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: My Love is not pretended; for I do really love you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How can I know that?

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: By proof; for I'le not require any Portion with you, since I am Rich enough without; Nay, I will not only take you without a Portion, but make you Mistress of all my Wealth, in so much that I will freely give you all I am Worth; and I wish I were worth Millions for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Sir, you express more Love in your Gifts,
then all my young Suiters in their Words; and if you will confirm your Promise to my Father, which you have now made to me, I shall accept of you for a Husband, and promise you, to be an honest and Loving Wife. He Kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Suit.
sp.p: Let us both go to your Father, and conclude the bargain.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Lawyer and his She-Clerk.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: IS Doctor Cure-all so industrious about the old Lady Riches?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he was very busie in preparing of Cordials, Ointments, and such things; and was angry that I came with a Message from you; for he bid me be gone; for the Lady, he said, could not hear Love-Messages, she was so full of Sciatical pain and Gout; but the old Lady did favour me, and chid the Doctor for bidding me to be gone; for she would have heard my Message, when her sides were anointed, and her Gouty Toe Plaistered.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: And did you stand by, till she was anointed?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir, for she did desire me to help to anoint her sides, whilst the Doctor laid a Plaister to her Toe.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: And how did she like your service?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: So well, Sir, as she said, she was never better chaft and rubbed in her life; I suppose it was for your sake.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: But when I am married, I shall not allow her my Clerk to anoint her sides, although she be so old to go upon Crutches. Exit Jack Clerk.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Sir, there is a Client without, desires to speak with you; and there is a Gentleman without, that doth raile bitterly.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Because his Law-Suit went against him; he says, That all the poor Cavaliers are not only undone by the Wars, but also by the Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: These poor Cavaliers are very troublesome.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Alass, their Losses make them impatient.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: They are so poor, that Lawyers cannot gain by them; wherefore, we are for the other Party, who are so rich, that 'tis fit their Purses should be emptied.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But if they get their Suites, Sir, the poor Cavaliers pay the Charges.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and bid Jack Clerk come to me.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Have you writ those Deeds out?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: And have you Copied out those Cases that I am to plead for, and against?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: 'Tis well done.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, you are pleased to seem to favour me.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I do really love thee, and will do thee any favour I can.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Then I desire you would be pleased to Plead a Cause that concerns a Kinswoman of mine.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That I will to the best of my power; but what is the Case?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Why Sir, I have a Kinswoman who is well born, but poor, and a Gentlewoman; but a Gentleman being in Love with her, and she not condescending to his unlawful desire, hath taken her away by force, and keeps her by force.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Have you, Witness?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I have two Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That is sufficient; let them be ready at the next Sessions.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But Sir, I desire not to appear as Plaintiff, for I have got another Gentleman to be Plaintiff; and my Friends are without, Sir, if you please to see them.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Well, call them.

div.stage: Enter the Lieutenant and Cornet.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I shall serve you as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Lieut. & Cor.
sp.p: We thank you Sir.

div.stage: Exit Serjeant.
Enter Dick, Will, Harry and Captain.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We are come to know if we shall have a Hearing?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: My Master hath promised to Plead on our behalf.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: We desire no more.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But I am to inform this Society, That there is a very rich old Lady, (a Widow) who these three Rich Men court; The Usurer did Wooe her, and the Lawyer and Physician do Wooe her; now if any one of you could cozen these Three of the Lady, it would be a Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But should not any one of us cozen our selves, or she cozen us to marry her? for she is so old, that there is no hopes of Posterity.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why shall we desire Posterity, so long as we are poor? and if any one of us should ever come to be so happy as to be Rich, if he hath no Children, and chance to die, let him leave his Wealth amongst the Society of poor Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Content, content.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But which of us shall address himself to this old Lady?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Dick Traveller is most likely to speed.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I have white Hairs; wherefore I am confident I shall be refused.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The truth is, the only Man that is probable to speed, is Harry Sencible; for he hath a young smooth face, and old Women love young smooth fac'd Men alife.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, but a young Man doth not love an old Woman; wherefore she is a fitter match for Dick then for me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Harry is in the right, Dick is the fittest Match for her; but the difficulty will be, how to make the Match, for we shall find it more difficult for all us Men to cozen one Woman, then for one Woman to cozen all us Men.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: It is impossible; wherefore let us never endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: But we will never lose any design for want of endeavour.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I will tell you my Masters, how to compass this design.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Harry shall put himself into a Woman's Habit, and Madam Informer who is acquainted with the Lady, shall prefer Harry to be her Chamber-Maid, where he may have time and opportunity to commend Dick, and to bring him acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: He may do some good in that, and perchance not.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: It is but trying.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I like the design so well, as I am resolved to become a Chamber-Maid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But we shall want thy Company in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p:
No, no, I am confident I shall get leave sometimes
to go abroad, or find some ways or other to slip out.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: But you cannot change your Habit suddenly.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I shall not have occasion, for you all know me.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Come, come, let us about this business.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But first you must go with me to hear the Cause try'd.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Content, content. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Roger, Solus.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: If my young Mistress should have a perfect Idea of me, and then a strong Imagination, she might prove with Child again, and so my Master would be a Platonick Cuckold.

div.stage: Enter Get-all.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Roger, where is my Platonick Wife and Child?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: In the Chamber with the Milch-Nurse.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: My Family is well increased since I have been a Platonick Husband and Father.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I hope your Worship will not want Heirs to inherit your Wealth?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: No, no, I cannot want Heirs, the way being so easie to get them.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But hath not your Worship a mind to get her with Child, after a Corporeal manner?

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p:
Faith Roger, she is tempting, being young and handsome; but if I should get her with Child as our
fore-fathers got us, I fear this Learned age will punish me, either with death or intolerable Fines.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: But if there be no Witness, they cannot prove it; for this Platonick Son and Heir of your Worships, appears as if it had been got by a Corporeal action.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: You say true; wherefore call your Mistress.

div.stage: The while he Walks, Enter Mistress Peg.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: My Imaginary Wife, how doth our Imaginary Son?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But doth he Corporeally suck?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: I wonder at that; but my greatest wonder is, how that an Incorporeal Conception, should come to be a Corporeal Child!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis like Spirits that take Bodies, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But may I not lawfully get you with Child after a Corporeal manner?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes surely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Then let us go to bed, and try if I can get a Child after the old Corporeal way, for I never knew when this Child was gotten.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But I must be Ceremoniously Married first.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Hang Ceremony, those Children never come to good that are got with Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But I cannot lie with you Corporeally, unless you honestly marry me.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But I tell you, I did not know when I got this Child which I am forced to own.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir; but that was begot by your Idea, and my Imagination, and not personally; wherefore, if you desire to lie with me, you must first Marry me, otherwise the Law will severely punish us, and they would be glad we should give them that occasion, that they might take away your Wealth.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Faith, thou shall rather breed by Conceit, then I Marry really; but if we must not lie together Corporeally, may not we kiss Corporeally?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I did never kiss any Man but in the way of a civil Salute.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But did not my Idea and your Imagination kiss?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but not Corporeally.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Faith, I have a Natural desire to thee; but I dare not Marry thee, for fear I should be made a Cuckold, as I have been made a Father.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Truly I am very Chast, and shall make a very honest Wife; and if you will promise to Marry me, I will discover by whom you have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: If you can prove your self honest, I will.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
Then know Sir, This Child which is laid to your Charge, is none of mine, but a Bastard of my Brother's, Captain Valour; but by reason my Brother was ruin'd in the Civil Wars, and I having lost my Portion in his ruine, I had not Means to maintain me
honestly, according to my quality; wherefore, hearing you were a very worthy person, and Rich, and an unmarried Man, I desired my Brother's assistance in the design of getting you to be my Husband; but the design could not take effect if we had not counterfeited a Spiritual Court and Judge, which Judge was Mr. Traveller; and the Doctor Mr. Will Fullwit; and the Lawyer was Mr. Sencible; and my Brothers, Lieutenant and Major, Witnesses, all gallant valiant Men, but poor Cavaliers; so that the design was honest, but the management was full of deceit.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: But what was she that was the Midwife.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: An honest ancient Gentlewoman, whose Husband was kill'd in the Wars.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Well, since you have so ingenuously told me the truth, I will Marry thee for thy honest wit; for he's a fool that will marry a fool.

div.stage: Enter Judges as in a Court of Judicature, and Serjeant Barister as a Pleader at the Bar, and his Clerk with a bag of Papers; also Harry Sencible as the Defendant, and Will Fullwit and Dick Traveller as Witnesses, the Captain as a Plaintiff, and the Lieutenant and Anciant as Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p:
May it please your Lordships, I am here to Plead in my Clients behalf against Mr. Sencible, who against the Laws of Honour, Honesty, and Civil Government, hath a young Gentlewoman of good Birth and Education (but poor) in his keeping, not by the
Gentlewoman's (or Friends) Consent, but by constraint and force, inclosing her in a Chamber, under Locks and Bolts, lest she should escape from him.

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: Where is your Witnesses?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: Here my Lords.

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: Will you both Swear these Accusations for a truth?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: We are ready to Swear whensoever the Book is offered.

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: What says the Defendant?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My Lords, I will confess the truth, but I desire Justice, and that my Accusation against Serjeant Plead-all, may be heard.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Good my Lords, grant his Request; for I fear not what can be said against me.

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: We grant his Request.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p:
Then my Lords, I freely confess that I have such a Gentlewoman in my keeping, as I am accused, and do keep her under Lock and Key; not for fear she should leave me, but for fear some man should steal her away from me; for in this age Men are like hungry Wolves, seeking to devour the Virginity and Reputation of young handsome Women: But this young Gentlewoman who I do so carefully keep, is my own Natural Sister, which these two worthy Gentlemen, Mr. Fullwit and Mr. Traveller, will witness; besides, I can bring all my Neighbours that will witness the same; and since Serjeant Plead-all hath endeavoured to disgrace
me, not only before your Lordships, but before a Court full of People; I think it not unmeet, for me to declare to your Lordships, That Serjeant Plead-all hath at this present kept in his House a Gentlewoman, as a Servant, in Man's Clothes, whose Birth and Breeding is better then his own.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: My Lords, I deny his Impeachment; and if he can prove that I have a Woman in Man's Clothes, that is a Houshold Servant of mine, I will Marry her, were she an old Witch.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My Lords, this Assembly is sufficient witness of what he hath said, as also what I have said; and to prove what I say is true, here is the Gentlewoman who serves him as his Clerk, in Man's Clothes, she is Sister to Mr. Fullwit, which he and others will witness, and she her self confesses.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: My Lords, I do confess I am a Woman, and out of love to Serjeant Plead-all did take this disguise, which I hope is pardonable, since it is not a breach of the Laws of the Kingdom, whatsoever it may be in modesty.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: How is this! my Clerk a VVoman! and must be my VVife! I am finely cozen'd i'faith!

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: VVe beseech your Lordships to give your Judgment.

sp.speaker: Judges.
sp.p: Our Judgment is, That you are free, and the Serjeant must Marry his She-Clerk.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Father, with his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Daughter.
sp.p: PRay Sir, tell me whether you approve of my Choice?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: To speak truly, Daughter, you have chosen very wisely; but how your Youth will agree with Age, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: Never fear it Sir, for I shall love Age in a Husband, better then Youth in my self.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Well, Heaven bless you.

div.stage: Enter a Messenger from the young Suiters.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Sir, Report says, that the Lady your Daughter, is to be Married to an ancient Man, to the great disgrace of her other Suiters, Youth, Beauty, and Bravery; and therefore they desire, that before she Marries, she would be pleased to give them all a publick Audience.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.p: Daughter, answer this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p: Sir, pray tell them, that I cannot civilly deny their Request, in case they'l be pleased to give me leave to make a publick answer.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: No question, Madam, but they will, and I shall inform them of what you say. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Jane Fullwit in her Woman's Habit, and Serjeant Plead-all.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: VVEll Mistress, your VVit and your Person hath not only excused your deceit, but I am so in Love with you, that I would not but have been deceived for all the World.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Sir, with your pardon, there is one more deceived besides your self, and another like to be.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: VVho be those?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: He that is deceived, is Get-all the Usurer, and he that shall be deceived is Doctor Cure-all.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: What, my two Rivals?

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Then they cannot laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: If they do, you may laugh at them again.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I would the old Lady was deceived.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: She will in a short time.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Faith, I find that the Cavaliers are the best deceivers.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: They have been so oft deceived themselves, that they have learned by their misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: But we will not deceive each other, but go to your Brother to dispatch our Marriage.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Captain, Lieutenant, Cornet, and Will Fullwit, then enters Harry in a Chamber-Maids Habit.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Mrs. Harry you are welcome, how doth your good Lady? She makes a Curtsie ill-favouredly.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My Lady at this time is troubled with Love in the Heart, and Gout in the Toe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Is Dick Traveller the cause of the Love-sick heart?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: No, it is the Lawyer's young Clerk.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: He is discovered.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Yes, but I will not suffer any to inform her of it.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: But if her mind be so young, I doubt we may despair of our design.

div.stage: Enter Dick Traveller.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Mrs. Harry, give me leave to salute you.

div.stage: He makes a Curtsie, and he salutes him.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Faith Harry, you kiss like a Woman; I pray Jove you be not turn'd Female with wearing a Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: If I be, I pray Jove I may not be such a Female as my old Lady is.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But how goeth on our design?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Fast towards a young man, but slowly towards a gray head.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What young Man?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: The Lawyer's Clerk.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: What is she in Love with honest Jack? but she is discovered.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But she knows not of it, for she is almost desperate; and between every groan of pain, she sighs for Love.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why, then there is no hopes for me.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Not unless you are presented in the Name of the Clerk, and marryed by Candle-light; for she being half blind, will never distinguish which is which.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Faith, Harry's Counsel is good.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But if she be as deaf as she is blind, we shall not need to dissemble his Name.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But Harry, do you think she will live long?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: My only fear is, she will hardly live so long that he may be Married to her.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I hope she is not so desperately sick.

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.p: If she should die before Dick is marryed, we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: If she should, it would be worse then our Cashiering.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Take comfort Gentlemen, for old Women are such dry and tough meat, that Death cannot set his Teeth into them, nor his Dart enter them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Will says true; for perchance she may last longer then Dick would have her.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I would have her live till I am marryed to her, and then let her die assoon as she will.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, I dare stay no longer for fear my Lady should chide me most grievously.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thou art a most grievous Rogue.

div.stage: Exit Harry.
Enter Serjeant and Jane.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Hey-day, who comes here!

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: We are come to have you for a Witness to our Marriage, since you proved so good a one at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Stay so long, till we see an end of our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: If your Comedy be long, I shall not have patience.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It shall be short, and you shall have more Bridals to accompany you.

div.stage: Enter Harry.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I have been at home with my Mistress; but all the plot of Jack Clerk was revealed to her, whilst I was here; O Mr. Plead-all, I cry you mercy, I saw you not.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Harry pray conceal not any thing for my being here; for I thank you, I am now become one of the Society.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: And how do you like of the Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: So well, as I would not be a stranger for any other good.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I presume Mrs. Jane hath pleased you well.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: So well, as I am confident I shall be happy in my Marriage: But how doth the old Lady take the discovery of my She-Clerk?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Faith, as ill as she would take the discovery of her He-Chamber-Maid; the truth is, she hath been in such passions, as she is almost transform'd to Mummy.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That she was before the discovery.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But now she is more perfect Mummy then she was; but I, to comfort her, have promised to bring her a handsome young Man, only he is taller and bigger, as being a Man; and I did reason with her so long, that I have perswaded her to love a Man, rather then a Boy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And will she come to reason?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: She will, upon condition he be a young Man.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But how shall I make my self appear to be a young Man?

sp.speaker: Cornet.
sp.p: You are not so old, but you may appear in the dark to be a young Man.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Appear, say you! how the Devil can he appear in the dark?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, for the good of the Common-Weale, I have devised a way, how Dick shall appear like a young Man to a blind eye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, I know no difference between the dark and a blind eye.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Hang you, a Pox of you all, I meant a dim eye.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Come, dim or blind, let's hear your design.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: This is the design, Dick shall first shave as close as may be, and then paint his Face, and with a handsome Perriwig, and fine Clothes, he will appear a Young Man to an Old Woman.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, the Paint must be laid on his Face as thick as Morter on a Wall, otherwise his age will be seen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not to a dim eye.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why, I have not such Wrincles in my face as requires much filling up.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I will warrant you, that I will get such an Artist, that if Dick's VVrincles were as deep as a Sawpit, they should be clos'd up, and his face appear fair and even, if not smooth; wherefore Dick, get a handsome Perriwig, and put on your best Suit of Clothes, and I will send a Painter to your Chamber; then go to her, for she expects thee, and carry a Priest, and some Witnesses, and Marry her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Will not you be there?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I cannot, but I have left those in her house that shall conduct you to her; but I must go about my Sisters affairs, where I must desire all the Company to meet me at Doctor Cure-all's House.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: We will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: But the Cornet and Lieutenant must go with me to be my Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Take them.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Doctor and his Man.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: GIve me my Cloak, for now the Clerk being proved a Woman, I hope the old Lady will accept of me, and that will be a double good fortune; first, that my Rival is cheated; next, that I shall be Master of the Ladies Riches.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Doth your Worship mean the old Lady?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Who should I mean else?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir, she was Married last Night, about one of the Clock, as her Servant told me this Morning.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Married! to whom?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To a young Cavalier, one Mr. Dick Traveller.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What the Devil, hath he Married her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I know not whether the Devil Married them, but certainly they are Married.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, he is older then I.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He hath past for a young Man with the Lady.

div.stage: Enter another Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: Sir, there's a young Gentlewoman desires to speak with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis some comfort to converse with a young Woman, after the loss of an old—

div.stage: The Doctor goes forth, and enters leading Mrs. An. Sencible.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Lady, wherein may I serve you?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, I am to desire your assistance for the Cure of a Disease I am troubled with.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What Disease?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The Disease is Love.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Truly, Lady, a Physician hath no Remedy for that Disease, unless the Party be in Love with the Physician.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The truth is, Sir, I am in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: With me Lady!

div.stage: Enter Sencible, and when he enters, he sees his Sister, he starts back and frowns, she seems to be afraid.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Is the Doctor and you so well acquainted, as you two to be private alone.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Truly I was never here before.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I will assure you, Mr. Sencible, she speaks truth, for she was never here to my knowledg before.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I perceive you both agree in a Story, and I take it as an affront you should entertain my Sister in private.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I vow to Heaven I never saw her before this time, nor knew I that you were her Brother.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: This answer will not serve me, for I will have satisfaction; and as for you, Sister, I will offer you up as a Sacrifice to Honour.

div.stage: He draws his Sword, she shreeks out, and runs behind the Doctor, the Doctor strives to defend her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Sir, 'Tis unworthy to draw your Sword upon
a Woman, or to fight with an unarmed Man.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I do not intend to fight with you at this time, but to kill my Sister.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: For visiting a Man, and being alone with him in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why is that such a Crime?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: 'Tis such a Crime, that unless she can prove she is Married, or assured, I will kill her.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Good Doctor save my life.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then Sir, give me leave to tell you, we are agreed to Marry, may we have your consent?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I must have time to ask the advice of some dear Friends first.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Dear Brother consent, without advice.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: That I will not.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Then send for your Friends hither.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I have no body here to send.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You may have two or three of my Servants if you please. Enter a Man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There is two Gentlemen below that desire to speak with Mr. Sencible.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: They are come as I desired, pray bring them in. Enter Will Fullwit, and the Captain. Dear Will, and Captain, I was sending for you both, to ask your advice about a Cause that hath much troubled me, which is a great concernment both to my Justice and Honour.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I coming to see Doctor Cure-all, found my Sister out of my House, discoursing here alone with the Doctor, which is a great discredit for a young Virgin, to be not only abroad without attendance, but in Company with a Man alone, and in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That is not well, I did not believe Mrs. Anne Sencible would have done such an act.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the Lady is in no fault, for she and I are agreed to marry, if her Brother consents.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: That is another Case; and will not you give your consent Harry?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall consent.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you shall Harry; Doctor give me your hand, and Mrs. Sencible give me yours, so joyn them together; do you agree truly and really to Marry?

sp.speaker: Both Answer.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Sencible, give them joy of their Contract.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: I wish you Both joy.

div.stage: Enter to the Doctor, Mrs. Peg Valorosa, Get-all, Serjeant Plead-all, and Mrs. Jane Fullwit.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Come, come, Captain Valorous, let us go to the Church, for I am impatient.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Not so impatient as I.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, we come in here but to take another Couple along with us.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Are they agreed?

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: They are, they are; there only wants that Ceremony, You do, and all is sure.

div.stage: Enter Dick Traveller, Lieutenant and Cornet.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I am come only to make one to fill up the Matrimonial Triumphs.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: How doth my old Lady like the young Blade?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: So well, as she is so well pleased, as it hath made her half young again.

div.stage: Enter Mistress Informer.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Welcome Mrs. Informer.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: By my troth, my heart did tremble, for fear I should not come time enough to these fortunate Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Get-all.
sp.p: Well, to let all this Company see, that I the first deceived, am as well, if not better, pleased then I the deceivers; here I do promise to give my Brother, that must be Captain Valorous, Twenty thousand pounds to maintain his Bastards, to discharge his Whores, and to Marry a Virtuous and Honourable Wife; also, I give Doctor Feel-pulse, Will Fullwit, Five thousand pounds; and Harry Sencible Five thousand more; and Five thousand pound to the Lieutenant; and Five thousand pounds between the Cornet and Mrs. Informer; as for my Judg Dick Traveller, I did intend to have fee'd him well, and to give him money to have bought a place in the Arches, but he is better provided.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p:
I cannot present the whole Society, but I will
make my Brother Fullwit's Five thousand pounds, you gave him, Ten.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: So will I give as much to my Brother Harry Sencible.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: And I will present the rest of the Society.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Let's go unto Church to make all sure,
For nothing in Extreams will long endure.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Stay we must go to the Hearing of my Cousin Prudence's Cause first, and then we shall have another couple.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Scene is a Publick Hall, or Pleading-Court, wherein is a Publick Assembly, the Young Suiters and some other Gallants, taking one Bar, and the Young Lady and her Old Suiter another; and all Bridal Couples.

sp.speaker: One of the Young Suiters
sp.p: Most Noble Auditors.

I Am chosen by my fellow-Sufferers to declare the Injustice and Injury this young Lady has done us, and her self, by refusing us that are young, handsome, healthy and strong, for an old, infirm, weak and decayed Man, who has neither a clear Eye-sight to admire her Beauty, nor a perfect Hearing to be informed of her Wit; nor sufficient Strength to fight in her behalf, or defend her Honour; nor that heat of affection that he
can love her as she deserves. Indeed, it is not to be suffer'd that Old Men and Women should Marry Young Persons; for it is as much as to tie or bind the Living and Dead together; for, though it cannot be truly said, that old age is dead, yet we may say, 'tis rotten, and Corruption is next to death; for all Creatures corrupt before they dissolve; and we are taught by our holy Fathers, that we must put off the Old Man, and put on the New Man: Wherefore, 'tis not lawful for this young Lady to Marry that old Man, it being both against Church and State, as not profitable to either, but disadvantagious to both.

sp.speaker: The Ladies
sp.p: Most Noble Auditors,

I Come not here to express either my Wit or Malice, but to defend my honest Cause, and to express my true Love; Wherefore, I shall briefly answer this Gentleman's Objections: First, as for the Injustice he accuses me of, I utterly deny that I am guilty, for to make a lawful Choice is no Injustice to them; and to refuse a young Man before an old and wise one, is no Injury to my self; Next, what he says of their Handsomness, Health and Strength; I answer, that in my opinion, a handsome Man is an error in Nature, and Health and Strength are very uncertain in young Men, for their Vices decay one, and impair the other, before
their Natural time; whereas, the Infirmities of Old Age are Natural, neither infectious, unwholsome or dangerous to their Wives: And though ancient Men have not their Hearing so quick, nor their Eye-sight so clear as young Men, yet have they quicker Wits, and clearer Understandings, acquired by long Experience of all sorts of Actions, Humors, Customs, Discourses, Accidents, and Fortuns amongst Mankind; Wherefore, old Men cannot chuse but be more Knowing, Rational and Wife then Young. Concerning the Church and State, since they do allow of buying and selling young Maids to Men to be their VVives, they cannot condemn those Maids that make their bargain to their own advantage, and chuse rather to be bought then sold, and I confess I am one of the number of those; for I'le rather chuse an old Man that buys me with his VVealth, then a young one, whom I must purchase with my VVealth; who, after he has wasted my Estate, may sell me to Misery and Poverty. Wherefore, our Sex may well pray, From Young Mens ignorance and follies, from their pride, vanity and prodigality, their gaming, quarelling, drinking and whoring, their pocky and diseased bodies, their Mortgages, Debts and Serjeants, their VVhores and Bastards, and from all such sorts of Vices and Miseries that are frequent amongst Young Men, Good Lord deliver Us. But for fear of such a Misfortune as to be a VVise to a young Man, I will Marry this ancient Man, and so, Cousins, I am, if you please, ready to wait on you to Church.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THE Sociable Companions we hope do fit
Your Judgments, Fancies, and your better Wit:
This Lady is Ambitious, I dare say,
That all Her hopes is, That you'l like her Play.
Which favour, She esteems at a high rate,
'Bove Title, Riches, or what's Fortune's Fate;
She listens, with a trembling ear; She stands
Hoping to hear Her Joy, by your glad Hands.

div.head: SCENE I. As an Introduction to the Play.
div.stage: Enter two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman.
sp.p: TOM, How do you like the New Plays?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: As I like an Old Wife, Not well.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: If the judgment of the Stage should hear you, they would condemn you.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Faith, that Condemnation would be a Commendation to me, and a reproach to themselves; for those that cannot judge of Wit, cannot judge of Me.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Cannot they judg of Wit, say you?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: No, for those that understand not Wit, cannot judge of Wit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Do they not understand Wit?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: No, for if they did, they would not applaud Plays, that have neither Humour, Wit, nor Satyr; which are those they name New Plays, made up of Old Romances.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But New Plays have Plots, Designs, Catastrophes and Intrigues.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What are those?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Those are to express Policy, Ingenuity and Art; besides, they describe Love, Justice, Honour, and the like.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Why, Seneca doth express Moral Virtues, and Machiavillian Policy, better and more properly then Dramatick Poetry; and the Spectators will learn more in one day by reading their Works. or such like Authors, then by seeing forty Plays, and less Charge: Besides, it doth lessen the esteem of such grave Learning, neither is it more proper for Plays then the Scripture is.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But the Scripture was Acted in the old time.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p:
Truly, and I have heard they were foolish Plays, although made out of the Sacred Scripture; and that there was a Superscription of one Play set upon a Post, which was thus, Here is a Play to be seen of King Saul, with the merry Conceits of David and Goliah;
which certainly was profane. But a Stage is not an University, Grammar-School, or Church; for by such actions or descriptions, it would rather abuse Religion, and corrupt Learning, then advance them; for though the Stage may be very beneficial to young persons to learn good Behaviour, Discourse and Wit, yet not to learn Morality and Divinity; and as for Policy, all Men are naturally apt to be Dissemblers, they shall not need to be instructed; also, concerning the description of foolish Romancical Love, it doth but corrupt the minds and thoughts of Men and Women, which causes not only foolish and unhappy Marriages, but wicked Adulteries.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But pray tell me what you mean by that you name Satyr? whether you do not mean railing?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: No, for railing is to speak ill of particular persons; but Satyr is to reprove general Vices.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: And what do you mean by Wit and Humour?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: By Wit I mean similizing, and distinguishing of Words and Things; by Humour I mean the Behaviours, Dispositions and Practices of Mankind; all which good Comedies will inform Youth better, then far and dangerous Travels; but as for Morality and Policy, as I said before, they are more proper for Schools and States, then for Stages.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But Lovers Scenes are most pleasing to the Spectators, and are the best part in a Play.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: In my opinion the Lover's part is the worst part; but as for such Love-making as is in the New Plays, it would give me as good a vomit to see it, as Crocus Mettallorum steept in wine, or the like, and swallow'd down my throat.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter as in the Presence, Mons. Conversant, Mons. Observer, and Mons. Mode.

sp.speaker: Conversant.
sp.p: GOod Morrow Gentlemen; Mons. Mode, did not you attend the Emperor to the Chappel to day?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: No, but I am going to attend him from the Chappel.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: It had been better you had attended him into the Chappel for your own sake, for there you might have said your Prayers, which, it is probable, you Courtiers seldom do.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, we Courtiers have little time to pray; for what with Dressing, Trimming, Waiting, Ushering, Watching, Courting, and the like, all our time is spent.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: It seems Courtiers are so much concern'd with their bodies, as they regard not their Souls.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
Pleasure lives with the Body, and we Courtiers live with Pleasure; as for the Soul it is not well known what it is; but let it be what it will, or can be, or
is, yet it belongs more to another World, then to this; which other World we Courtiers care not for, nor think thereof; we only desire to be happy in this World, for we are well content to quit the Happiness of the next World for the pleasure of this present World.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But yet when Courtiers come to die, they will wish they had thought more of the next VVorld, and less of this.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, we Courtiers never think of Death, until Death think of us; and when Death remembers us so, as to take us out of this World, we believe we shall only die and turn to dust, and be no more; we are only troubled and grieved that our Masking delights are at an end, and that our light of life, and delights of Pleasures must be put out by Death's Exstinguisher; the truth is, with Court-Gallants, Court-Officers, and State-Magistrates, it is according to the old observation, which is, They live without Conscience, and die without fear.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I did believe that Courtiers had been so vain, that they could not be so valiant, as to die without fear.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
There are many sorts of Valours, or rather I may say, Courages; for though most Courtiers have not Valour to fight Duels, or in Battels; yet they have courage to run in debt, not fearing Imprisonment, and they have courage to Court Mistresses, not fearing the Pox; also, they have courage to flatter, cozen, dissemble,
profess, protest, and then betray, not fearing dishonour.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Will not Courtiers fight, say you?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: No faith, if they can chuse to avoid it; for we Courtiers are Men for life, and not for death; for though we are Men of Action, yet not Warlike Actions.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: In what are Courtiers active?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: In Dancing, Racing, Tennis-playing, Carding, Dicing, and the like; for should a Soldier become a Courtier, he would become a Coward in a short time; for the Pleasures of the Court do abate the Courage of War.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I believe you, because you are a Courtier, and know a Courtier best; but I fear you will not appear a diligent Attendant, if you go not to the Chappel to wait upon the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: You say true, wherefore farwell.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But before you go, pray inform us of the cause that makes the Princess so Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: That which makes most Women Melancholy, to wit, Amorous Love.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: 'Tis said, that it is a pleasing pain; but is the Princess in Love?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: With no body.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Can she be in Love with no body?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Yes faith, rather then Women, will not be in love, they will love no body.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: That is impossible.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: It is not impossible, if an Idea be no body; and 'tis said, Thoughts are Ideas.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I suppose that no Women are in love with their own Thoughts, for if they were, they would think more, and speak less; wherefore, you are mistaken; for Women are in love with their own Words.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: If they be, their love is placed still upon no body; for the old opinion is, That Words are bodiless: But the Princess is in love with an Idea she met with in a Dream in the Region of her Brain; and unless she may enjoy this Idea, not only awake, but imbodied, she cannot be at rest in her mind!

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: If this be true, it is a strange Love!

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: It is as true as strange, and as strange as true; and all the Ladies in the Court are become Dreaming-Lovers to imitate the Princess.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: All the Ladies, say you?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Yes faith, All, both Maids, Widows and Wives.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: As for Wives, it is fit they should never have other Lovers, both for their Husbands and their own sake; for then their Love and Lovers cannot possibly be known, if they can but keep their own Counsels.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: But they cannot keep their own Counsels, for if they could, they would never have divulged their Amorous Dreams. Exit Mode.

div.stage: Enter Spend-all to Conversant and Observer.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Monsieur Spend-all, I wish you joy of your Preferment, for I hear you have a place bestow'd upon you, agreeable and proper for your Pastime and Profession; for you being a great Gamester, are made Croom-Porter.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No faith, but I am not; for Keep-all, the old miserable Userer, is made Groom-Porter.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Why, that is very well; for he may put out his Money to use amongst the Gamesters, and have Am's ace for his Interest; but if he be made Groom-Porter, you shall be Lord Treasurer.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No faith, I would have but one Office, if I might have my choice.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: What Office is that?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Master of the Mint.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: That will not do you much good, unless you were Master of the Coyn; but if you were Master of the Coyn, you would play all away at Cards and Dice, Tennis, and such like Games.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: If I did, I should do but as most Gentlemen do, that have Estates, which spend their Money for their pleasure, and I take Pleasure in Gaming.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But not to lose.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I had rather lose, then not play.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I did believe that Gamesters play'd more out of covetousness, then for pleasure.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You mistake; for Gamesters are more in love
with Cards, Dice, and Rackets, then Lovers are with Women.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: And I believe Gamesters fear Fortune more then Lovers do the Spiritual Court, the Parish-Constable, or the City-Watch.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, Fortune is like most Magistrates, or great Officers, who will cruelly punish some, and partially favour others; and all her actions are without Reason and Justice.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: But you cannot bribe Fortune.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, and in that respect Lovers have the better of Gamesters.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But Gamesters are for the most part Lovers.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, no; for a Gamester cannot spare so much time, as to kiss a Mistress; but fare you well, for I must go to the Porters Lodge.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But tell me truly, before you go, whether Keep-all the Usurer is made Groom-Porter?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: The truth is, I did but jest; for he is not Groom-Porter, but the Knave of Clubs is made Groom-Porter.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: If it be so, then that place is properly served, for the Knave of Clubs is a fit person for that Office.

div.stage: Exeunt Men.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter the Princess and her Governess.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: VVHich of the Gods and Goddesses shall I pray to assist me, since my beloved is Spiritual, and not Mortal, at least not Temporal; but yet he is not Coelestial; for surely an Idea is not a god, although it be not a bodily Creature?

sp.speaker: Govern.
sp.p: But Souls may meet and converse, and enjoy each other.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How meet?

sp.speaker: Govern.
sp.p: In the Mind.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But that's no satisfaction to Humane kind.

sp.speaker: Govern.
sp.p: I know not whether Satisfaction doth, but surely Tranquility lives in the Mind; and the god of Dreams hath presented the Idea, which surely is the Soul of some Noble and Meritorious Lover, as a reward to your Vertue.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How foolishly you talk! as if the gods were Lover's Mediators: But if they should humble themselves in such Amorous Imployments, and did present this Idea, then I should enjoy it every time I sleep; but alass, I never did perceive it but once, and then like as a Heavenly Vision, no sooner perceived, but vanished away.

sp.speaker: Govern.
sp.p: But can you love so much upon so small an acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I am of Marlow's opinion, Who ever lov'd, that loves not at first sight!
But this Idea is fixed in my heart,
And whilst I live will never thence depart:
But I will make Apelles my dear Saint,
And he shall both my Love and Passion paint.
Apelles, draw this Passion in my Heart,
And make the Picture of my Love by Art:
For thou the first was he that did invent
To Figure Passions, and them to present
To object's sence; and if so, then I
May my Idea by my eyes descrie;
For all Ideas they, as 〈◊〉 prove,
They are not Substance, but in Substance move.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Mode to Observer and Spend-all.

sp.speaker: Observer.
sp.p: ARe the Ladies coming into the Presence?

sp.speaker: Mode,
sp.p: No, they all keep their beds to enjoy their Lovers so, as they sleep to dream, and dream to be embraced.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: They shall not need to do that, for they may be embraced awake.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: O fie! that is an old out-worn fashion, and is more proper for old Ladies, then young.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Sure you mistake; for Dreams are more proper for old Ladies, and waking-embraces for young.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Nay, then you mistake, for young Ladies love Amorous Contemplations, otherwise they would not delight so much in Romances as they do; but old Ladies who have more experience, and so are wiser, love the fruition of Realities; which makes them love young Men, not in Dreams or Romances, but in Courts and Cities.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: If so, then young Men may despair of young Women, and old Women not be jealous of young Women; and if I were sure of that, I would presently clap up a Match with an old doting Lady that I am acquainted withal, who is as rich as old.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: You had best make hast for fear you should have Rivals; for if all young Men despair, the old Women will be so Wooed, that the multiplicity and choice will make them as nice, coy and proud, as the most prime young Beauties.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You say true, wherefore I will be beforehand, and go to her before she hears of this dreaming-fashion.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But how if this fashion should soon change to a quite opposite?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, there is the danger; therefore I will not go.

div.stage: Enter the young Princess Melancholy, and some Ladies, whereof one rubs her eyes, the other gapes, the third stretches her self; all passing over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Lord bless us! what a drowsie fashion the Ladies have got?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But to my view, they were hot so drowsie but they did leer upon us.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: That was to view if any of us was the Man they dream'd of.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: O Lord! if it be thy will, let me be the Man the Princess dreams of.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And I desire I might be the Man they all did dream of; which if so, the Grand Signior would not be better served, then I should; nor more numerously, for I should have all the young Women in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: If you had, you could not Marry them all.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, but I could Manage them all.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: They would rather Manage you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I should be well pleas'd to be Managed by a young Lady.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: But not by so many young Ladies as are in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: If he were, he would be Managed so, as to be a lame Jade. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Lady Quick-wit, and Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Quick-wit.
sp.p: SElf-conceit, the new Maids are come that are to be our Chamber-fellows.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Where, where are they? for God's sake, tell me quickly, I long to see them; but are they handsome?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, by my troth; for one of them is so bashful, that what Beauty Nature hath given her, is spoiled for want of breeding; the other is none of Nature's choicest Pieces.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But what are they?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: They are gone by the back-staires, to the Princess.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: The Princess keeps her Chamber to day.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, but she has permitted them into her Presence.

div.stage: Enter all the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Gallants, are the new Maids come from the Princess?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: No, we come to see them; for it is said, they are very handsome.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I have heard by two or three, That they are not handsome.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: They are coming, they are coming.

div.stage: Enter the Mother, and the Lady Bashful.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Where is the Princess, Gentlemen, to give the Oath to this young Lady?

div.stage: All the Gentlemen come to Salute Her.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Mother, will you give me leave to Salute your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Should I not give you leave. you would take leave. He Salutes the young Maid.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Lady, you will add to the Splendour of the Court.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Lady, you will advance the Glory of your Sex. He Salutes Her.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Mother, you are one of the fortunatest Mothers that ever came to the Court; for here was never such a company of Beauties at one time, as is at this time.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Come, come, you are all Flatterers; wherefore my Daughter beware of them.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Mother, your new-come Daughter is bashful.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You must perswade her to hold up her head.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: What eyes has she, black or gray?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Well, well, pray have patience; for by that time she has been in the Court so long as either of you, has been, she will be as confident as any in the Court.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But Mother where is your other new Daughter?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She is coming forth; and by my faith she is a metled Lass indeed. But come Daughter Bashful, we must go seek the Gentleman that must give you your Oath. Exit Mother, and Lady Bashful.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Lord! how simply she looks!

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Give me a simple Girl; I love to teach, not to learn.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: What a dull eye she has!

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: A Melancholy eye, for variety, sometimes pleases best.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: She has an unfortunate brow.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Her brows seem like a bow, that's ready bent to shoot Love's glances forth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: She hangs down her head as if she were working of Cross-stitch.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: She looks as if she would be as constant as Penelope was.

div.stage: Enter the other new Maid, the Lady Wagtail.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Where is the Mother, is she always so confident of her Daughters, as to leave them to themselves?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I marry Sir, this Lady seems to have mettal.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: She seems of a free Spirit.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: A Lady of an excellent Presence.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: There is life in her Countenance.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, which way went the Mother?

div.stage: All the Gentlemen run out to seek the Mother, then return back and speak to Her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The Mother will come presently.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, excuse me for troubling you; I should not have been so rude, but that I am ignorant of the wayes in Court, but I shall be industrious to learn them, and then I shall be ready to serve you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: We are all your Vassals, Lady.

div.stage: Lady Wagtail addresses her self to Self-conceit and Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Ladies, I shall be glad to have the honour of your Friendship, and to be endeared to such honourable Sisters.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: We shall be ready to serve you.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Wanton, one of the Maids of Honour, as running into the Room.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Where is my Comrade? where is my Comrade?

div.stage: Wagtail and Wanton meet, Embrace and Kiss each other.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Dear Wagtail, thou art according to my heart.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: My dear Wanton, I make no doubt, but we shall agree very well.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I was so joy'd, when I heard you were allotted to be my Chamber-fellow, for I was so afraid of that clod of dull Earth, the new come fellow; for it is reported that she makes Conditions not to be with such a Chamber-fellow that sits up late, or hath much Company.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: The Princess says, she must be in the Chamber of Mrs. Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: She shall not lie with me, let her lie in the Chamber of Mrs. Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: With me? By my troth, that shall not be, for shall I that have been here this dozen years, have the rubbish thrown into my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Why, then she must lie with the old Mother, there is no other place.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, the old Mother sits up as late with the old Signiors of the Court, as any of her Daughters do with the young Monsieurs. Exeunt Ladies.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I hope if there be no room for the young Lady amongst Women, she will be forced to come to us Men for a Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, we shall quarrel as much, who shall have her, as the Women do, to cast her out of their Company.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I am of the Ladies mind, I would not willingly have her; for she appears with such a divine Purity, as if she would be apt to convert me from my Debauchery, and trouble my Conscience with Repentance. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter Quick-wit and Wagtail.

sp.speaker: Quick-wit.
sp.p: LAdy, I hear you have an admiring Servant.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: For God's sake Lady Quick-wit, tell me who it is?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You know who it is.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Nay, prithee tell me; in faith I know not who it is.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You dissemble in making your self ignorant.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: In truth I do not know; wherefore prithee tell me, for I long to know who it is.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I hope your Servant has not put you into a longing humour?

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: No, but you have, and therefore tell me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis reported, Monsieur Ape is your admiring Servant.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Truly Monsieur Ape is a very fine Person.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Indeed he wears fine Clothes.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: The truth is, he is a neat spruce Courtier.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: He ought to be so, spending most of his time in dressing and trimming himself.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a very Civil Man to our Sex.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: He is so, if it be a Civility to kiss the Ladies Busks, Fans, Gloves, and the tails of their Gowns.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a well-bred Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, if good breeding lies in the Heels, for he dances well.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is an exact Courtier.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis true, for he Flatters and Complements.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a great Scholar.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: He is well read in Fashions, and studies new Modes.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He hath an Elegant speech.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And speaks in a Romancical stile.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: And he has a ready Wit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: To imitate Extravagancies.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a Valiant Man.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: To take foolish Women Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a Politick Man.

sp.speaker: Quick.
