sp.p: He is so, in pretending to have more power with the Emperor then he hath; by which means he gets Clients to Fee him, and simple ignorant Men to Bribe him, for which Fees and Bribes, they have fair words and large promises, but not any performances.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I perceive Monsieur Ape is not your admiring Servant, you speak so spitefully of him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: It seems I am not his admirer, I speak so truly of him.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I must not hear any evil against my Servant Monsieur Ape.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Then you must not hear him mentioned.

div.stage: Enter Lady Self-conceit, with her Portrait.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Quick-wit, I have been seeking you to shew you my Portrait.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What Painter drew it?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: A Painter did not draw it, but a Poetical Lord did write it.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So I perceive a Portrait is a Mode-Phrase for a Character, or a Description; and a Portrait, Character and Description of Particulars, signifies one and the same thing.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yes, but Characters and Descriptions have been so often used, writ and named, that the Readers are so weary'd with those old fashioned names, as it keeps them all from reading the matter or subject of such Writings.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, then the word Portrait is to invite the Readers to read it.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: No doubt of that, and well, if the word Portrait will perswade them to read it; but shall I read my Portrait to you?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, I desire to hear a Portrait, for though I have seen many Portraits, yet I have never heard them speak.

lg.l: Your Curls of Hair like Clouds, yet black as night;
Your Eyes as Stars do give a Sparkling light;
Your Forehead like the Heavens milky way;
Your Nose a hill of Snow in Valley lay;
Your Lips like Rosie-morn when th' Sun doth rise,
Shine on your Chin, as bright as he i'th' skies;
From whence the Beams dilated on your breast,
Do make a Torrid Zone 'tween East and West;
And those that do this Heav'nly Picture view,
Must needs confess 'twas only made for you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Faith, this is like the Painter that drew a Rose for a Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: What, do you call me a Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why? a Woodcock is a fine Bird, and good Meat; but why did not this Portrait-maker draw or describe you no farther then the breast?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: By reason many Persons Pictures are drawn no farther.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: It was a shrewd sign, he could similize no farther.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: He could not go beyond the Heavens.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: In my opinion he has gone too great a Journey in going so far; for I believe it has made his Poetical feet, which I perceive to be diseased with the Gout, too weary; for he has travel'd through the Ecliptick line; but if he have crost the line, I think he must have gone from South to North, a very cold Climate.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I perceive you are spiteful at my Portrait, because you have not one made of you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Can you blame me if I be spiteful to see you Metamorphosed from a Terrestrial Body, to a Coelestial Portrait.

div.stage: Enter Observer and Conversant.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Ladies, how doth the Princess?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Princess is very Melancholy, and it is fear'd she will fall into a Consumption.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But the Emperor to prevent it, will send for all the Gentry and Nobility in the Empire to present themselves to the Princess, and whomsoever she likes, she shall have.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But how if her Idea should prove a Married Man?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The truth is, it disturbs the Thoughts of Married Wives; for those that love their Husbands, are afraid, and those that care not for their Husbands hope; but all the Men are well pleased in hope of being Emperor, for you know the Princess is Heir to the Crown.

div.stage: Enter Mode.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Lady, how doth the Princess?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: She is as all Lovers are, Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Are all Lovers Melancholy?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, when they cannot enjoy their Beloved; and her Beloved is but a shadow, which the more it is follow'd, the farther it flies; wherefore she is Melancholy, as being despised.

div.stage: Self-conceit fighs.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What makes you sigh?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Faith, because I am not a Princess, to have my choice of all the Men in the Empire.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I would not be a Princess upon that condition, for I should be as much troubled to chuse, as to refuse.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: That is a sign you love Men well.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why say you so?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Because you express your trouble, that you should desire more then one, and be loth to deny any.

div.stage: Enter a Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh Ladies, Oh the strange sights that I have seen! the monstrous strange sights that I have seen!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What monstrous sights have you seen?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why, I have seen strange Monsters!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What Monsters?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
I saw Men with strange Heads, and as strange Bodies; for they had the speech of Men, and the upright shape of Men, and yet were partly like as other Creatures; for one Man had an Asses head, and his body was like a Goose; another Man had a Jack-a-napes-head,
but all his body was like a Baboon, and he shew'd tricks, as Jack-a-napes and Baboons use to do; another Man had a Swines head, and all his body was like a Goat; Another had a head like a Stag, with a large pair of branched Horns, and all his body was featur'd like a Woodcock, and his arms were feather'd as a Woodcocks wings, but he could not fly from his disgrace, for his Horned head did hinder the flight of his Wings; Then I saw a Woman that was not like a Mare-Maid, for Mare-Maids are like Women from the head to the waste, and from the waste like a Fish; but this Woman was like a Fish from the head to the waste, and from the waste like a Beast; so that she was a Batons rompus; Another Woman had the eyes of a Crocodile, but her body was like a changeable Cameleon; and many other Monstrous Creatures did I see.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Where did you see those Monsters?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Where they are to be seen.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: In Dreams, when I was asleep.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: It seems you have a Fool's head that dreams such fantastical Dreams.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: The wisest and gravest heads that are, do dream such Dreams; for a Philosopher's head hath butter-flies Dreams; and a Politician, although he has a Foxes head when he is awake, yet he has but an Asse's head when he sleeps.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You are a Knave awake, and a Fool asleep.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Then I am a wise Man.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Is a Knave a wise Man?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: According to the foolishness of the World he is; for if the World of Mankind, which is the most part, were not Fools, Knaves could not cozen them; and those are wiser that deceive, then those that are deceived; at least, they are accounted so by those Fools they have deceived.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: You speak like an Ass.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: If I speak like Balaam's Ass, I speak wisely; but truly Ladies I had a pleasant Dream.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What Dream was that?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I dream'd that all the Princess Maids of Honour did dance about me, and after that they did all kiss me, which was very pleasant to me; for though they danced like Apes, they kissed like Courtisans.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Out, you Rogue, do you say we kiss like Courtisans.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why all Women kiss alike, ask the Gentlemen.

div.stage: Exit Fool.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Come Quick-wit, let us go and see how the Princess doth. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: The Ladies are much concerned for the Princess Sickness.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I believe they are all troubled with that Disease, although they are more crafty to conceal it.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p:
The Emperor is very strict to the Princess, so
that he will not suffer any Man to come near her but Mimick the fool; and he is only suffered to divert her Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: He is more a Knave then a Fool; wherefore he might more safely have trusted the wisest Man in the Kingdom.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: The Princess lies upon a Couch as sick, and her eyes shut. Soft Musick is heard, and a Song sung.

lg.l: You God of Sleep send Dreams for to restore
The Princess mind to be as 'twas before;
Or else you other Gods that dwell above,
Cause her to dream of a Seraphick Love:
Let not her Mortal Soul so cloud the Light
Of her Immortal Soul that shines so bright.
Cast out the vain Idea from her brain,
That nothing of that Figure may remain.

div.stage: After this, the Fool standing at the Door, sings a part of an Old Ballet; as follows.

lg.l: This long seven years and more, have I still lov'd thee,
Do then my joy restore, fair Lady pity me,
Pity my grievous pains long suffer'd for thy sake,
Which will not let me rest, for no rest can I take:
Fair Lady pity me, do not my Suit deny,
O yield me some relief that shall for sorrow die.
How can I pity thee, the Lady then repli'd,
I am no Match for thee, thy Suit must be deny'd;
I am of Royal blood, thou of a mean degree,
It stands not for my Good that I should Marry thee:
This Answer oft I had, which struck my heart full deep,
And on my bed full soft did I lie down and weep.

div.stage: Singing the last Verse, the Fool enters, and the Princess awakes.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How dare you disturb me with your Foolery?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Fools never disturb, for we are made for Laughter, not for anger.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Carry away the Fool to the Porters Lodge, and let him be soundly whipt.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No, carry the Princess to the Emperors Chamber, and let her there be whipt, for she is more Fool then I; for she is in love with a Dream, and I am in love with a Princess; the truth is, I have a great desire to be an Emperor, and you had better love a Fool then a Shadow.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: In truth I will tell the Emperor my Father.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I faith, that will not help you; for he is wise, and knows I am the fittest Match for you; for he knows that when two Fools Marry, they make but one Fool; and he will chuse rather to have but one Fool then two; and when we are Married we shall make one grand Fool, and that will amount, and be as much as indifferently wise.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I will have your Tongue cut out of your Head.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You will as soon cut off my Head; but let me tell you, You shall not; nay by'r Lady, you must not be in this humour, the Emperor commands it, as also that you shall come to him. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Spend-all in a fine Suit of Clothes, meeting Conversant.

sp.speaker: Conversant.
sp.p: JƲpiter bless us! how fine and brave you are, in a rich Suit of Clothes; is this your Wedding day?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, this day is not my Wedding day; but this Suit is my Wooing-Suit, for I am going to Woo an old Lady, who is very Rich.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Is she Wise?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I hope not, for if she were, she would never grant my Suit; but if she be a Fool, as I hope she is, then Youth and Bravery will win her.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: And the more sprightly, lively, and fantastical you appear, the better the old Lady will like you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I believe you; but I doubt that the sight of the old Lady will put me into so dull and Melancholy a humour, as I shall not please her.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Imagine her a young Beauty.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I cannot imagine her a young Beauty, when I see her; for Imagination works only upon absent Objects.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Then think her your Reverend Grand-Dame.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: That will make me think of death, she being dead.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Nay faith, she will rather make you think of a Resurrection.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Can I think an old wrinkled Woman, a glorified body?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I forgot the Glory, I only thought of Life; but however, you may think her a Saint.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: That I cannot, if she marry me, a young, vain, deboist Man, which is, a Sinner.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Imagine she Marries you to convert you from Evil to Good.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Nay faith, she would sooner pervert me, were I good, to evil; but were she a wise, reverend, virtuous aged Woman, I could love her better then a wanton young Filly; also, I should be ruled and govern'd by her experienced advice and counsel; but those ancient Women that are so, will not Marry a wild, vain young Man.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: There is not any thing that can rule, advise, or govern you, but Time.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why, an ancient Woman is Time; for though she be not old Father Time, yet she is old Mother Time.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Well, go to the old Lady, woo her, win her, and Marry her; for if you will wink, or shut your eyes, she will be as pleasing as a young Wife.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Would you have me a blind Wooer, and a blind Husband?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: It would be happy for some Husbands if they were blind, that they might not see their own disgrace; for many a Husband sees his Neighbour in bed with his Wife; and it would be great wisdom in old Women, if they would, or must of necessity, Marry a young Man, to Marry a blind young Man, that he might not see her decays, ruines and wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Well, I will go and try if I can perswade this old Lady to Marry me.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Do so, for it may become a fashion for young Men to Marry old Women.

div.stage: Enter Lady Bashful, Spend-all addresses himself to her.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Lady, I was a while since in the Privy Chamber, where my eyes did search for you, but they could not single you out from the rest of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: It seems that either you were blind, or that I had not any Beauty.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: The Ladies in Court, when they stand close together, are like the Heaven's milky way; for the number of Stars appears like a thick white stream, so as no particular Star can be discerned.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: I had rather be a Meteor singly alone, then a Star in a Crowd. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lady Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Lady, will you give me leave to be your admiring Servant?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The truth is, we Ladies in Court have so many Courting-Servants, that we know not how to govern them.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I shall be govern'd easily; for I will watch your looks with admiration, listen to your words with great attention, study your thoughts with serious Contemplation, and obey all your Commands with pious devotion.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Admiration dazles the sight, sight stops the hearing, hearing hinders the thinking, and action is an enemy to study.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You have so much Wit, Lady, that your Wit is able to govern the whole World.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Wit can easier make a VVorld, then govern a VVorld; for VVit is a better architect then Governor; in truth VVit cannot rule it self; for VVit is ruled by Judgment; and thus by mispraising VVit, you have done Judgment wrong. Exit Quickwit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, I am an unfortunate Man in Courtships.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: That is, because you Complement with the Ladies, that love to have Men talk to them rudely.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: VVell, I will try my own way of Courtship once more, if I can converse with any of them again.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Then you shall never win their favours.

div.stage: Enter Lady Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Lady, you are finer drest then any Lady in the Court.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign I want Beauty, that I am forced to use the art of dressing; and you the flattery of Commendations, seeing I had not Beauty worthy of a true praise.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: The Court is the Sphere of Beauty, Lady.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: And Men are Beauties Gazers.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Men are Love's Astronomers, Lady.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: And what new Star-like Beauty have you found out?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You, Lady.

div.stage: Exit Self-conceit without Answering.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Oh happy Man that I am, for I am a Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Of what are you a Conqueror, of Wit?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No of Love; for silence gives consent.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But you did not woo her to love.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Not woo her! prithee what have I been speaking all this while?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: VVhy, you have been Complementing.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and Complements are Lovers VVooings.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But you forget the old Lady; you were going to woo before you saw these young Ladies.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hang Old Ladies, give me a Young Lady.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But consider, the old Lady is rich.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and I want wealth; wherefore I'le go a wooing to the old Lady, and leave my heart with the young Ladies; but now I think better of it; I will not go, for I believe you stay here to watch a time, to get one of these young Beauties alone.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: No, no, I will stay here to be an Agent in love, for you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I desire no such Agent as you; for you arc a subtile, slie Gentleman; you will take your time and opportunity; besides, you have Lands and Money, which will winn a young Lady sooner, then fine Clothes and Complements will do.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Prithee be not jealous; for young Ladies are not so wise as to love prudently.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What a Pox should you dwell in this Room, if it were not for some such design?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I stay here to observe Humours, hear Wit, and to see Beauties.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And not to make Love?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: If it be so, then, prithee, praise me to the young Ladies.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Do not forget any of my good parts.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I cannot forget them; for I do not remember any you have.

div.stage: Exit Spend-all.
Enter Observer.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Observer, I wonder you will be absent out of this Room, in regard you only come to observe the Court beauties and Court-wits.

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: Faith, I became tired and wearied of the observations in this Room, the Presence; and so I went into the Privy-Chamber to observe the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: And how did he appear?

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: He did appear in Majesty, as far beyond his Royalty, as his Royalty appears above his meanest Subjects.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Then he appear'd as a God.

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: Indeed he appear'd above what is mortal.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: And did you hear him speak?

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: Yes; and he was in so witty a vein, that my Hearing was (as if it were) tyed to his speech, and my Mind so fill'd with delight, that I had not power to stir from the place I stood, but both my body and mind were (as 'twere) fixt to a Deitical Centre.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I perceive, that you, instead of an Observer, are become a Courtier; and now you have learn'd to flatter.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p:
Not so, for by Heav'n I speak the truth of my thoughts and belief; for though I do not believe the Emperor to be a God, yet God and Nature have made, and endued him, to be above all other Men; for name me any other Prince or private Man in this age, that has that sweet Nature, excellent Qualities, experienced
Knowledg, clear Understanding, upright Justice, Heroick Courage, free Generosity, and divine Clemency as he has; and if you match him in all the known World, proclaim me a Fool and a Lyar, which is to be a Flatterer, a Vice I hate.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: I confess, there are two Reasons that perswade me to be of your mind; the first is, That I have observed the same in the Emperor; the second is, That I did never know you to flatter, dissemble, or speak false in my life; for you are so infinitely proud, that you will not descend so low as to flatter, or be so humble in praises, were it to God himself.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: God is too Omnipotent for Praise, and our Emperor too Heroick and truly Royal for Flattery; so that the one is not a subject for praise, nor the other for Flattery.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Lady Quick-wit, Self-conceit, Wanton and Wagtail.

sp.speaker: Self-conceit.
sp.p: I Will tell you a Wonder.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What Wonder?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Why, I found Mrs. Bashful alone with a Man.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Why, that's no wonder to see a Man and a
Woman alone, especially in the Court; for we watch all opportunities, upon every occasion, to be so.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But 'tis a wonder to see Bashful alone with a Man, and abroad too; for she shuns Men, as she would do Serpents, and locks her Chamber-doors against them, and accounts it a crime to be seen undress'd, and a sin not to be forgiven, to be seen in bed.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: VVhy, she was neither in bed, nor undrest, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: No, she was at Madam Civilities house, and 'tis to be hoped she will come to it in time, when she has so much wit, as to hold a Discourse.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: She hold a Discourse! she wants the Capacity, she wants the Capacity.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Nay, you can give the best relation or description of her; for you were her bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Prithee what is she? a meer Mope; doth she never speak or discourse to you?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: You shall judge, whether she doth or not; for she will never ask a question, nor make a doubt, nor give her opinion upon any thing.

div.stage: Enter Bashful.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Come poor Bashful, there is none makes much of thee.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: I should be loth to be made much of, after the Court-fashion.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: After the Court-fashion! how is that? express it, express it.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: Nay, you can express it best.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Faith, I pity thee for having no Servant.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: I had rather be pitied for having no Servant, then censured for having too many.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If you be a good Girl, and do as the rest of your Honourable Sisters, or as all Court-Ladies do, I will send you some of my worn Servants to Court you.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: No, pray keep them as a store, lest you should want your self. Exit Bashful.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Faith, she is fitter for a Nunnery, then a Court.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But I observe the Court has improved her Wit.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Nay, the Court is the only Place to make Fools, Wits.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Or Wits, Fools. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Spend-all, and Conversant.

sp.speaker: Conversant.
sp.p: MOnsieur Spend-all, how do you prosper in your old Lady's affection?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, more prosperously then I desire.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Would not you willingly enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes her Wealth, but not her Person.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p:
You must take the worse with the better; for
I have observed, that Fortune, Fate, Nature, and the Gods, mix Good and Evil, Pleasure and Discontent, Health and Sickness together.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I confess there is not any thing perfect, or pure in Nature; but God be praised in his Creatures, and all things.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Then God be praised for the love of the old Lady to you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I have much strife with my self to give praises for her; but I desire and should give thanks to see some of the young Ladies, that I might converse with them to revive me from death to life, from hate to love.

div.stage: Enter Lady Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Lady, you are the life of the Court.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And the Court is the life of me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Your Eyes give light to all the beholders.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I had rather my wit could give life to all the Hearers.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: But your Beauty doth excell all the Beauties in the Court.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Until you converse with another Lady, and then her Beauty doth as far excell mine, as mine at this present doth excell others.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Indeed, Beauty appears best in Conversation.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And worse with often viewing.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No more then the light of the Sun doth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The more the Sun is gaz'd upon, the blinder the fight is.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: That is the reason the splendor of the Sun's light doth over-power the sight.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, then the splendor puts out the sight of his light, which buries his glory in the darkness of blindness; and if my Beauty doth the like, I am sorry for it; for I would not have such a Beauty as digs its own grave in the Eyes of its admirers; but as a moderate Light, so moderate a Beauty pleases the sight best. Exit Quick-wit.

div.stage: Enter Lady Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Lady, there is not any Man doth more admire you, then I.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If I have Merit, you ought to give Merit its due; and if I am worthy of admiration, I am bound to the Gods and Nature for their favours, and not to you for your Praises.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: But all men do neither honour, nor admire what is worthy of either.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If they do not, the injury is to Nature and the Gods.

div.stage: Exit Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Faith, Spend-all, your Complements will not serve you in Love-matters.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I confess they are not fortunate.

div.stage: Enter Lady Bashful.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Madam, I wonder you should hide any part of your Face with Black-patches, your Face being fair and lovely.

sp.speaker: Bashf.
sp.p:
Black-patches curiously cut and struck upon
he Face, are like wise Sentences in a Speech, they give Grace and Lustre.

div.stage: Enter Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Lady Bashful, I have been seeking you all the Court over, in every Lodging, and I could not find you.

sp.speaker: Bashf.
sp.p: You see, I am not lost, for here I am; but where's the Lady Quickwit?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: She is within, and asks for you.

div.stage: Enter Quickwit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O! it is so cold! so very cold, as it is able to freeze all the Lovers hearts in the Court and City!

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: And not in the Country, Lady?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O no, for those that dwell in the Country, make such great Blazing-fires, as they thaw Cold, and heat Love.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Love doth not require Heat, for it is sufficiently hot of it self.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes, when it is in a Fever, in which Love most commonly dies: But come Ladies, shall we go to Supper?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Conversant, tell Lady Quick-wit, I am in Love with her.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Lady, Monsieur Spend-all sayes, he is in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I hate to hear of Love by a Second, it seems so like a Challenge. Exeunt all the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, Court-Ladies have quick Wits.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p:
They are bred to answer, they are so often
spoke to, but of all the Ladies, I confess, I like the Lady Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, I like them all so well, I know not which to like best; and I wish with all my heart, they all would like me as well as my old Lady doth; Oh, what a happy Man should I be, for I should have variety of Pleasures! Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Wagtail, and Wanton.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: THe Lord of Loyalty sent me a merry Letter to day; and in the Letter, a Copy of Verses, desiring me to give them to Madam Bashful.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Faith, those Verses will make her so conceited with her self, that she will be so proud, as to think her self the only she in the Court; wherefore, let me advise you not to give them her.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But what shall I say to the Lord of Loyalty, if he should ask me, whether I had given them to her.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Put it off with Rallery.

div.stage: Enter the Mother, and Observer.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Mother, where is your Daughter Bashful, she is not here to attend the Princess coming forth?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She is gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Yes, to meet the Lord Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Indeed Mother, you are too blame, to let your Daughters go abroad without you; and if the Princess should know of it, she would be very angry.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Why, she ask'd the Princess leave.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: It is a shame she should be abroad without the Mother; it is enough to disgrace all the Sister-hood; and therefore for Juno's sake, send for her home.

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: Why Ladies, I have known the Princess's Maids many times to go abroad without the Mother, and no disgrace to their Honour.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But not to meet such Company as she is gone to, for all the Kingdom knows, the Lord of Loyalty is none of the chastest men; and he courts her for her Youth and Beauty; 'tis not likely he will marry her; for he loves Variety too well, to tie himself to one.

sp.speaker: Observ.
sp.p: Truly I am of that opinion; but she is so Vertuous, she cannot be corrupted.

div.stage: Enter Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Mother, the Princess is very angry that Madamoisel Bashful is gone abroad without you; she says, that though she gave her leave to go abroad, she thought she had so much discretion as to take the Mother along with her; but you must send for her presently.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Go, go, quickly Mother, quickly.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I will go for her.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Nay, I will go for her.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Nay, pray stay, and let the Mother go her self.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Observer, Conversant.

sp.speaker: Conversant.
sp.p: MOnsieur Observer, I heard a Lady say, you were a Fool.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Ladies may say what they please.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But it seems, you have not pleased her, that she calls you Fool.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: It seems I have not courted her.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Are Ladies never pleas'd but when they are Courted?

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: No Faith; for then they think they are not thought Handsom.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Indeed Women delight in their Beauties.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Not unless men admire their Beauties; for they are delighted with their Beauties, for the delight of Courtship; Beauty gets them Suiters; for were they ill-favoured, they would never be wooed,

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But when they are wooed, they are not presently wonne.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Yes Faith, they are wonne before they be wooed; and being wooed, they presently yield.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: The truth is, Women have kind natures.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Not so kind as willing.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Women are Loving-creatures.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Yes, they are Self-lovers.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Not when they give themselves to men.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: They give themselves to men, because men should give themselves to them.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: So they love men out of self-interest.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: No doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: You are an unjust Man.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: In dispraising all the Sex out of a displeasure to one Woman, for calling you Fool.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I should not only be call'd a fool, but should prove my self one, if I should regard what Women say.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Monsieur Wedlock, how doth your Lady?

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: She is groaning and complaining.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: What is she in labour?

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: No, but she is breeding.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Monsieur Spend-all, I hear you are entring into the Matrimonial Order.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, I am going into the Order of Cuckolds, Wittals, or Fools.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Why, Marriage is an honourable. Order.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: The Order is as it proves; but if you think it so honourable, why will not you be one of this Matrimonial Order?

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Because I am not ambitious of such Honours; but is the Lady you are to Marry very beautiful, Monsieur Spend-all?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, but she is Rich.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Is she of honourable birth?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, but she is Rich.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Is she well bred?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, but she is Rich.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Is she wise?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, but she is Rich.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Do you Marry only for Riches?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes; for Necessity forces me to Marry an ill-favoured, foolish, old doting Woman.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Much good may she do you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Nay faith, she will not do me any good, unless she would die soon; but her Wealth will do me much good, and I shall prove an excellent Husband to her Riches.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: You are so deboist and wild, that you cannot be a good Husband to any thing.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: But I shall; for when I am so rich, as to have wherewithal to spend, I shall then be so thrifty as to spare; for it is to be observed, That Rich Men for the most part are miserable and covetous, when those that have but little, spend all they have, or can get.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Pray bring me to visit this old foolish Lady you are to Marry.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You must pardon me; if she were wise and
young, I would let you see her; but being old and foolish, I dare not, lest you should entice her from me; for Old Women are more unconstant then Young; and being foolish, she will be so various, that her mind may change like the wind.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: You may trust me, were she young, beautiful, chast, honourable, well-bred, witty and rich; for I will never Marry.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, if you could get a Wife, with all these Excellencies.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p:
I would not Marry, could I get a Wife with all those fore-mentioned Excellencies, as you call them; for were she young, she would want discretion, for want of Experience; were she beautiful, she would make me jealous, for Beauty is Courted; were she honoured with title, she would strive to rule, and would not be ruled; were she that which is named good breeding, which is to Fiddle, Dance, Sing, and speak divers Languages, and to know the Female and Masculine Genders in Languages, she would Gossip abroad, and seek out Company, and be at all Publick Meetings, to shew her breeding; if she have Wit, she will be always talking, and always opposing, to prove her Wit; if she be chast, she will be proud; if she be fruitful, she will be sickly and froward; if she be rich, she will spend much, because she brought much, and in the end will make me poorer then I am; and on the other side, were she old, I should not imbrace her; were she ill-favoured, I should have an
aversion against her; were she of mean birth, and ill breeding, I should be asham'd of her; were she a fool, I should not regard her; were she poor, I should despise her; were she false, I should part from her.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Well, Monsieur Observer, since you will neither Marry old, nor young, handsome, nor ill-favoured, chast nor wanton, mean nor honourable, foolish nor wise, poor nor rich, but are resolved to live a Batchellor, I will bring you to be acquainted with my old Mistress, that must be my old Wife, and Mr. Wedlock will bring you acquainted with his young Wife.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: By my faith, but I will not.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No, why?

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Because he doth not declare he will not make Courtships to Wives, though he declares he will not have a Wife; and unless he declare and profess, he will not make love to other Men's Wives, I will not bring him acquainted with my Wife.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why, do you mistrust your Wife?

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: No, but I mistrust him; and were I sure my Wife would not yield, yet I do not love she should be tempted: But howsoever, to keep a Wife safe, is, to keep her close from Courtships, and from Masculine Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But Women will get liberty one way or other, if they have a wanton mind, and desire change.

sp.speaker: Wedl.
sp.p: Yet it is the part of a wise Husband to do his endeavour to keep her honest.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: VVell, I will neither visit Monsieur Spend-all's old Mistress, nor your young VVife; but I'le go with you to a merry Meeting, where I suppose, there will be those Women that will better please me, then the old Woman, and easier be enjoyed then your young Wife; wherefore, if you will go, Gentlemen, I will present you a Supper.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: If you will present us with Mistresses, we will go with you.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: They will present themselves.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Mode to the rest.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Monsieur Mode, it is reported, that you have the art to Court two or three Mistresses at one time; which if you have, I shall desire to be your Scholar, for I could never be in the favour of two Mistresses at one time; for the Courting of one lost me the other, and those I lose, become my Enemies.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: He is a poor Man that hath but one Mistress; and he is a fool in Courtship, that cannot Court half a dozen Mistresses at one time.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: So, by this you call me a poor fool.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: If you were not a fool, you would not desire to be my Scholar; and if you were not poor, you would not desire more then you have.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Then make me wiser and richer.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Would you be wiser for profit, or wiser for pleasure.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For pleasure!

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Would you be richer for Wealth, or richer for Honour, or richer in a number of Mistresses?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Richer in a number of Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Then be bold, rude, and vain, talk much without sense, swear much without cause, brag much without reason, accoutre your self fantastically, behave your self carelesly, and imploy time idly; and be sure you raile of all Women generally, but praise every particular one, but so as in a general way, as some for one thing, and some for another, as you shall think best, by which you will keep them all in hopes; for if you should praise only one, that one will be too proud, and then disdain you, and the rest through dispair will hate you; also in your actions you must behave your self generally, as in a careless way, dividing your Courtships amongst them all, as to kiss one Woman's hand, another's neck, a third Woman's lips, embrace a fourth, rally with a fifth, and bed with the sixth; and after this manner you may Court twenty Mistresses at least at one time, and serve your self in private with them all one after another; for though you may Court many Mistresses at one time in publick, yet in private you must have but one at a time, and she will believe, or at least make her self believe, she is the only she that is beloved.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I will follow your Instruction; and if I thrive, I will give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
But if you be not ingenious, and well
practised, my Instructions will do you but little good; for you may be like Players, that have excellent parts, and spoile them in the Acting; or like a Minister that chuses a good Text, and wants Oratory to preach of it; or you may be like a bungling Taylor that spoiles a fine Suit of Clothes with ill making: But if you will thrive, you must be of many Professions; and if you will be a Master of Courtship, you must be learned in the Liberal Arts and Sciences; you must be an Astrologer to foresee your Times, and their Times; an Astronomer to find out their Humours; a Cosmographer to measure their Capacities; a Philosopher, to pierce into their Natures and Dispositions; a Logician, to make their Vanities and Vices appear Vertues; an Arithmetician, to number their Praises, and cipher their Follies; and a Mathematician to draw them to your desires and delights.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I shall do my best endeavour; but I fear that most Women are not worth so much pains, study and practice.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: As for that, your idle Times must judg of it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Well, I will go to my Lodgings, and consider it.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Nay, faith, Consideration will spoile all my Instructions. Exit Spend-all, the rest stays.

div.stage: Enter Lady Wagtail, Wanton, Self-conceit, and Bashful, as also the Mother.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are come, I would not be in your condition for any thing.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I'faith, you will be talk'd withal.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: If I were in so sad a condition, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: Why Ladies, I have neither deserved Imprisonment, nor Death, which is the worst that can come unto me; but if I be condemned, I shall suffer both with patience and with courage.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: O Lord! she speaks freely.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: She has found a Tongue since she went.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: 'Tis well, if she has lost nothing, since she went.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: On my word you have done very ill, which you deserve to be chid for.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I believe the Princess will turn you away.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.p: I am very sorry I have offended the Princess; but yet I have done nothing but what I had her leave for.

div.stage: Enter Lady Quickwit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Madamoisel Bashful, you must come to the Princess. Exeunt Bashful and Quickwit.

sp.speaker: Obs. to the Moth.
sp.p: Alas poor Mother we were all afraid you were kill'd.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Kill'd, who should kill me?

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Why, a rough, rude Coachman.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Which way should he kill me?

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: With tumbling you over.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: How tumbling me over?

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: VVith your head downwards, and your heels upwards.

div.stage: Enter Madamoisel Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: VVhat News? what News? what doth Madamoisel Bashful confess?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: VVhat doth she confess?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: VVhy, she confesses, she was at Madamoisel Civilitie's house, where she met the Lord Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: And what said the Princess then?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: VVhy the Princess chid her for offering to meet any Man without her leave; But she has pardon'd her for this time, and you must go all to the back-stairs, and stay there to wait on the Princess into the Gallery.

div.stage: Exeunt VVomen.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I would the Ladies had as much love for me, as they are angry with their fellow-Lady.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: If they had, they would overpower you with their kindness.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I would desire nothing more but to be so overpower'd.

div.stage: Enter Self-conceit in hast running over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Run, run.

div.stage: Enter Quick-wit, passing in hast over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Follow, follow.

div.stage: Enter VVanton.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Call, call, call.

div.stage: Enter Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Bring, bring, bring.

div.stage: The Men stand in a Maze.
Enter Fool passing over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Oh the Lord! I am undone, undone.

div.stage: The Men stop him.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: What is the matter, Fool?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I cannot stay to tell you.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: But you must.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: If I must, I must.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Tell me what makes this Hubbub, which seems to distract the Ladies? is the Emperor not well, or the Princess sick?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: The Emperor is well, but will have cause to be sick; and the Princess is sick, and will have cause to be well.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Because the Princess has spi'd her Idea, and will marry him, and so will be cured of her Melancholy, and be well; but he is a poor Mariner or Sea-man, and that will make the Emperor sick.

div.stage: Enter the Ladies, and the Mariner passing over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Now you have seen the cause of the uproar, you will let me pass with my fellow-fools.

div.stage: Exit Fool.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Sure the Princess will not Marry this poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: If she doth, the Court will be Metamorphorsed from a house to a Ship, and the Courtiers to Mariners.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Then we shall sail to some new Plantation.

div.stage: Enter Lady Quick-wit, Self-conceit, Wanton.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: As I live, he is a handsom Man.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But he is a poor mean fellow.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But a poor mean fellow may be a handsom Man.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Not in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Truly I am of the opinion, that Wealth doth not make Worth. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter the Sailer leading the Princess, who appears well pleased, with the Attendance of Ladies and Gentlemen, and the Fool.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: SIR, although the Emperor is at Council, and will not be seen at the present, yet I will entertain you until such time as his Majesty admits you to his Presence.

div.stage: The Sailer Kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: They say, Lovers promise much; if so, you are a Lover, for you promise more then you dare perform.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You say, you will entertain the Sailer's Company until the Emperor admits him to his Presence, and if he doth not admit him until to morrow, you must entertain his Company all night.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: You are a Knave, Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: But I am not a Lady's Fool.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen and Ladies, call for Musick, for we will dance until the Emperor rises from Council. One calls for Musick.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Sir, can you dance our Country Dances.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: I will do my endeavour, Lady; and if I have not skill for the present, I will learn for the future, if you command me.

div.stage: The Musick plays, they all dance, and the Sailer with the Princess; the Sailer dances civilly, gracefully, and with art and skill.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Sir, you want not Art, for you Dance skilfully.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Lady, I want not Love, and Love works Miracles.

div.stage: They Dance again: At the end of this Dance Enters a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: May it please your Highness, the Emperor desires your Presence.

div.stage: The Princess whispers to the Sailer, he hows and kisses her Hand. Exeunt All.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter all the Maids of Honour, except Madamoisel Bashful, and Self-conceit; as also Monsieur Conversant, Observer and Spend-all.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: O That we might dance Country Dances to day.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Why, Monsieur Spend-all makes a Ball to night, are not you one of the invited?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: O yes, but I had forgot the Ball.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, we are all invited.

div.stage: Enter Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: What News?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Madamoisel Bashful and the Lord Loyalty are Married.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: For certain truth do you speak it?

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Of a certain truth 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, the Lord Loyalty was accounted a Wise Man.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Why, Madam, he is never the less Wise for Marrying a virtuous sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What, not in these troublesome and mutinous Times.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p:
In all times there was and is Marrying, and giving in Marriage; and those that are Honest are Wise, and it is Honest to Marry, and Wise; for if Men and
Women should live in common, it were the way to extinguish Propriety; and where there is no Propriety, there is no Justice; and without Justice a Commonwealth would be dissolved.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Well, in my opinion he has done very indiscreetly.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Nay, faith, methinks, he hath done very foolishly.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: In my opinion, she has done as foolishly as he, for he is a ruined man.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Give me leave to tell you, Ladies, there is never a one of you all who would have refused him, as ruined as he is; but you would have been ambitious and proud to Marry him.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: You are deceived; for I would not Marry him or any other, were he as rich as Pluto.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Nor I would not Marry, might I have a King.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nor I to have been an Emperess.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Nor I if I might have been Mistress of the whole World.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Then I perceive, Ladies, you are all resolved to live single lives.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: There is none happy, but those that are Mistresses of themselves.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I should never endure to be subject to a Husband.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I hate Marriage as I hate death.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I love Freedom, as I love Life.

div.stage: Enter Mother.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Mother, do you hear of your Daughter's Marriage?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Yes, and the Princess is very angry at it.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: She hath reason.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If I were the Princess, I would make them repent their Marriage.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Yes faith, I would put water into their Wine.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Lord, Ladies, why should the Princess be angry either with him, or with her, since Marriage is honest, and free for every one to chuse where they please; neither do I see either in Reason or Justice, why either of them should be condemned, since none will suffer, if they be unhappy, but themselves; and I suppose that none here is so ill-natured as to repine at their Felicity.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Come, pray let us go see how she looks since she is Married.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Proud, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I dare swear she will carry state now.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: She was proud enough before she was Married, she cannot be much prouder then she was.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You say right, for what every body thought was bashfulness and modesty in her, was meerly pride.

div.stage: Exeunt Ladies, the Men stay.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: The Maids of Honour live so happily in the Court, and are so pleased with their several Courtships, as they hate to think of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
That's because they cannot get Husbands; for
Men are afraid to Marry Maids of Honour, because they are so used to Courtships, that they will give leave to be Courted when they are Married; besides, Men think them vain and expensive.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: They speak so bitterly against Marriage, and all that are Married, as I do verily believe they would not Marry upon any condition.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I will try them whether they will or no, for my own satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Which way will you try them? for if you should examine them never so soberly, and gravely, they will never discover their minds so, that you shall know whether they would Marry or not.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, I will offer every one of them a Husband, and try if they will accept of them.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: O, they will laugh at you, and scorn you for your offer.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Well, I will try them, let them scorn and laugh as they please.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Conversant.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Monsieur Mode, I hear you intend to travel into Foreign Nations.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: You hear right, Sir; for I want only travel to make me a compleat Mode-Gallant; whereby, I shall be more graceful in the eyes of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: But if your Travels be long, you will be less graceful in the eyes of the Ladies, for you will be too old to please their sight; but you want not Mistresses, nor the art of Courtship.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, to tell you the truth, I would travel to see Foreign Beauties; for I am satisfied with the Ladies here in my Native Country.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: I hope you have not taken a surfeit of them.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Truly I should be glad to have some of his Leavings.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: It is a sign you are sharp set.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: The old Lady has whet his appetite.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I confess old Women make wanton young Men.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Let Monsieur Mode Court your old Lady to cure his surfeit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: With all my heart, so he will bequeath me his young Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I did instruct you how to Court and gain Ladies to your Imbracements; but either you are a dull Scholar, or an unfortunate Courtier.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I confess my ill fortune in Courtships; but you may be as unfortunate in Foreign Nations; for though you are Ala Mode here in your Native Country, 'tis likely you will be quite out of fashion and language in other Nations.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: For Language, I dare say he will be to learn.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Then how will he Woo a Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: O, VVomen are best pleased with those they understand least.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: He knows the humours of VVomen best, he is so conversant with them; but prithee Mode do not travel until I have learn'd thy Art of Courtship.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Into what Countries will you travel, Monsieur Mode?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Into France and Italy; the one to refine my Habit, the other to refresh my sight with new Beauties.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: Then they must not be ca-st Courtisans; but let me perswade you to stay at home, and Marry.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: No, I will not Marry, to lose my freedom.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Faith, and I intend to Marry to take more liberty.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Marriage is a bondage.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Not if you Marry a rich old Woman.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: No, for her Riches will supply his wants, and maintain his Mistresses; and her age will be an excuse for his Adulteries.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith, Gentlemen, you speak reason; wherefore, I'le go a Wooing to Monsieur Spend-all's old rich Lady.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You will not speed there, for I am aforehand with you; for though you can Court young Women better then I, yet for old Women I go beyond you. But if you chance to Marry a young Woman, I shall willingly change a nights lodging with you.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Are you Married to the old Lady?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I must Marry her, which is my grief.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Pray bid us to your Wedding.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
That I will, and feast you after I am Married,
for I shall not be jealous of my Wife, nor afraid you will make me a Cuckold; and I have a desire to invite the young Female Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: That will make your old Lady jealous; and if she be jealous, when you are just upon the point of Marriage, she may chance to refuse you; wherefore, do not invite them until the next day, when she is past her choice.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You say true, and the next day we will Revel.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Self-conceit and Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Quick-wit.
sp.p: THe Emperor is highly discontent.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If he be displeased, he can only be angry with himself; for when the Princess was so Melancholy, that she was ready to die, he did assure her, she should make her own choice of a Husband, and that he would not deny her any one Man in all his Empire.

sp.speaker: Quick-wit.
sp.p: But this Man is not of his Empire, for he is a stranger.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Faith, it would be but an even Match, whether she did chuse a poor mean Native, or a poor mean Stranger. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Princess and the Sailer; the Fool attends them; the Princess Weeps.

sp.speaker: Sailer.
sp.p: VVHy doth your Highness weep? for if the Emperor your Father be unjust, the Gods will not be so; for they will Crown our honest Loves with Happiness and Blessings.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But Lovers are never happy.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Believe not so; for true Lovers are always blessed with good success, and those that have ill fortune have not been true Lovers.

div.stage: Enter such as are proper to deliver the Emperor's pleasure; they speak to the Sailer.

sp.speaker: Sailer,
sp.p: The Emperor's pleasure is, That you immediately go out of his Dominions; for if you be found in any part within such time as may be travel'd to the Sea-side the shortest way, he will cut off your Head.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Tell the Emperor, I fear not death.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Will not you be gone.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: No, I will stay as long as I can.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: But you shall go, since it is the Emperor's pleasure, That we see you out of his Empire.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Be gone, and trouble me no more, or I'le beat you out of the Princess's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You beat us, you poor Water-Snake!

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Cupid, thou god of Love, and Mars thou god of War, assist me.

div.stage: He falls upon them, and beats them out of the Room; the Princess seems to be in a fright.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: A Company of Cowardly Rascals, that have no more Courage then a Flea, that skips at every little motion.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: O my dear Love! what will you do?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Die in your Arms, sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But you cannot resist the Emperor's Power.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: But I can die in despite of the Emperor's Power.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But your death will be my death.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Say not so; for those words will beget such a belief, as to make me a Coward, which is more terrible to me then death; for in death lives Rest, but in a Coward lives Infamy.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But pray consider, if you will yield to depart out of the Empire, I may find means to depart with you, or to follow you.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Death is more Honourable then to fly from any misfortune; and though I love you better then my Soul, yet I had rather die then fly.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But by your willing death, you will become a cruel murderer, not only to your self, but me.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: Die you must, my dear Mistress, so must I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Heaven grant that in one Grave we both may lie.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Shed no more tears, nor talk of Graves; for if you will absolutely be ruled by me, if I be not too hard for the Emperor, and all his Councels, hang me when you are Emperess, which you must be; for the Power and Title comes from your Mother, not from your Father.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Tell me how?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Nay faith, a Fool must have some time for contrivance, as well as wise States-Men. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Mode, and Madamoisel Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: LAdy, there is one of my Acquaintance, that desires a Wife; but he may desire long enough, for I think none will have him for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Why! he is the most deformed Man that ever was seen.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well, if I were to chuse a Husband, I would never chuse a handsom Ma; for their Beauty makes them so self-conceited, that they regard not their Wives; besides, they seem, and are for the most part, effeminate, which I hate; wherefore, for my part, I would chuse an ill-favoured Man, and the more ill-favoured he were, the better I should like him, as looking more Masculine.

sp.speaker: Mode,
sp.p: O! but that's not all, Madam; for his Nature and Disposition is according to his Person; the one as evil, as the other ill-favour'd.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O Sir, such a man I could love with all my heart; for a surly Nature seems Heroick; when as such men as have sweet Dispositions, and gentle Natures, which is to be soft and facil, are Fools; and I would not marry a Fool for any thing in the world.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: But Madam, let me tell you, He is none of the wisest.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, mistake me not; for I would not have him a very wise man, lest he should condemn me as a Fool; but an indifferent understanding I like best.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Why, then this man would be a fit Husband for you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The fittest in the World; Good Monsieur Mode speak for me, and I shall think my self obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I shall motion you, Lady.

div.stage: Exit Quick-wit.
Enter Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Madam, there is a Gentleman, an Acquaintance of mine, which intreated me to ask you, whether you would please to accept of him for a Husband, if he should offer himself to you; he is loth to have a personal denial, wherefore he would not make his addresses himself, unless he had an assurance you would entertain him.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Pray Sir, what manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Faith Lady, I cannot much commend either his Person, or Parts, Humour, or Disposition; but he has a Competent Fortune, not so much, as to maintain a Wife gallantly, but decently.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Why, that's as much as I desire; more would be but an unnecessary superfluity; as for Person, I regard not the outward Shape; and for his Humour and Disposition, I shall alter those when we are married; and truly Sir, I think my self much obliged to you, for mentioning the man unto me.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Your Servant Lady.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Yours, Monsieur Mode.

div.stage: Exit Self-conceit.
Enter Wanton.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Lady, I am tyred with the importunity of a Gentleman, that will not let me rest in quiet, until I have inform'd you of his Affections to you, and for you.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Nay, he must be unknown, until he know whether you will accept of him; but in truth, my Conscience bids me perswade you against him; indeed I would not have mention'd him, but that he will not let me rest, till I have told you his desires.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: What manner of Man is he? and what Estate has he? and of what Qualitiy is he?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
He is a Gentleman, and as for his Person, to
speak truth, he is a very Handsom man, as any is, but he is not worth a Denier, a very Shark for his living.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I marry Sir, give me a Man that lives by his wits; for every Fool can tell how to live, if he be rich; besides, I had rather enjoy Beauty, then Wealth, with a Husband.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: O, but that's not all, Madam; for he is a very deboist Man; he Drinks, and Whores, and Games.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Marriage will reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: But he has got such a Habit of Debauchery, that 'tis to be fear'd, he will never be reclaimed.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: The truth of it is, I would chuse a deboist Man for a Husband sooner then a Temperate Man; for his several Debaucheries will be my several Pastimes; besides, I shall have his Company but sometimes, which will make him appear to me fresh and new; whereas, a Stoical and Temperate Husband, will tire me out with his continual Company, being always at home, or else he would restrain me with his Moral Discipline.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: But there is another reason, that may disswade you from him.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Why, 'tis said, he has the French Pox, and I believe you will not venture on that Disease.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p:
I am of so healthful a Constitution, I fear no Disease; besides, he is not a Courtly nor well-bred Man, that has not a spice of that Disease; and the truth is, I should account that Man uncivil, and not a Gentleman,
but a meer dull Clown that were free thereof, and sound there-from; for the compleatest Gentlemen are ever under the Arrest of that Disease; wherefore, Sir, to release you of his importunity, tell him from me, I shall not refuse him, but willingly accept of him.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I shall Madam. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Wagtail, Self-conceit, and Wanton.

sp.speaker: Wagtail.
sp.p: LOrd! Self-conceit, I have not seen you never since the night before the last night!

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: You might have seen me if you had been so kind as to come to my Lodging, for I lay a bed all yesterday, by reason I had a great many to come to Visit me, and they were Men of Quality.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Faith, I could not come, by reason Monsieur Malicious was going over, to whom you know, I have intrusted all my affairs, so as I was dispatching some business with him.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But I will never forgive my friend Wanton, that she would not come with the Lords and Gentlemen to visit me.

sp.speaker: Wan.
sp.p:
Faith, I could not come; for my Chamber-fellow and I, both of us, did bath yesterday, and there came in two or three Gentlemen whilest we were in the Bath,
and stay'd talking so long with us that I have catch'd Cold.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Lord! did Madamoisel Supple Bath again yesterday! why she bathed but the day before; for a Gentleman told me, that Madam Liberty was in the Bath, and when she went out, then she went into Madamoisel Supple's Bed to warm and dry her self, and Mr. Amorous entertain'd her whilst she lay there, and Madamoisel Supple, as soon as Madamoisel Liberty went out of the Bath, went into it; and by that time that Madamoisel Liberty rose out of the bed, Madamoisel Supple was ready to enter into it, and then Mr. Break-jest did entertain her with pleasant Discourses.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Certainly, Bathing is very wholsome.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: But let me tell you, Wanton, that often Bathing weakens very much.

div.stage: Exeunt Wanton and Self-conceit.
Wagtail Sola, Enter to her Mode.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: Monsieur Mode, I have watch'd for an opportunity to speak to you alone these two or three days.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: To me, sweet Lady! what is it you would say?

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: 'Tis this; I hear you are acquainted with a Man, who is very rich and unmarried, and 'tis reported he will marry a Wife of your chusing; and Sir, I shall not be ungrateful, if you will chuse me for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p:
'Tis true, I am acquainted with such a Man,
who is very rich, but he is a very Fool; the truth is, the next degree to a Changeling.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I like that the better, for so I may govern him and his Estate.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: Nay, Lady, let me inform you, that though he be a Fool, yet he is a covetous and self-conceited Fool, neither to be ruled nor wrought upon, nor yet to be perswaded to any thing, but what he himself likes best.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: However Sir, I shall gain a respect and esteem in the World by the Reputation of his Wealth; wherefore, good Monsieur Mode, let me intreat you to prefer me to his good liking.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I shall do my endeavour, Lady.

div.stage: Exit Wagtail.
Enter Observer to Mode.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: The Sailer is gone to Prison, and the Princess confin'd to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: I am sorry for the Princess's restraint.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Sailer as in a Prison, Manicled with Chains.
div.l: YOu Heav'nly Powers, do you her life secure,
Though for her sake I torment must endure.
Show'r blessings on her Life, and let her Name
Be glorious to Posterity and Fame:
But I profane, thou art a Deitie;
Wherefore my Prayers, I'le direct to thee:
Thou Goddess know'st, what torments I do feel,
My life is wrack'd upon ill-fortune's wheel.
O! do not break my heart, thou Heav'nly Power,
For 'tis thy own Idea's onely Tower;
For when I dye, where will thy Mansion be?
In every Heart and Head that thinks of thee:
Then let me die in peace, for thou wilt reign
In every Soul, as well as every Brain. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Jaylor and Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: MAster. Jaylor?

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: What say you, Mr. Fool?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Will you take a Fool's Counsel?

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: No by my Faith.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Then by my Faith, I'le prove you a Fool; for my Counsel is, To let the Sailer escape.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: So I shall be hang'd my self.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: That is uncertain; but if the Sailer suffers, you are sure to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Why you know the Princess must be Emperess,
because that Dignity comes by her Mother; and the Emperor is but Emperor during life, and so upon Courtesie; and when the Princess is Emperess, she will be sure to hang you, and not only hang you, but ruine all your Posterity.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: Go, go, you talk like a Fool as you are! I will be an honest Jaylor, and not betray my Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Not betray your Prisoners, say you! consider well, lest you betray your self.

div.stage: Exit Fool, Jayler Solus.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: This Fool has a notable Wit. Exit.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Wanton, Wagtail, Self-conceit, and Quick-wit.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: VVHen did you see Monsieur Mode?

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I have not seen him these two days.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I fear he is sick.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I hope in God, not.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n grant he be in health.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Amen; for he is one of the civillest persons I know.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Indeed he is an obliging person.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a gallant Man.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: The truth is, he has not his equal.

div.stage: Enter Conversant.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Ladies, what happy Man is he that you are praising.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: VVhy, Monsieur Mode?

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: He is a Man that may be a Sample to all Men▪

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: There is none can parallel him.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: He is worth more then praise can give him.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: He cannot chuse but prosper in his Travels, when he is so highly praised by a Company of Beautiful Ladies.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: In his Travels! why whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Into Italy; and the Company he is gone with, went on such a sudden, as he had no time to come and kiss your hands, and take his leave; but he has sent me to make his excuse, and beg his pardon, although he could not help it, unless he should have lost those Conveniences he has by going in the Company of such as can speak the Language, which he cannot.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Pray speak no more of him, for it is no matter whither he is gone, since he has no more Civility.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Never was there such an act done by a Gentleman, as to go not only out of the Town, but the Kingdom, and never take his leave of us.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Faith, he has shewn himself what he is, a Clown.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: A meer Booby.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: A Boor.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Indeed by his behaviour to us he seems not to be a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: One might have easily judged what he was, if any would have taken the pains to consider him.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: I despise such a man.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: I hate such a man.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I abhor him.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: Ladies, I perceive our Sex is very unhappy, for you will love and hate us in a minute, and praise and dispraise us in one breath.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: We have reason.

div.stage: Enter Spend-all, Conversant, Observer, and the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ladies I have ask'd the Princess leave, that you, Her Maids, should honour me with your Presence at my Marriage Feast.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Are you Married?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What fair Lady, have you Married?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Madam, my condition perswaded me to chuse a fair Fortune, rather then a fair Face; but what she wants in Beauty, she has in age, I should have said in Wealth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: It is a sign her Age is in your mind, more then her Wealth, that your tongue was so ready to speak it.

sp.speaker: Wagt.
sp.p: But if your Lady be old, we that are young, shall hardly be welcom.

div.stage: Enter Mode.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Lord, Monsieur Mode, I thought you had been gone to Travel.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: No, that design is alter'd; for I intend now to stay, and marry a rich old Lady too.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: If all the young Gallants marry old Women, What shall we young Women do for Husbands?

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: It were great pity, and not to be suffred, that young Women should marry whil'st their Beauty doth last; but they should live unmarried, to be Mistresses to command Men, and not made slaves to obey, as Wives are.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The best for young Women, is to marry ancient Men, for so we shall be Vertuous Mistresses to wise men in a married condition and life.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: But Lady, all the younger sort of Men, are not so necessitated through their lavish expences, to marry for Riches; for I am not so vain, nor poor, but I may marry for Beauty, and not any Beauty pleaseth me so well as yours.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I had rather be married for my Wit, then for my Beauty.

sp.speaker: Conv.
sp.p: That man is happy, Lady, that can have a Wife with both.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: This is just according to the Old Saying, That one Wedding makes two.

sp.speaker: Obs.
sp.p: And if you please Madam, these two Weddings shall be the cause of a third.

sp.speaker: Self.
sp.p: Let us see, how the married Couples agree first.

sp.speaker: Mode.
sp.p: We will have no particular Wooing, but all shall be in common; otherwise, our meeting will be dull, and our mirth out of tune.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: You say right, Monsieur Mode, for the fiddle-string of Mirth will be broken; but let us go and rejoyce with Mr. Spend-all, and dance and feast, as a Thanksgiving to Fortune for her favours to him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: The greatest favour that Fortune can give me, is, to be honoured with your Company; and if you please to lead the way, the rest will follow.

sp.speaker: Spend-all sighs.
sp.p: Ha! these Marriages spoile all Amorous Courtships.

div.stage: Exeunt Omnes, each leading his Mistress.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter Fool, and the Sailer as in a Prison.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: MAster Sailer, the Princess has sent to know of you, whether you be dead?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: In her absence I am dead to all Happiness, for I have no joys of life.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Then I shall tell her you are dead.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: You may tell her I am worse then dead; for I am miserable, wanting her Company, and misery is worse then death.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Pray God I remember all this; viz. Absence, Happiness, Joys, Life, Dead, Miserable, Misery, and Death. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Princess alone, Musing; Enter Fool to her.

sp.speaker: FOol.
sp.p: O Lady! Lady! the Sailer's dead.

div.stage: She falls into a passion as distracted, then speaks.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Make me a Ship to fail up high to Heav'n,
Where I may swim through all the Planets Seven;
Not to find Gold or Silver, such base dross,
But my dear Love and Lover; which rich loss
Is worth more then the World: Or, make a Boat,
That I may thorough the dark Stygian float
To the Elysium, there to meet my Dear,
Where I shall neither State nor Father fear:
Or else, you Gods, cast me so low and deep,
Without a Dream I may for ever sleep.

div.stage: The Fool Laughs.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Dreams, Ships and Water has been your ruine.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: You Villain, do you laugh at my misery?

div.stage: She gives him a Box of the Ear.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: O, do not beat me, your Sailer's alive yet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Did not you tell me he was dead?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, but I did not tell you his Body is dead, but his Joys are dead.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Is he alive then?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: He is alive, but talks as madly, I dare not say, as foolishly as you do. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: A Scaffold and Block for one to be beheaded. Enter the Guard, Jaylor and Prisoner; as also a grave Man, as his Father; the People staring upon them. The Prisoner being upon the Scaffold, bows down gracefully to the Assembly, and then speaks thus.

sp.speaker: Sailer.
sp.p: VVOrthy Spectators, although I am a Stranger by Birth, yet I am as a Native, being a loving Subject, and humble servant of your Soveraign the Princess; but Fortune which takes more delight in Variety, then Justice, has not only toss'd me from Climate to Climate, and Nation to Nation, but from Happiness to Misery, from Misery to Happiness, and from Happiness to Misery again; and yet my life will end happily; for I shall be a Sacrifice on the Altar of Love, which is such an Honour, that not any worthy person would refuse or repine at; for all true Lovers will bear up my Hearse with Sighs, cover it with Tears, and intomb me in their Memory.

stage.hi: Ʋpon this Speech the People begin to murmur; then the grave Man steps up and speaks.

sp.p: Worthy Spectators, This Person which is here ready to die for Love, (yet not for the Love you imagine) is no wayes capable of Marrying your Princess; for this Person is not only a Woman, but a Princess her self; being Daughter to the Emperor of Persia, who for Love hath wilfully banished her self from her Father's Court and Empire: My Wife was her Governness, God rest her Soul; she being dead▪ and I her Guardian, did love this Princess as my own Child; and knowing her design was not to be alter'd, have attended her, both in her Disguise and Travels; but your Princess imagining her a Man, being in Mans Clothes, has unfortunately fallen in Love with her, which has been the cause both of our trouble and discovery: But I hope this Nation is more just then to murder an innocent Princess, that has not committed any fault either to the People or their Soveraign.
Long live the Princess, remove her, and conveigh her to the Emperor.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Conversant and Observer, with Lady Quick-wit, and Self-conceit.

sp.speaker: Conversant.
