sp.p: Madamoisel Tell-tale, prithee for Jupiter's sake run to the Duchess, and tell her I heard her Lord enquire for her; and 'twas told him she was seen going to Madam la Gravities Lodging; for if her Husband finds her and the Duke of Noeland together, he will frown; wherefore, prithee run: Tell-tale runs out.
Although on my Conscience he hath no reason to suspect them.

sp.speaker: Spight.
sp.p: No, but our Husbands are jealous Men, and very mistrustful. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE XXVI.
div.stage: Enter Tom Diogenes, and another Man.

sp.speaker: MAn.
sp.p: Tom, I hear thy Master is Married again to a very rich Lady.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, Faith; Fortune hath been a better Friend to my Master, then the Court of Wards.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Now thy Master hath such great fortune, thou may'st grow rich.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, Faith, for when my Master Married his first Wife, he was so poor he had nothing to give me, and now he hath Married a rich Wife, I fear he will grow so covetous, as he will not part with any thing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But rich Men use to be free and liberal.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
O no, for Men are bountiful, when they have
nothing to give, but sparing when they have something to keep. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE XXVII.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Underward, and Tom Diogenes his Man.

sp.speaker: Tom Diogenes.
sp.p: IF I may be so bold, Sir, I wonder your Worship will leave the Court?

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Nay, Tom, the Court leaves me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I dare answer for the Court, it will never leave your Worship as long as you have a peny; and when you have nothing, then 'tis time to leave you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Wherefore, Tom, I will leave it whilst I have pence.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where will you find so kind Friends in the Country? Courtiers will so smile on you to your face!

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: And laugh at me behind my back.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: In your presence, what sugar'd words they will give you?

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: And in my absence, what wormwood and gall?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: How they will imbrace you?

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: And when they are from me, kick at my name.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, they will kiss you.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: A Judas-kiss, to betray me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And when they see you, clap their hands for joy, a plaudite of welcome.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: When out of sight, out of Mind; or else like Snakes to hiss me from their Stage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay, they will whisper in your ear Court-Secrets.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Though there be none.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And they will almost softly speak Treason in your ear.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Yes, and afterwards swear, that it was I spoke it unto them.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Well Sir, for my part I never saw kinder people in my life.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: VVhen they use you kindest, then look to your self, for then they have deceiv'd, or mean to deceive you; all is Interest and particular End, that is all the kindness and friendship they have.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Interest is well, if they pay that, for they are never able to pay the Principal; but I assure your Worship if they give me good words to my face, I care not what they do when they are gone; back-biters are but back-snarlers: But where will your VVorship have such fine Clothes, a la mode Feathers, Mistresses, gilt Coaches, Pages, Lacquies, Powders, Perfumes, Maskes, Playes, Balls, and a thousand such like Recreations? and in VVinter time sitting with a particular Lady upon a fine French bed by dim Candle light, having such sweet Conversation after sighing,
groaning, professing and protesting with Lovers tears, and all for Loves Epilogue, which she longs for as much as you, though she makes it nice with tricks of Loves dissembling; and will you lose all these fine sports for catching birds in the Country, or killing a timerous Hare.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: For all your Court-delights, I'le have none, for in one day in the Country, live more harmless joys, then in years at Court, which heap up Alps of trouble.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: VVell, it is your VVorships pleasure to go into the Country, and be Melancholy, conversing with Beasts, Birds, and Trees, and to leave these Court-pleasures for your rich Heir.
sp.l: VVhere what is left, he means to spend it,
And in high Pleasure there will end it.
sp.p: VVherefore, had not your VVorship better take your pleasure your self? for after a Prodigal, comes a good Husband; for he is necessitated to it; and after a good Husband a Prodigal; for he is obliged to it; like the VVeather, after fair comes foul, and after foul, fair: VVherefore, I beseech your VVorship for the good of your Family, spend most you have, and you shall have Pleasure to boot.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: No Sir, I am resolved of my Course.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
The more is the pity, that good Counsel will not be taken, when it is so prudently given; but Gentlemen will run on to their ruin, I see it, the gods help them! for they will never be advised nor counselled;
but I beseech your Worship here upon my Knees, that you will be pleased to spend most of your Estate for the good of your Posterity; alas Sir! when you leave your Heir in the Golden waves of Riches, in the vast Seas of good Fortune up to the Chin, lest he should be drown'd in the deluge of Happiness; alas! Sir, he will strive to swim, and then look you here, swimming he throws your Gold on that side, and on this side, with his hands and arms, and kicks your Gold with his legs, thighs, and feet, on that side and on this side, and all to save himself from drowning in this whirlpool of Prosperity; wherefore, I beseech your Worship to leave as little as you can, for the good of your House.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: You are a Fooll, Children are but excuses for Covetousness; for it is still for ones own sake, that Men do every thing as the heat of humour and passion leads them; for I have known more covetous old Batchellors and childish Men, then any that have been Married, and had many Children; and let my Heir spend it in God's Name, for he cannot take more pleasure in spending of it, then I in getting of it; and therefore you Puppy, let us go.

div.stage: Exit Monsieur Underward, Tom Solus.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: My Master leads me, for now I am his Puppy; but if my Master were blind, I would lead him, and be his Dog.

div.head: SCENE XXVIII.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Underward, his two Brothers, and two Sisters.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Underward.
sp.p: BRothers and Sisters, I sent for you, to invite you to my Wedding-feast, and also to come home and live with me; and since Heaven hath sent me a rich Wife, I will justly perform my Fathers will, and give those Portions he did allot for you.

sp.speaker: Impoverished.
sp.p: Brother, as Heaven hath given you a rich and beautiful Wife, so Heaven hath given me a rich and gallant Man to my Husband, for I am Married to Monsieur Lover, my Lady's Brother.

sp.speaker: 2 Brothers.
sp.p: And we will go a Wooing, and try if Fortune will give us rich Wives.

sp.speaker: Younger Sist.
sp.p: I have neither Heaven, nor Fortune to my Friend; for Fortune did place me ill, and caused my honest industry and faithful service to be rewarded with sharp words, and cruel blows; Heaven hath forsaken Innocency, and left it to suffer disgrace.

div.stage: She Weeps.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Be patient Sister, I will either recover your Honour, or destroy your Enemy, or die my self.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Jealousie, the younger Sister's Servant.

sp.speaker: Jealous.
sp.p: O Mistress, forgive me, and take me into your favour again, or I die.

sp.speaker: Young. Sist.
sp.p: I can forgive you, but never love you more.

sp.speaker: Jealous.
sp.p: Marry me, and then try to love afterwards.

sp.speaker: Young. Sist.
sp.p: I shall not dare to Marry a Man that shall, or can have any suspition of me, unless my actions prove me false and wicked.

sp.speaker: Jealous.
sp.p: Dear Sister, speak for me, I confess my fault, repent, ask pardon, and promise never to do so again.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: What say you, Brothers, may we in honour perswade our selves to have our Sister Marry this Gentleman, and receive him into our Family?

sp.speaker: Jealous.
sp.p: Gentlemen, the greatest Sins repented of, Heaven pardons.

sp.speaker: 2 Brothers.
sp.p: Brother, this Gentleman is nobly born, honourably bred, hath a great Estate, and is a proper Man.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Well, I perceive, Brothers, you are for him; Sir, I will try all the power of an Elder Brother, to perswade her not only to Marry you, but to love you, which I am very confident she will, being vertuous and good natur'd, and will love you as well, if not better then ever she did.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE XXIX.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Underward, and Tom Diogenes his Man.

sp.speaker: Tom Diogenes.
sp.p: I Beseech your Worship to give me leave once more to advise you from the Country; alass Sir, will you change your Organ for a Bag-pipe, your Harpsichord, for a Cymbal; your Viol, for a Country Fiddle, or a Welsh Croud; a grave Irish Harp, with the Harper that sees what he doth, for a blind Harper with Cats-guts that whirles in the nose, as if it had the Pox; or a Spanish Gythar, to play a Saraband a la mode; with Knacking Castagnetas for a Country Gythar, that sounds like a Tub; and your rare Italian songs with Trilloes for Lancelot du Lake, a Carole, or a Wassel-bowl Song, with some edifying Ballets; and will you change your Corrants, Sarabands and Bralles, for Scotch Jiggs, Hornpipes and Rounds? look before you leap, I beseech your Worship.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: It is all in vain, good Tom; for I am resolved your twinkling device shall not stay me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
But pray hear an old Servant; will you change a Spanish Olia, for boil'd Beef and Cabbage? a French Bisk for Brewis with Beef-broth or buttered Eggs with hot Pepper upon them? and all the Dainties of Sea or Pond-Fish, for a Dace or a Gougeon in the Country,
and all Curiosity of Dressing so Metamorphosed as you shall not know what you eat? and for fruit, change your Musmelons for a Pompion? your most curious Sallads for Onions and Garlick? all your choice Fruits for Crabs? and all your Confectionaries for starcht Carrowaies, or purging Comfits, because you buy them of Country Apothecaries? I beseech your Worship have some mercy of your self, and leave not the delicious Wines, and the sweet juice of Grapes for strong Darby-Ale, fah! how it smells of the Malt, for they put no Water to it, nothing but squeezed Malt, Sir, which inflames the Country Noses.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Tom, I do not tast your advice by no means, no not at all.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sir, I must be bold still to put you in mind not to leave the Court: Will you change your sweet Spanish Gloves, for Dogs Leather-Gloves in the Country, that smell of the dressing? your Spanish Perfumes for choaking Juniper? your Jessamin and Orange-Flowers, for a Posie of Dock-leaves, Daysies and Thime; and your sweet Pomander, for an Orange stuck with Cloves, for a Token to your Dairy-Maid? sweet Powder, for the dust of a Country High-way, to put you in mind of your Mortality, dust to dust? Good Sir, think of it, be kind to your self.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Tom, I smell out your advice to be none of the best Counsel.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: One word more, I beseech your Worship: Will you change your fine Damask Linnen for Country Huswives Cloth, to rub off your Worships fine skin? it may pleasure those that have the Itch: Or will you leave touching the smooth Billiard-balls, to handle Nettles? or the Cold or Chrystal balls, for Fus-balls in the Country? and to leave the glorious apparel'd Lady for a Wastcoatier in the Country? the Ladies silk-Stockins, for Woollen-Stockins in the Country? rich Garters and Roses, for Garters of List of Cloth? rich laced Shoos for wet-Leather-Shoos tyed with points? imbroider'd rich Satin Petticoats for Stamel-Petticoats, perfumed too much with the natural Titillation? either this will stay your Worship, or nothing; if this take not I am in dispair.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Good Tom, it doth not touch upon me at all; but prithee since thou art such a Clown, what makes thee love the Court so?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Troth, I'le tell you Sir; I am as it were given a little to idleness; wherefore, I find it the fittest place for me in the World, Sir; besides, Sir, with his Majesties loyal Subjects, and false Officers below Stairs, I can be drunk when I will at his Majesties charge, of the best Wine; and being provident, and having the disease of good fellowship upon me, being a poor Man, it would undo me, Sir, and eat me out of House and Home; but Providence is above all things, it distinguishes betwixt the wise Men, and the Fools.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: Come, Tom, there is something else in it, that makes thee so earnest.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, nothing to speak of.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: But there is, and therefore tell me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Truly then, (under the Rose,) the Mother of the Maids sends me often about her most serious and important Business, and casts such a loving eye at me; saying, Sweet Tom, I do so trouble thee, but as thou loves me, fetch me a quart of Milk, or so, to make a Posset; and giving me such a loving Nip with her hand, saying, Sweet Tom, go: Now your Worship knows not what this may come to, I being a lazie fellow and pritty handsom, and she a virtuous Lady, we may commit Matrimony, who knows? and with her Motherly care, and my Fatherly duty, we may do your Worship a pleasure, one way or other.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: You flatter your self, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No Sir, she flatters me.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: I thought there was another deadly Sin in it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I find my self very Gentleman-like of late, so as I mean to have the other five deadly Sins.

sp.speaker: Ʋnder.
sp.p: You are a Fool, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O sweet Mother!

list.head: The ACTORS NAMES in the Presence.

div.p: The Interlocutors Names in the Scenes join'd to the Presence

list.item: Monsieur Ʋnderward, and Diogenes his Man.
Madam Impoverish'd, Monsieur Ʋnderwards eldest Sister
A younger Sister of his, and Monsieur Jealousie her Servant.
Monsieur Lover, Servant to Madam Impoverished.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Take-pleasure and Monsieur Adviser, and meet Monsieur. Facil.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Adviser.
sp.p: MOns. Facil, Where have you been so early this morning, abroad?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I have been at Church, to see a young Virgin and a Batchellor married to day.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: How do you know she is a Virgin?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: By her modest Countenance.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p:
Faith, Women have more modesty in
their countenance, then in their natures; wherefore you may be deceived by her countenance; for Womens countenances, like false glasses, make their minds appear fairer then they are; for a modest countenance may have a wanton mind.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But this Brides countenance was so modest, I wish that I had been her Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Would you have married her only for her modest countenance?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Yes, for a modest countenance is the greatest Beauty in my eye.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, that Beauty never lasts above a day, nay, an hours acquaintance fadeth it, two hours wither it, and in three hours it is quite vanish'd away.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Some Women have modest countenances and natures all their life-time.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Their life must be very short, if it last no longer then their modesty: 'Tis true, Women have feigned modesty, but not real modesty; for they put on modesty, as they do paint, the one to make them appear fairer, the other to make them appear chaster then they are.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: You do not deserve either a modest, or chast Woman.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, I hate both modesty and chastity in Women; for modesty and chastity are enemies to the Masculine Sex, and worse then a Cloister, as being more restraint.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Well, leaving Modesty, Chastity and Cloisters, will you go to the Bridal-House?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Yes, for I believe there will be liberty and choice.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: There will be two choice Brides.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Why, hath one Man married two Women?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: No, but two Men have married two Women; for there are two Brides and two Bridegrooms.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: It had been better that one Bridegroom had two Brides, for then he might have spar'd one for a Friend.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: It had not been better for you, unless you had been that Friend to receive that Courtesie.

sp.speaker: Takepleas.
sp.p: I would have endeavour'd with all the Rhetorick I have, and all the Protestations I could make, and all the Oaths I could swear, to make him believe I was his Friend, that he might be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Come, come, they would have done thee no service.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But I might have done him service, at least to his spare-Bride; but who are those that are Married?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Sir John Amorous, to the Lady Coy; and Sir William Sage, to the Lady Vertue. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Long-life, and Mr. Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Mr. Longlife, I am glad to see you look so well, and that you are strong and lusty.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: So am I to see you so, good Master Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: I thank God, though I am old, I feel no stitches.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Beshrew me, I feel some stitches now and then

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: O! that is nothing, for the youngest and strongest Man of them all, will feel stitches sometimes.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: I rather wish the young Men did feel them, then I, for they are better able to endure them; but what News do you hear Mr. Aged?

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Faith, none that is good, or that is worth the hearing.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: It is a sign the times are bad, the times are bad.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Men are so evil, Mr. Longlife, that the times must needs be so.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: The times were better when we were young.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: We thought them so, being young; for young Men have not much experience, nor long acquaintance of the World; they endeavour to know, and be acquainted with the Vices in the VVorld, though not the Vertues.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Faith, Vertue is rather talked of, then known, at least then practised.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Indeed Men preach Vertue, but practise Vice.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: 'Tis such old Men as we are, that are the Preachers, and young Men the Practitioners.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Yes, evil young Men say, That old Men preach Vertue, when they are past practising Vice.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Indeed young Men despise old Men's Counsels and Advice, and will believe nothing they say, untill they live to be old themselves, and then they see their past-follies, and think themselves only wise, because they are old.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Then all Men think themselves wise, if young Men think themselves wiser then old Men, and old Men think themselves wiser then young Men.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: 'Tis true, they do so; and the same way Men think other Men Fools; for young Men think old Men Fools, and old Men think young Men Fools.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Nay, old Men do more then think young Men Fools, for they know young Men are Fools; for 'tis impossible they can be wise, for wisdom is not born with Men, nor left to Men as Inheritances are.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: No By'rlady, they must be bound Apprentices to Time, and serve Time many years, before they can be wise Men.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Well, let us leave foolish young Men to Time, and let you and I go take the fresh air for Health.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: With all my heart, let us go. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Brides and Bridegrooms, and all the Bridal Guests, Sir Mercury, Poet one of the Bride-Men, and the Lady Fancy one of the Bride-Maids, that helps to lead one of the Brides to the Church.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Gentlemen Bridegrooms, we must rifle your Brides of their Bride-Garters.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amorous.
sp.p: If it be the custom, I submit.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: But I will not agree to such an uncivil custom, for no man shall pull off my Wives Garters, unless it be my self.

sp.speaker: Vertue.
sp.p: We have pull'd off our Garters already, and therefore if these Batchellor-Gentlemen, will have them, we will send for them.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Pray Ladies let us have them, for the Bride-Garters are the young Batchellors fees.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Since we must not rifle for their Garters, let us cast Dice for them.

sp.speaker: Takepleas.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: The Bridegrooms points being our fees, therefore we must rifle for the points.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: If you please Ladies, we are ready to be rifled.

div.stage: The Women offer to take off the Points, but Lady Vertue hinders them.

sp.speaker: Vertue.
sp.p: Ladies, pray stay, for it is the custom, not to unpoint the Bridegrooms, until they be ready to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I am ready to go to Bed, if the Ladies please.

sp.speaker: One of the Female-Guests.
sp.p: No, we will stay till Night.

div.stage: Exeunt all, only two of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: The Lady Coy is one of the most modest and bashful Brides that ever I saw; in so much, as she is ashamed to look upon her Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Some of her modesty ought to be reserved, or else she will have none left for to morrow.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Why, doth Modesty wast like a Watch-candle, in a night?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Yes, faith, it is a light that soon goes out, or rather a shadow that soon vanishes.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Then the Lady Vertue has no shadows, for she appears neither bashful, nor bold; but she is both in her Behaviour and Countenance like a Bridal-Guest, rather then a Bride. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the Brides, Bridegrooms, and all their Bridal-Guests, Men and Women.

sp.speaker: Sir John Amorous.
sp.p: PRay let us not dance, but go to bed.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: That will be an injury to your Bridal-Guests, to rob them of their Mirth and Musick, by going to bed so soon.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: No, Ladies, we will dance; Musick, play.

div.stage: The Musick plays, and they dance; Sir John Amorous kisses his Bride, and Courts her with smiles and amorous looks.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and Ladies, for Heavens sake, have mercy upon two languishing Bridegrooms, and leave off dancing for this time.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Have I found you out, Sir William Sage!

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I was never hid, Madam.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Yes, but you were; for now I perceive you would go to bed with your Bride.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I shall not need to obscure my desires, Madam, for it is lawful for any Man to lie with his own wife.

sp.speaker: Mediator.
sp.p: You are a Wag, you are a Wag, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: No Madam, for to be a Wag, is to be unseasonably wanton, which I am not.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Faith, this Dancing is unseasonable, therefore fair Ladies, attend the fair Brides to bed.

sp.speaker: Female Guests.
sp.p: Come, Lady Coy, we will help to undress you.

sp.speaker: Coy.
sp.p: No truly, but you shall not, for I will not go to bed.

div.stage: They seem earnest to have her to bed, and she to stay.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: What is the matter, Ladies, will not you let our Brides go to bed?

sp.speaker: Female Guests.
sp.p: We desire to wait on them, and to help to undress them, but the Lady Coy will not go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Then pray go with my Bride.

sp.speaker: One of the Ladies.
sp.p: Yes, if she please to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Wife will not you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Vertue.
sp.p: Yes, if you please to have me.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: 'Tis my desire.

div.stage: Exit Lady Vertue, and some of the Ladies with her: Sir John Amorous comes and kisses his Bride.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Pray go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Coy.
sp.p: Pray let me stay here.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, she would be carried to bed; carry your Wife to bed, Sir John Amorous.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Not against her will, although against her consent.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: In words you mean.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Come, Sweet-heart, I will usher you into your Chamber.

div.stage: Exit Sir John Amorous, leading his Bride, who seems very unwilling to go, all the Company goeth with them, only Adviser and Facil stay; Facil fetches a sigh.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: O how happy a man is Sir John Amorous! and how unhappy a man am I!

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Perchance two days hence, Sir J. Amorous will think himself as unhappy, as you think your self now, for a great surfeit is as bad as a sharp hunger. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Vertue as in her Chamber, with some other female Guests; she seems to undress her self.

sp.speaker: Lady Vertue.
sp.p: PRay Ladies help to undress me.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: That we will.

div.stage: They unpin her Gorget.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Shall we fling the Stockins when you and your Bridegroom are a bed?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Yes, if you please, Ladies.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: And shall we break the Bride-Cake over your head?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: I must intreat you to omit that custom, as also setting a Sack-posset upon the bed; for the crumbs of Cake and drops of Posset, will be very ill bed-fellows; besides, it is not a cleanly Custom; but I have given order that all such Junkets shall be provided for you in another room, to make you merry, when I and my Husband are a bed.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: So I perceive, you will send us away, as soon as you can.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: I'le leave your staying, or going away, to your own discretion. Enter a Maid-Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Madam, your Bridegroom hath sent to know, whether you be in Bed.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: I shall be in a short time, tell him: Come Ladies, let us go into the Bed-chamber. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Amorous, and his Bride, with the rest of the Female-Guests.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amorous.
sp.p: Ladies, I shall leave my Bride with you, to help her to bed. Exit Sir J. Amorous.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Come, Lady Coy, to morrow you will be Lady Amorous.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Why, do Wives never take their Husbands name till the day after Marriage?

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p:
No, for the first day, they neither are called by their own, nor their Husbands name; but are
called Brides, as an Interlude between both.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Come, come, undress the Bride.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: That we will soon do.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: I will not be undrest.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: What, Lady, will you lie in your Clothes?

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: If she will lie in her Clothes, it will neither be easie, convenient, nor cleanly; but come, come, Lady we will undress you.

div.stage: They offer to undress her, but she puts them back.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: I will not be undrest.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Lady, give me leave to ask you, whether you married your Gown or your Person to your Husband?

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: My Person.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Then pull off your Gown, and go unclothed to bed.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: I would undress me, but I am ashamed to lie with a Man.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: That shame is very unnecessary at this time; wherefore cast it off with your Clothes.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: I am afraid to lie by a Man.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: That fear is an effeminate fear, and will not last long; wherefore undress, undress, for Loves sake.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: I must go, and say my Prayers first.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Faith, Jove will dispence, with a Bride one night; the truth is, Bridal-Prayers are irreligious.

div.stage: Enter a Maid in hast.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here comes the Bridegroom and all the Gentlemen attending him.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: O! shut the door, shut the door, for Jupiters sake.

div.stage: The Scene to shut the door, the Men knock.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Open the Door, and let the Bridegroom in.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: He cannot come as yet, the Bride's not a bed.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amorous.
sp.p: Let me come in, or I'le break open the door.

sp.speaker: L. Coy.
sp.p: O keep him out, or I shall die for fear.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: You shall not come, until we please.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Let us come, or we will enter by force.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: You shall not, for we will defend the breach.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: With what? with what?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: With our Tongues and Armes.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Your Tongues are pointless and edgless, and your Armes are weak defences.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: You shall find them otherwise; but pray Sir J. Amorous carry away your unruly Regiment, and we will promise you upon our words, and honours, that as soon as the Bride is in Bed, we will come to you and give you notice, then usher you into the Bride-bed, with Epithalamiums.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amorous.
sp.p: Upon condition that you will be speedy, I will depart.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: We will, we will: Come Lady Coy to bed, to bed, for shame. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Sir William Sage, with all the Gedtlemen, his Bridal-Guests, passing over the Stage, and going away again; after them comes Sir John Amorous, as going to bed in his Night-Gown, Madam Mediator and the Ladies usher him, and when he passes, this Epithalamium is sung.

lg.l: NOw at the Door
You'l stand no more,
But enter the Bridal-bed:
Where you will prove
The Sweets of Love
With God Hymen's banquet fed.
Then Noble Knight
Put out the Light,
Her flaming Eyes will guide you;
And in her Armes
Those Circled Charmes
In Wedlock's Islands hide you.
Now all the joyes
Of Girles and Boyes,
Of sweeter pledges send you,
And know no strife
'Twixt Man and Wife,
But all the Blessings send you.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Madam Fancy, and Sir Mercury Poet, coming out of the Bridal-Chamber together.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Madam Fancy do not you wish to be a Bride, and that this night were your Wedding night?

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: I should be well content to be a Bride, and to have a Wedding day, conditionly the day would last to the end of my life; but mistake me not, I mean for the length of the day, not shortness of life.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: I perceive you would have no sleeping time.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: You mistake, I would have no Wedding night. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Facil and Adviser.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: BUt are you seriously in love with the Lady Coy, the now Lady Amorous?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Yes seriously, but I may despair I shall never compass my desires.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, it is not probable you should obtain them, but yet you had best try.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: That were but to plunge my self deeper into an unfortunate love.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But a wise Man will omit no industry to compass his desires, neither do the Gods assist idle and cowardly Men.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But she is not only new Married, but so guarded with Modesty and Vertue, as unlawful love cannot get audience, much less a favour.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, if I were you, I would try in despite of her Modesty and Vertue.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Fie! a Lover and a Coward! when the worst is but to be denied; but yet I would take many denials, before I would desist of my Suit; and if you do not pursue it, you partly deny your self.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: How should I make my love known unto her?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: By some Lady confident, or she-servant Favourite; as also by Complemental Letters, and Love-Verses made in her praise; besides, making Balls and Collations to entertain her.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I'le take your Counsel.

div.stage: Enter Mimick in hast.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But stay, here comes Mimick the Lady Amorous Fool, who will be the fittest of all for this Employment; I'le speak to him: Stay, stay, honest friend, and let us speak a word or two.

div.stage: Mimick goes on in hast.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: God be with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But will not you stay, a word or two?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
Sir, I have stay'd twice two, that is four; nay by the Mass it was six at least; for you have asked me twice to stay, till you speak a word or two, and a word, and a word, and two and two is six, by my
Calculation; and if you speak a word and two more, it will make three times three, that is just nine, the Golden Number, if I be not mistaken.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: You are right, friend.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: A right friend is a great friend, and a great friend is a good friend; and so God be with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Nay stay and tell me, are not you the Lady Amorous Mimick?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No truly, Sir, I am the Lady Vertue's Mimick, and the Lady Amorous Fool.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: What, do you serve both the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I am at both the Ladies service, Sir; God help me and give me Grace to please them well.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Thou art an honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But an honest fellow cannot serve two Mistresses, the more the pity!

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But you may serve this Gentleman, and he will serve thee; for if thou will but conveigh Letters, or can any way bring him to the private speech of the Lady Amorous, he will reward you bountifully.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I like the reward well; but I do not serve the Lady Amorous, but the Lady Vertue; but she being my Ladies Friend, and her Maid my Friend, I shall do my endeavour to deserve his gifts. Exit Mimick.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, I doubt not, but our design will go on well.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I wish it may.

div.stage: Exit Facil at one door, and Adviser at another, who meets Take-pleasure as in hast.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Whether away so fast, Take-pleasure?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: I am going to a Company of Ladies that have sent for me.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Let me go with you; for one Man can never please a company of Ladies; and surely it seems they are in great distress, otherwise they would not have sent for you in such hast.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Not sent for me! why, what do you think of me?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why, I think you are a good fellow, and love a Mistress well; but I do not think you the Grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: If I were, you should not come near my Seraglio.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But let me go with thee to these Ladies, for they are not in a Seraglio, nor never will be; they love their liberty so well.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: I am content, upon condition, you do not so much as look upon those Ladies I court.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But how if these Ladies look upon me?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Yes, there is the mischief; therefore you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But if you let me go, I'le promise you, I'le wink to those Ladies that look on me.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p:
Winking is more dangerous then if you should plainly woo them; for winking is a kind of
Wooing, and will win a Lady as soon as words will do.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Then I will shut both my eyes.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: That will be worse, for that will put them in mind of going to bed; it will be like sleeping.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Prithee let me go, and order me as you will.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Wellcome, and as we go I'le tell you, how you shall behave your self to those Ladies.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I will be govern'd according to your instructions. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter M. Mediator, and the Female-Guests, the day after the Wedding, to the Lady Amorous, who sits in a shaded place, and Curtains drawn about her, a Maid stands by.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: VVHere is the Lady Coy, the now Lady Amorous?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: There; my Lady is within those Curtains.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Why are you so benighted, as to have your Curtains drawn so darkly about you?

sp.speaker: L. Amorous.
sp.p: I do not love the light.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Are you faln out with the light?

sp.speaker: L. Amorous.
sp.p: In truth I am ashamed to see the light.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Ashamed! let's see your face, whether you blush or not?

div.stage: The Lady offers to draw the Curtain, the Lady Amorous endeavours to hold it, and hideth her self behind it.

sp.speaker: L. Amorous.
sp.p: O fie! for Cupid and Venus sake do not look upon me, for if you do, I shall die with blushing.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Come, come, we will see you.

sp.speaker: L. Amorous.
sp.p: I'le rather run away.

div.stage: She runs away, the Ladies follow her, and meet the Lady Vertue.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Madam, we were a going to see how you appear, since you are a Wife.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: I hope I do not appear worse then I did, when I was a Maid; for I have not been Married so long as to have Children, Cares and Troubles, to decay my Youth and Beauty.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: No, but we did imagine you would have been as most Brides are, shame-faced, and out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Why so, since Marriage is lawful, honest, and honourable? for if Marriage had been an act, that deserves a blush, I would not have Married.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: But the Lady Coy, the now Lady Amorous, your fellow-Bride, is so out of Countenance, and doth so blush, as she is asham'd to appear in the light, and is forced to shut her eyes through shame, when her Husband looks upon her.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Why, hath she deceived her Husband? was she not a Virgin when she Married, that she is so out of Countenance as not to return her Husbands looks

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: No, it is, that she is so extream modest.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Modesty is only ashamed of dishonesty, and not of that, which is honest to the Laws of God, Nature, and all civil Nations and People; but to answer for my self, if my Husband approves, likes, and is pleased with me, I have no reason to be out of Countenance; and I hope my Vertue is such, as not to be ashamed of the light: But come Ladies, I have prepared a Banquet, to which I invite you, to join with me in rejoicing at my happy Union. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Adviser, and Monsieur Facil, to Monsieur Courtly, who is sitting at the Table, and writing.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Adviser.
sp.p: VVHat! writing!

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I am casting up some Accounts.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, I will see what a good Husband you are.

div.stage: He takes up the Paper.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: That Paper is the account of yesterday's expence.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I can judge by a day's expence a week's, and by a week's a year's.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: That you cannot, for some days and weeks are more expensive then others.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, at the years end several sums comes to one and the same yearly sum, as so much yearly spent.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Indeed for the most part it doth.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Leave your talking, and let me read your Expences, this is the yesterday's expence; let me see, here is the account of the expence of Ushering four Ladies.
Imprimis, To a Sexton, to place four Ladies in several Pews in a Puritan Church, to hear a holy Brother preach, 2 Crowns.
Item, For Sillibubs in the Park for those Ladies, 20 s.
For two little baskets of Cherries, that hold some dozen Cherries a piece, but the first of this year, 15 s.
To the Keeper of the Park-gate, half a Crown.
Item. for Cheesecakes and Rhennish-Wine in the fine Garden for those Ladies, 20 s.
To a Fortune-teller, to tell those Ladies their Fortunes, 40 s.
Also to the Door-keeper of the Garden, half a Crown.
Item. for a Supper for those Ladies at my Lodgings, 5 l.
To the Musick, 3 l.
For Torches to light those Ladies home to their Lodgings, 5 shill.
The total comes to 13 l. 15 s.
You might have saved the 5 s. for Torch-light, by keeping those Ladies all night in your Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I should have been a loser by that thrift.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But do you spend every day thus much on Ladies?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Not every day, but most days I do.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: And after one and the same manner, and in the same places, and with the same Ladies?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No, I have variety for my money.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Why, that is some comfort to you, and pleasure to the Ladies; but will it hold out?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No, faith, for neither my purse nor person will hold out; wherefore I must leave off to play the Gentleman-usher to Ladies, and go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: You had better be the fore-horse in a Cart, then first Gentleman-usher in a Coach; ushering is so laborious; besides, the intollerable charge; in so much that you may with less expence maintain a whole Village of Country Wives with their Daughters and Maid-servants, then entertain one Lady; moreover, those Villages will serve you, when as you are forced through civility to serve the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You say true; therefore I'le go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But will not those Ladies follow you?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Let me tell you, That is to be consider'd; and I would not have you go into the Country, for I and the rest of your friends would be sorry to lose your Company.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p:
Faith, the Ladies ingross me so much, as I
have no time to say my Prayers, or to think of my self, much less to keep Company with my friends.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: It seems you do not take the Ladies to be your friends.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: If they be, they are very troublesome, and chargeable friends, which Friends, I could be well content to be quit off, if I could tell how or which way.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: There be a hundred wayes to shake off those Ladies, if you will.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No faith, I cannot; for they stick as close as burres, unless I should rudely quarrel with them, and basely raile against them; and if I did, it would be a question still whether I should be quit of them?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Let me advise you, how you may civilly be quit of them.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I shall gladly follow your advice.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Do not visit them, out of some pretence you are not well.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: If I do not visit them, they'l visit me.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Then pretend some Law-suit.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Faith, they will follow me, and go to all the Courts of Judicature, to hear my Cause pleaded and judged.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Then go to a Tavern every day, they will not follow you thither.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p:
Yes faith, some of them will, at least to the Tavern door in their Coaches to require my Company; but howsoever, they will send messenger after messenger to hasten me to them, pretending earnest business; and when I come, 'tis either to usher them to a Play, or to
Church, or to the Exchange, or to the places of pleasure, or to the Fields, Park, or Garden, or else to some Ball, or particular meeting, or to some Picture-drawer, or to play at Cards, or the like; and to Man them to these places, they will send to me, before I am up or awake; the truth is, they will not let me rest in quiet.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But this is a slavish life.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But do they never reward thy service, Courtly?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes, as the Devil doth his Servants.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: With fire; for they send me hot burning Spirits, which are called Cordials.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: It seems they think you want strength.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I must needs, when they tire me off my legs, ushering them from place to place.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Do they give thee no Amorous favours?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes; but they are better pleased, I should prevent them, and take favours from them before they are presented.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But that is some recompence for thy time and charge.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p:
The recompence, if you call it so, is the worse; for I had rather give them my Estate, then receive their Rewards; for though they make their favours, as a reward to their Courting-servants; yet their rewards are their chief pleasures, and the rewarded
pains, of their Courting servants, lose more health by their favours, then they get wealth in their service.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: The last advice is, You must be as if you were drunk.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: That advice is worst of all; for then they are so busie, and make such puddering about me, to lay me to sleep, as they make me almost mad.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: You have said so much, as I perceive your own advice is the best, to go into the Country; and if the Country will not save your body, life and estate, from these Locust-Ladies, you must travel into some other Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: If I do, they will follow me; for Ladies are as far-travellers in this age, as the Men; and I know some Gentlemen that are followed by Ladies out of one Kingdom into another, so as they do not know whether to go, for the World is not sufficient to hide or obscure them from the Ladies search.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why, then most of the Men must turn Fryers, for that is to live in this world, as if they liv'd out of it.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: That shift will not serve their turn; for if the Cavaliers turn Fryers, the Ladies will turn Nunnes, and then make those Fryers their Confessors.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Then there is no way for Men to escape those Ladies followers.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes, there is one way.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: What way is that?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You must excuse me, for I will not declare it. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Facil, and he speaks to himself.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I wonder Mimick stays so long, and doth not bring me an answer yet, from the Lady Amorous.
But here he is.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Monsieur Mimick! well met; have you delivered my Letter to the Lady Amorous?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Facil, I did deliver it to her.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: And how did she receive it?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, she received your Letter, as all Women do Love-Presents.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: With an outward dislike, and an inward affection.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: If she received my Letter, with a displeased countenance, I judg she doth not love me.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then your judgment is not wise; for love lives not in the countenance, but in the heart.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But the Countenance expresses love; for a well pleased Countenance, expresses a well affected heart.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
If you ground your belief on a Womans Countenance, you will be deceived; for Womens Countenances for the most part are as false as their faces; the one is glast with smiles, as the other with Pomatum; and dissembling modesty is like Spanish Red, which is
soon rub'd off with acquaintance and jealousie; or a peevish humour wipes off their smiles; so that there is no trust in their Countenances; for they change every minute of an hour; wherefore, they are unskilful Men, and unhappy Lovers, that steer the course of their desires, by the Card of their Mistresses Countenances, which vary almost every moment, or by the Stars of their Mistresses eyes, which are wandring Planets. The truth is, most Lovers have troublesome Voyages in love, by reason all Womens minds are as inconstant as the wind.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But I hope, by your favour and industry for me, to the Lady, my Voyage will be easie and free.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Do you believe I have power on your Mistress mind, as the Witches of Lapland have on the Winds?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Faith, Monkies, Dogs, Parrots, and Fools, are powerful with Women, especially with Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then deliver your Love-Letters to the Ladies Monkys, tell your Love-Messages to the Ladies Parrots, and give your Love-Collations to the Ladies Dogs, and your Love-bribes to my Ladies Fool.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: It is the easiest way; only to employ her Fool, and to encourage you, I give you five Pounds for the present, and more I promise you hereafter, to plead my suit, and to speak in my behalf.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
Faith, your case is so bad, as it requires a witty and ingenuous knave to make it seem a good case,
and an eloquent Orator to make it seem a clear case; for Oratory makes a foul case seem fair, and great fees makes an Orator's wit quick, and his tongue smooth.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Well, I will trust to your Knavery, wish well to your Oratory, and hope Fortune will favour your Wisdom.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: You mistake; for Fortune never favours wise Men, but Fools. Exit Facil.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Well, craft shall serve for wisdom, and the chief part of my craft must be to Fool this Lover, or rather to cozen him; for Lovers are Fools of Cupid's making, and they wear Fools Coats in Cupid's Court.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the Lady Vertue, and Sir William Mimick, who seems to be in a very serious study, not taking any notice of his Master and Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Surely Mimick has State-matters in his head, he is so studious and serious.

div.stage: He doth not answer.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Why Mimick, are you deaf?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I am somewhat thick of hearing.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But Mimick, let us know what is the cause you are in so serious a study.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I am considering with my self, what profession I shall be of.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: And what Profession have you chosen to be of?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I have not chosen any as yet, for I waver in my mind amongst many Professions, as an amorous Lover doth amongst many Ladies, not resolving which to address himself to; for though he would enjoy them all, yet he can court but one at a time; and though he resolveth to court all, yet he can but enjoy one at a time.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But he may court and enjoy them all, one after another.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, that is an endless work; for before the last Lady is courted and enjoyed, he will be forced to be of the Profession of a Priest, to preach his own funeral Sermon, or of a Sexton, to dig his own grave: But leaving Priests and amorous Lovers, what Profession shall I be of?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: There are so many Court-fools, that they never thrive with that Profession; for what they get by flattery, they spend in vanity.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: The Law is more of the Knaves then the Fool's side, therefore I shall never thrive in that Profession.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: What think you of being a Merchant?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
I could Traffick with Jest, but I am afraid in some of my Ventures I should have my head broke;
therefore, I will not be of that Profession.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a States-man?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, I think I am fool enough to be a States-man, but I have not Formality enough; besides, I shall make such disorders and disturbances in State-affairs, as I may chance to be kill'd in an uproar or seditious Tumult.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: What think you of being a Soldier?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, for I am more safe from danger in my Fools Coat, then they in their Iron-arms; and shall get more by a Fool's Profession, then a Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: What think you of being a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: That I am now; for I learn every day to play the Fool better and better.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a City-Magistrate?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I like that the best; for my Fools Coat will serve for my Magistrates Gown; but yet I am afraid of the Common-people in these seditious times.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: What think you of being a Traveller?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: O Lord! so I may travel to my wit's end.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a Chymist?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, I get more Gold by playing the Fool with Lords and Ladies, then Chymists do by playing the Fools with Fire and Furnace.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Then I think you had best continue your own Profession still, which is to play the Fool.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
But my Profession of playing the Fool is
a general Profession, and I would fain have a particular Profession; for there are few Men but have some other Profession besides their Natural Profession; Wherefore, I must study some other Profession.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What do you think then of being a Vintner?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: My Guests will drink up my Wine, and leave me their Scores; lie with my Wife, and give her the Pox; and if I have not a handsom Woman to my Wife, I shall have no Guests.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I shall have only my Measures for my pains, and the shreds for my labour.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: What think you of being a Usurer?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: So a Fool and his Money would be soon parted, and I shall have bonds for my Money; but a hundred to one if I get my Money by the bonds.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What think you of being an Amorous Lover?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I shall woo more Mistresses, then I shall win, and win more Mistresses then I shall use.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But you may get a rich Wife, if you Woo well.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: If I should woo the best of any Man, I shall sooner get the Pox with a Mistress, then VVealth with a VVife; for Fortune is the only Match-maker.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But there is a saying, That Fools have Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Not all fools; for there be more Fools then good fortune; the truth is, There are so many Fools, as it is impossible for Fortune to favour them all.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But Fortune may favour those that are most foolish.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then she will not favour me; wherefore I'le reject Fortune, relie upon my own wit.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Your VVit is so weak, as it cannot uphold you.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I'le try the strength of it, and when I fall for want of VVit, it is a proper time for Fortune to raise me up to shew her power.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: VVell, we will leave you to your study, and when you have chosen a Profession, I suppose you will make us acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No doubt of it; for you must help to put me into practise. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Longlife, and Mr. Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Longlife. How are you since you went abroad,

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you Mr. Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: I am now come to you, to ask you a question, whether you would not think it were wise for us, we having only two Children you, a Son and I a Daughter, to match them together, and so we being both rich, we may joyn our Estates together, by joyning our Children together which will make them both flow in plenty,

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
I like your proposition, concerning the joyning
our riches together, by joyning our Children together: But my Son is a Wit, Mr. Aged, and your Daughter I hear is a Wit; and if their wits be joyned together, it may over power their Wealth; for Wit and Wealth doth never agree together; For wit regards not Wealth, and wealth regards not wit; which is the reason that those, which have most Wit, (which are Poets) are poor; For you shall seldom read, or hear, That natutal Poets are rich. And both our Children being Poetical, should we marry them together, would undo them.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: By the Mass, you say true.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Then we must endeavour to marry our Children to Fooles; you must provide a foolish man for your Daughter, and I a foolish woman for my Son; That the dulness of the Fool, may allay the quickness of the Wit, which will make a good temper, causing them to thrive in wealth, and to increase Posterity; for let me tell you, That great Wits for the most part have few Children, but what their brain produces, which are Ideas, Inventions and Opinions; Ideas are Daughters; Inventions are Sons, and Opinions Hermaphrodites; and the production of these Incorporeal Children, hinders the production of Corporeal Children; and we both desire to have Corporeal Grand-Children to uphold our Families.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: You say wisely, Mr. Long-life; and therefore, we must endeavour to marry our Children to Fools, for the Wealth and Posterities of our Families. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir John Amorous, and his Lady.

sp.speaker: LAdy.
sp.p: Sir John, Sir John, I take it very unkindly, that you should go abroad, and leave my Company?

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: Sometimes, Wife, to be absent from each other, is a refreshment, and Temperance is part of Prudence.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I love not such Refreshments, Temperance, and Prudence; wherefore, you must either stay at home and keep me Company, or I shall seek other Company elsewhere.

div.stage: Exit Lady. Sir J. Amorous Solus.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: That will be some ease; for I had rather be a Cuckold then be bound to one Woman, especially my Wife.

div.stage: Enter his Wife's Maid.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: Mal, I'le prefer thee.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I thank you, Master.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: I'le prefer thee from my Servant, to be my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: If you had been unmarried, and would prefer me from being your Mistress, to be your Wife, I should have taken it for an honour.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: But I am Married, Mal, and thou shalt take thy Ladie's place, in thy Ladie's absence.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I had rather Marry Tom your Butler lawfully, then lie with my Master unlawfully.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: Why, Mal, Love is lawful, and to serve your Master is lawful; wherefore, it is lawful to serve your Master's Love.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But some kinds of Love are unlawful, and some kinds of Service are unlawful; for it is unlawful to love Vice, and unlawful to serve the Devil; wherefore it is unlawful to be my Master's Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir J. Amor.
sp.p: To be your Master's Whore, is to be your Master's Mistress; and to be the Butler's Wife, is to be the Butler's Slave; but I'le leave you to the Butler's droppings of his Taps: But howsoever, Consider it well, Mal, for you will be good enough for the Butler afterwards. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir William Sage and his Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir William Sage.
sp.p: I Wonder that Mimick is not here! for his Company is very delightful, to pass away idle; time for idle time is only free for Fools Company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He is rather a Knave then a Fool; but here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Mimick.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Mimick, have you chosen a Profession yet?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes, marry have I, for I intend to be an Orator.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: If you be a professed Orator, I suppose you have studied a speech.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes, I have studied, as Orators use to do, in making an Oration; for I have rackt my Brain, stretch'd my Wit, strapado'd my Memory, tortured my thoughts, and kept my Sences awake.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Certainly, it is a very eloquent and wise Oration, since you have taken so much pains.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Labour and Study is not a certain rule for wise, witty, or eloquent Orations or Speeches; for many studied Speeches are very foolish: But will you hear my Speech?

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But then Master, you must stand for, signifie, or represent a Multitude, or an Assembly.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: That is impossible, being but a single person.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Why doth not a single Figure stand for a Number, as the Figure of Five, Eight or Nine, and joining Ciphers to them, they stand for so many Hundreds, or Thousands: And here be two Joint-Stools, one of which Stools and you Lady shall serve for two Ciphers and my Master for the Figure of Nine, and so you two and the Joint-Stool make Nine hundred.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But if the Assembly be so big, as to be a Company of Nine hundred they cannot all stand so near, as to hear what you speak, neither ean your voice reach to the Circumferent Ears.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: The greatest Glory of an Orator is to have Crouds of People follow him, and those that hear the least will praise him the most; and the truth is, That all Orators gain more renown by those that do not hear them, but only see them, then by those that stand so near, as to hear what they speak; for there is ten to one of those that do not hear them, to those that do hear chem; So that if those that do hear them, should dispraise their Orations, yet those that hear them not, will commend them, and having ten to one of their side, they may say what they will, they shall be applauded, and the most Voices carry them up to Fame's Tower; which considering, I will set another Joint-stool as another Cipher to my Lady, and three Ciphers, with the Figure of Nine, my Master, will make it Nine thousand.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: As many as you please.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But what shall I have for a Pulpit or standing place? for I must mount above all the Assembly?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Take another Joint-stool, and stand upon that.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: O fie! that will not appear well; besides, I shall stand tottering, ready to fall, and the very fear of falling, will put me out of my Speech.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But you will appear standing upon a Joint-stool, like as a Statue upon a Pedistal.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I should be well pleased to have a Statue made for me, and set up as an honour and remembrance of me; but I shall not be pleased to stand as a Statue my self.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Why then get a Tub; and stand in that.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: A Tub will not do me any service, unless it be a mounted Tub. But for this time I'le stand upon the Table, without Tub or Case, to speak the naked truth; and thus I ascend.

div.stage: He ascends upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Begin.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Stay, I must breathe first, hawk, spit, blow my nose, humm, and look gravely round about upon the People, and then speak at first in a low voice, then raise my Voice by degrees, until I come to the highest strain or point.

div.stage: He Speaks.

sp.p:
NOble, Honourable, and Worthy Auditors, I am come here to speak of a Subject which concerns all Men; which General Subject is Women; and I am not only to Treat of Women, which is an easie Subject to be Treated of; but of the Chastity of Women, which is an hard, frozen Subject; and so hard frozen it is, that all the heat Love can bring is not able to thaw it; the truth is, Chastity is a Subject, that lives at a great distance; for though the two Names, Woman and Chastity, are oft-times joined together, yet the several Subjects of those Names, dwell not near each other; for Chastity dwells at the Poles, where no Woman is; and Women dwell or inhabit the Torrid Zone, where no
Chastity is: Thus you may perceive that Names are more easily joined, then the things they signifie; but how to bring Chastity and Women together, is the difficulty, indeed so difficult as it is impossible; and as impossible as for hot Hell and cold Heaven to meet, or for gods and devils to be friends: But noble Auditors the Names Chast Women being join'd together, are sufficient; for that Conjunction of Names contents, satisfies and pleases all Men, as Fathers, Sons, Brothers and Husbands, that would have their Daughters, Sisters, Mothers and Wives Chast; and as for Amorous Lovers, they are pleased to have the Subjects dwell at distance; so that Art and Nature, Deceit and Verity have agreed together to make all Men happy, so far as concerns Women.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Leave off your Prating, or I'le fling one of these Ciphers at your head.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Will not you let me speak out my Oration?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, unless it were better.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: If you will let me speak out my Speech, I'le make the two Poles meet in the very forehead of the Torrid Zone of a Man's head.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'le hear no more; wherefore, come off from the Table.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Well, I obey, although I am vexed at the heart, that I must not speak out my Speech, as also to be disgraced before an Assembly of Nine thousand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You knavish Fool, what cause invited, perswaded, or commanded you to speak an Oration concerning the Chastity of Women?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: That which perswaded me to speak an Oration, and not only an Oration, but a factious or malicious Oration was that which perswaded all Orators; first, felf-love to shew their Wit; next, their ill Nature to make a division and dissention amongst Mankind.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, since you have express'd the evil Orators of these evil times, such as make Factions and Divisions; I will express such Orators as ought to be; and thus I'le speak to this Assembly.

div.stage: She Speaks.

sp.p:
NOble, Honourable and Worthy Auditors, I am come here to contradict a Knavish Fool, that has spoken to the Disgrace of VVomen; saying, That only the Names of VVomen and Chastity are joined together, but the Subjects dwell far asunder; which is false; for though some VVomen, as the scum of the Female Sex, be Incontinent, yet all VVomen are not so; for some VVomen are Chast by Nature, others by Vertue, and some by Honour: As for Vertue and Honour, they are like to Plants set or planted by Education, and grow up like to tall Cedars or strong Oaks in the Mind, which bear no evil fruits; as Vices
and base qualities, or evil and dishonest desires: But Worthy Auditors, give me leave to tell you, That Women are the unhappiest Creatures which Nature ever made; not only that they are the most shiftless Creatures, but the most abused of any other Creatures, and only by Men; who do not only continually assault them, and endeavour to corrupt and betray them, but they have enslaved them, and do often defame them with slanders and reproaches, vain glorious boasts, and lying brags; the truth is, Men are like Devils to Women, seeking whom they may devour; inticing, alluring, perswading and flattering Women, to the ruine of their Souls, Bodies, Minds, Fortunes, and good Names; but Women are beloved and favoured by the gods, who endue their Bodies with Beauty, and their Minds with Spiritual Grace, their Thoughts with Religious Zeal, and their Lives with Pious Devotions; which keeps their Bodies Chast, their Minds pure, and their Lives Vertuous: But those few Women that are Incontinent, are rather Beasts then Women; but most Women are Angelical; and though Men defame them, yet the Gods glorifie them.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Lady, if you speak any longer of the Female Subject, you will cast them from Heaven into Hell; for you cannot go beyond Heaven, Angels and Gods.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am content to speak no more of them at this time, but leave them in bliss.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Mimick, your Lady will be too hard for you.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes in Foolery, but not in Wit. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Adviser, and Monsieur Courtly.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Courtly.
sp.p: VVHere were you, that I did not see you all yesterday, nor most part of this day?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, I was all the Morning at a Sermon, and at Noon I went to a Tavern, in the Afternoon I went to a Play, and at night I went to a Common-house, and from thence I went to the Gaming-house, and there I stay'd till late in the Morning; and then I went home, and lay and slept so long, as I have but newly dined.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Dined, say you! why it is almost Supper-time.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Not with me.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: No; for you turn the Day into Night, and Night into Day.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I did not so yesterday.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, but you did; for you spent all the day in deeds of darkness.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Will you say, that hearing a Sermon is a deed of darkness?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes, unless you did profit by it, which I do not perceive you did; the truth is, by your after-actions you seem the worse for it.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I'le confess to you, my friend, that the Sermon made me so dull and melancholy, as I was forced to go to a Tavern, to revive and comfort my Mind with some Spiritual Liquor; and from thence I went to a Play to recreate my Thoughts, and to take them from all sad Contemplations, in seeing and hearing a merry Comedy acted; and the truth is, the Play made me so lively, as I became so wanton, that I was forced to go to a Common-house, and after I had convers'd with the VVoman, I was as dull and melancholy as I was after the Sermon; so then I went to the Gaming-house for diversion, knowing I should meet store of Company; and being there, I fell to play, where I lost all my Money; for which I was so troubled, as I wish my self dead, having not any Money left to live; and being moneyless, I went home to bed, that I might sleep and forget my loss for a time.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: But did not the thoughts of the loss hinder your sleep?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: No faith; for my thoughts were so opprest with grief, as they fell fast asleep, and so fast asleep they were, as I did not dream.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: But now they are awake, they remember your losses, do they not?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p:
Yes, but I will perswade you to go with me
to the Tavern, there to drink out the remembrance.
sp.l: For when my head is fill'd with Vaporous VVine,
My thoughts for Losses will not then repine.

div.stage: Enter Take-pleasure to Adviser and Courtly.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Tom, Thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Go hang your self, for you are not a Man of your word, for you promis'd to meet me at the Crown-Tavern, where I stay'd for you till twelve a Clock last night, expecting your coming.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: And how did you pass away the solitary time?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Faith, I call'd for some Tobacco, and a pint of VVine, and then I took a Pipe, then drunk a glass of Wine, and you did not come; then I took another Pipe, and drunk another glass of Wine, and you did not come; so I took Pipe after Pipe, and drunk Glass after Glass, until the Pint-pot was empty; then I call'd for another Pint, and another Pint, and drunk them as the first; and still you stay'd, and still I drunk so long as I was almost drunk, expecting your Company; but at last finding my Stomack full, and my head light, and the night far spent I went home and so to bed.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Without saying your Prayers?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Faith, I could not say my Prayers for Cursing of Courtly; but at last I fell asleep with a Curse in my mouth, which Curse I found in my mouth when I did awake in the morning.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Did you swallow the Curse down, or spit it out?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Faith, it had almost choak'd me; for it stuck so in my Throat, as I could neither get it up, nor down, but at last I spit it out, for it was as bitter as Gall.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You had no reason to curse me, if you were drunk; for the only design of our meeting at the Tavern, was but to be drunk.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: That is true; but there is no pleasure to be drunk without a Companion.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: The truth is, I could not come; for I was forced against my will to Sup with a Lady.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Faith, Women spoile all good fellowship; but I had been better Company for her last night, then you were.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Come, come, let us go to the same Tavern, and there end all Quarrels. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Facil, and Mimick.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Facil.
sp.p: MAster Mimick, I am come according to your appointment.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then Mr. Facil you may depart according to my appointment.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But you assured me, That if I came at this hour, I should have access to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But Women change their mind every minute, and are in threescore several minds or humors in an hour; and this minute the Lady is in a very angry humor, which will not agree with your amorous humor.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But I'le stay until her angry humor is past.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then you may stay until you be weary; for she will change out of one angry humor into another, until she hath run out an hour; for there be many several kinds and sorts of angry Humors.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But I will stay an hour.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But if you do, it is not likely that the Lady will be in a humor to entertain your Courtly address; for it is probable, as being most usual, that from the last angry humor, she will change into the first degree of a Melancholy humor.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Then I will attend two hours, until such time as she will be out of her Melancholy humor.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: That will not do you any service; for out of the last Melancholy humor she will change into a pious humor, and so from one pious humor into another, until such time as she comes to weep like a Mary Magdalen, and after floods of Tears she will fall fast asleep; her Sences and Spirits being tired with Kneeling, Praying, Sighing and Weeping, and after she awakes from her devout sleep, she may chance to bestow a Charity upon you.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I'le attend in hope of that Charity.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I perceive by you, that Lovers will take no excuses or denials; but yet this last I hope will drive you away, which is, The Lady has the Wind-collock; wherefore she will not admit of a visit, especially Amorous Suiters this day.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: By this I find that you have fill'd me with hope, to delude me.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Let me tell you, that Love is the greatest Deluder, or Cheater, especially Amorous Love; but to keep you from dispair, I'le promise you (for Promises keep Lovers alive) I will devise some way to corrupt this Lady to your desires, although it requires much labour, study, wit, and time, to corrupt Chastity; and since my Service will be great, my Reward must not be small.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Then here I give you Ten pounds to reward your Knavery.

div.stage: Exit Facil, Mimick Solus.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Why, this is right as it should be, for one Knave to Fee another, that Knavery may thrive.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Sir Mercury Poet, and the Lady Fancy.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Madam, I take it for a great favour and obligation, that you will receive my visit.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p:
It would be an Obligation to my self, to oblige a worthy person, such as I believe you are, but I do not perceive how I can merit thanks in receiving
your Visit, for I suppose you can better pass your time, then with my dull Company, and unprofitable Conversation.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: It is a particular favour, because you do not not usually receive Visits.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: The reason why I do not usually receive Visits, is out of a respect to the Visiters, knowing I have not Wit to entertain them, Speech to delight them, nor Learning to profit them; so they would but lose their time in visiting me; and I chuse rather to lofe the profit I might gain by hearing wise, witty, and learned Visiters; then they should lose their time by learning nothing themselves; for Wisdom and Wit desires to advance in Knowledg, and not to stand at a stay; for though prating Fools take pleasure to inform, and formal Fools to reform; yet wise Men delight to be informed and reformed, through a noble ambition to attain to perfecton.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which Perfection, Madam, you have arrived to.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: That is impossible, for Nature hath made Women so defective, as they are not capable of Perfection.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Madam, my Soul is wedded to your Vertue, and my Contemplations to your Fancy, and my Love and Person longs to be wedded to your Beauty and Chastity.

lg.l: And if our Wits agree,
I'm sure you'l favour me.
For Wit the Brain doth move,
And causes Souls to love:
For Fools cannot love well,
Nor reason for Love tell;
They understand not Merit,
Nor a Coelestial Spirit.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: How is that! Merit, Spirit, and I know not what! Daughter, I am come to forbid you the Company of Sir Mercury Poet, and that you receive not any of his Visits: And Sir Mercury Poet, I do forbid you my Daughters Company.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Sir, I have not visited your Daughter, without your leave; for you were pleased to invite me to wait on your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: 'Tis true, for I did believe, (by reason your Father and I being old acquaintance, and loving friends, and both being rich, and having Children, he a Son, and I a Daughter) it might be very proper and fit to have agreed to have matched you together; but since your Father and I having debated and considered well upon the Case, we find it no ways profitable for either.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Where is the disadvantage or hinderance?

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Your Wit.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Is Wit a Crime?

sp.speaker: Aged.
