sp.p: It ought to be made Criminal; for it is not only unprofitable, but ruinous; not any person thrives that has it; and it makes those that are rich, poor; and those that are poor, uncapable to be rich.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: They that have Wit, need no other wealth, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Longlife.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Mr. Longlife, I find now your words true, That Wit regards not Wealth; for your Son says, That Wit is Wealth enough of it self.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Mr. Aged; but he will find, Wit cannot buy Land, unless he joins Knavery to it.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: True Wit is always just, and honest, it knows no double dealing; and honour is the ground on which it builds a Fame.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: But if you have no other ground, nor other building, but Honour and Fame, you may beg for your livelihood, or starve for want of bread.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I had rather die for want of bread, then live without honourable Fame; and Fortune's goods are poor to those that Nature gives.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: O Mr. Aged, I am unhappy, undone; for I perceive my Posterity will be all Beggars: And therefore, if you will not change your Principles soon, I will disinherit you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You cannot, Sir; for though you may give away your Land, you cannot give away my Wit (if I have any.)

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: If I cannot, I will marry you to a Fool; so that though you be poor, your Children may be rich.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: If you please, Sir, and Mr. Aged consent, I desire I may Marry this Lady.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: No, no, Son she hath Wit, I know by her silence, otherwise her tongue would have run a race in this time.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: I can speak Sir, but I doubt I have not Wit to speak well.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Nay, if you talk of Wit, you are not for my Son.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: Your Son hath so much Wit, that what Woman soever he Marries, cannot continue a Fool long, for she will get Wit from him, and yet he will have no less, for Nature still supplies his store.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: But my Grand-Children may be Fools, if my Son's Wife be none of Natures witty Daughters.

sp.speaker: Fancy.
sp.p: His Children cannot be Fools; for Wit begets Wit, although a Fool should be the breeder.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Good Mr. Aged, lock up your Daughter, until I have sent my Son to Travel; for otherwise we shall ruin our Posterities. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Lady Amorous, Lady Vertue, and Madam Mediator.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: MAdam, what makes you so fine to day? and not only your person is finer, but your house is finer trim'd and trickt, then usually it was; have you a Servant to visit you to day?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: No, but I have a Master that is to come out of the Country to day.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Who is your Master?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: My Husband, who comes home to day.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Do you make your self and your house so fine only for your Husband?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Only for my Husband, say you! Why, he is the only Man that I desire to appear fine to; and the only person I desire to please and delight.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: But Husbands take no notice of the bravery of their Wives.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Howsoever, it is the part of every good wife to express, on all occasions, their Love and Respect to their Husbands; in their absence to mourn, at their return to rejoice, and in their Company to be best pleased.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Love, Respect and Duty, are only expressible in Humors, Words and Service, and not in Habit.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But Joy is exprest in habit, as much as mourning; witness Triumphs and Triumphant Shews; and Triumphs of Joy, and Funerals, are not alike.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: All Noble Persons are buried in Triumphs.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Indeed they are buried with Ceremony, but it is such Ceremony as expresses Dolor, not Joy; for they are followed with black Mourners, and weeping eyes: But however, I endeavour to appear to my Husband, at his returning home, like a gay and joyful Bride, and not as a sad mourning Widow.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Let me not live, Lady Vertue, if you be not the most simple Woman alive.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: First, That you can take pleasure in the dull Company of a Husband; next, That you do not delight your self with the Gallants of the Times; and thirdly, That you do not only spoile your own Husband, but all other VVomens Husbands, with your example; for which folly, you ought to be condemned by all our Sex.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: If they condemn me for my Vertue, I will despise them for their Vices.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: But Vice is a Vertue in this age; ask Madam Mediator else.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: VVhat say you, Madam Mediator?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p:
I say, that Vice was never so confident as it is now, nor never so glorified as it is now, nor
never so beloved as it is now, nor never so practised as it is now.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Well, since Vice is so beloved, and Vertue despised, I will go to a merry Meeting. Come, Madam Mediator, you'l make one, although Lady Vertue will not. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Facil, and Mimick.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: MOnsieur Facil, I have tired my Legs, and worn out the Soles of my Shooes to find you out, to give you a Letter from the Lady Amorous.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I am sorry you have taken such pains.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: You may requite my pains when you please; but here is the Letter.

div.stage: He receives the Letter.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Faithful Mimick! happy Facil! divine Lady! delicious Letter!

div.stage: He kisses the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: VVhat delicious pleasure do you receive in that Kiss, Monsieur Facil?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: As much pleasure as Joy can give me.
VVhat is this, a plain sheet of Paper! you Rogue, do you abuse and cozen me?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Did not you give me Ten pound to reward my Knavery? for which I should be ungrateful, should I not be a Knave to you; but yet you have no reason to be angry for this unletter'd Paper, which is the royall'st Kindness, and most generous Present, the Lady could send you; for she has sent you a blank to write down your own desires, demands, or condition of agreement, love and friendship.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: If it be so, I ask you Pardon, and will requite your fidelity with Gold.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I'le take your requital.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Pray go with me to my Lodgings, and there I'le write in this white Paper, that came from the whiter hands of my Mistress, my love and affections, and you shall guide it unto her.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: You must ballace the Letter with Gold, or otherwise it will be drown'd in the returning-Voyage.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I will. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Lady Amorous, and two or three other Ladies.

sp.speaker: First Lady.
sp.p: LAdy Amorous, Marriage has made you a boon Companion.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p:
I was a Novice before I married; but now
I find that there is no pleasure, like Liberty, Mirth and good Company.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: You say true, Lady, for a Stoical life is the worst life in the VVorld.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: But the Lady Vertue, and Sir W. Sage live the life of Stoicks.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: The more Fools they; but my Husband and I, live the life of Libertines; for he takes his pleasure, and I take mine: Have you sent for Mr. Courtly?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Yes, there are at least half a score Messengers sent one after another to invite him hither.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Courtly.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: O Sir! you're welcome, we were even now a wishing for you to go abroad with us.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I account my self happy, Ladies, that I am come according to your wishes, as also to do you service.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: We did send a dozen Messengers for you.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I did happily meet them, Madam.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: But whether shall we go?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Where you please, Lady; for I am ready at your service.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Let us go to the Great Park.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: No, let us go to the Fruit-Garden.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: No faith, upon better Consideration, let us stay and play at Cards.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: That is dull; rather let us send for Fidlers, and Dance.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: We have not Men enough to dance, and Mr. Courtly cannot dance with us all.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: I'le do my endeavour, Ladies.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: No, let us hire a Barge, and row upon the Water.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: No, let us go and Sup at the Tavern at the Bridg-foot; what say you, Mr. Courtly, will you entertain us?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes, Lady, as well as I can.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Let us go.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: No, let us first draw lots, and let Fortune decide the place of our Recreations.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Content; but which lot shall carry it?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: The long lot.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: The short lot.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: I say the long lot.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: Let the most Voices carry it.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Ladies, if I might perswade you, it should be at the Tavern at the Bridg-foot, and there you shall have the best Meat, Wine and Musick, that place affords.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Content, content.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Facil and Monsieur Adviser.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Adviser.
sp.p: FAcil, how do you prosper in Loves Adventures?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: More happily then I could imagine, for she receives my Letters, and returns me Answers.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Then you shall not need to despair, since you have such encouragement.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: No faith, for now I fear she will be kinder then I would have her; for she has consented to a private meeting.

div.stage: Enter Take-pleasure as in hast.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Whether away in such hast, Tom?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Faith, Courtly has sent his Footman to me in such hast, as the poor fellow is almost melted with the heat he has with running, to bring me a note from his Master, who writes to me, that of all love and friendship I should speedily come to him, and to bring half a dozen other Gentlemen with me to the Tavern, to help him to entertain a Company of Ladies, otherwise he shall die in their service; wherefore, prithee Adviser, and Facil, go with me thither.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Faith, we cannot, for we have other business.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: The same answer I have had from a dozen other Gentlemen, and cannot perswade any one to go; wherefore, I fear my friend Courtly will be over-power'd by those many Ladies.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why would Courtly engage himself to so many Women?

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Alas, he could not help it; for they sent so many Messengers to desire him to come to them, as he was almost smother'd in the croud, so that he was forced as it were, to go out in his own defence; but he finds that the Company of Ladies is worse then the number of Messengers, for he hath leaped out of the Frying-pan into the fire.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I confess Men can hardly avoid the Females, and are more tormented with them then Beggars are with Lice, or a Horse with Flies; for since the Wars, numbers of Women do swarm about one Man, as Bees about a honey-pot.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: I confess it, and I fear my Friend Courtly will be devoured; wherefore, for Charity, go with me, and help him in distress, and I'le engage that he and I will do the like for either, or both of you.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Upon that condition we are content; then let us go with all speed Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Mercury Poet to the Lady Fancy, whom He finds Weeping.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Sweet Mistress! let not our Parents folly Be a cause to make us Melancholy:

lg.l: For Natures, Fates, and mighty gods above
Did make, Decree, and cause our Souls to love;
Then do not mourn, or cloud your Eyes with Tears,
But banish from your Mind all Griefs and Fears;
For still our Loving Souls will constant be,
Coelestial powers have joyn'd in that Decree.

sp.speaker: L. Fancy.
sp.l: But at full Moon, the winds blow high,
And in the wain they silent lie.
So doth a Lover's full griev'd Mind
Cause storms of Passions, like as Wind,
Beating the Thoughts, like Clouds about,
Which being prest, Tears streameth out.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: But when that Grief is in the wain
The Mind is smooth, and calm again;
Thoughts are serene, Joy shineth clear;
The Eyes are fair, no Tears appear:
But if that you with me consent,
Our Parents follies we'l prevent
With holy Ceremony, bind so sure
In Sacred Marriage, shall for life endure.

sp.speaker: L. Fancy.
sp.l: I do consent to be your Wife.
For without you, I have no Life. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Sir William Sage, Lady Vertue, and Mimick.

sp.speaker: Sir William Sage.
sp.p: VVHat are you studying your Play?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes faith, I am getting some speeches by heart.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Let us hear some of them.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I cannot speak like a Woman in Breeches and Doublet, unless I have a Petticoat.

div.stage: Enter the Cook-maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, I come to know what shall be drest for Supper?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: My Lady will fast and pray to night; wherefore, lend me one of thy Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: What will you do with it?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I'le not eat thy Petticoat, though it would fry in its own grease, but I would use it another way.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: What other way?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Why, I will wear thy Petticoat over my Breeches.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No, by my Faith, but you shall not; for then my Petticoat and your Breeches may commit Fornication.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
It were better our Clothes should commit Fornication, then our Persons; but in my Conscience our Clothes will be honest; but it is probable, that the
Fleas in your Petticoat, and the Fleas in my Breeches may commit Fornication; and so our Clothes, or rather our selves will be guilty of another such like Vertue, as Fornication; which is, I shall be a Pimp, and you a Bawd for the Adulterous Fleas; but howsoever I must borrow thy Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Would you have me lend you my Petticoat, and stand my self naked?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: If you should, it would seem a deed of Charity, to give thy Petticoat from off thee, to those that want it; besides, you will appear like the Picture of Eve in her state of Innocence; and when I have done acting my part, of seeming a Woman, I will be like Adam; and so we shall be both like our first Parents.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I'le see you hang'd in an Apple-tree, before I lend you my Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Then I shall not need it, unless it be for a shroud to lap me in; but rather then you will see me hang'd, you will cut the cord or halter, although you were sure to damn your Soul for the deed; but if thou wilt lend me thy Petticoat, I will promise hereafter to be thy Champion Knight, armed with thy Kitchin-Vessels; thy Spit shall be my long Sword or Tuck, and thy Dripping-pan my Target, thy Porridg-pot my Head-piece, one of thy Pie-plates shall serve for a breast-plate, and a Buff-coat made of the smuddy skins of Gammons of Bacon.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Upon that condition, to see you so armed, I
will lend you my upper-Petticoat, if my Master and Lady will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Thou hast their leave; for I must act my part for them to see me; and I had rather wear thy upper-Coat, then thy under-Petticoat.

div.stage: She pulls off her Petticoat.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Joan, help him to put it on.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, I will put it on my self, for she will put it over my head, and I will put it under my feet, for I had rather my feet should go thorough her Petticoat, then my nose should be in her tayl, which will be, if I put her Petticoat over my head.

div.stage: She snatches her Petticoat away.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You jeering Fool, you shall not have my Petticoat to play the Fool with.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: You Slut, take your Coat again, for the smell makes me sick, and suffocates my breath.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You are a lying fellow, for saying my Petticoat stinks.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Prithee Joan, be pacified; for I confess, my smell is a foolish, nice, sickly smell; but for thy comfort, many right Honourable, and right noble Persons love the haut-goust of such Petticoats; but the perfume of thy Petticoat, has spoiled the part of my Play; for it hath put me quite out of the Amorous Speeches, I should have rehears'd.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p:
But it is not so proper for a Woman to speak Amorous Speeches, as for a Man; wherefore,
speak some Amorous Speeches to Joan, as a Man in your own Garments.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But my Speech was to be spoken in the absence of my Lover; complaining to the gods, and imploring their favours to assist me to the sight of my Love.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: That would have been rather as a Prayer, then an Amorous Speech.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, no, I would have order'd my Speech so as it should have been Amorous.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Then I perceive we shall hear none of your Play at this time.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I have parts to act as a Man; which is to address my self in a Courtly manner to some fine, fair, sweet, young Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Imagine Joan such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: My Imagination is not so powerful, as to Metamorphose Joan in my Thoughts to such a Lady; besides, Joan cannot answer a Man as she should.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You lie, you Rogue, for I have answer'd better men then thou art, or ever wilt be.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But can you talk Court-talks?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I know not what Court-talk is, but I can talk.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Stand forth here, and I will court thee as a Gallant doth his Mistress: Lady, your Beauty shines.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
That is, because I wash'd it with some of the Beef-broth, and wiped it with a greasie clout, I use to wipe the dishes; otherwise, the great hot shining fire i'th'
Kitchin would burn and parch it so dry, as it would be scurvy, or scabby.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Setting aside your basted, rosted face, I must tell you, it is not the Courtly manner to interrupt a Man in his speech; you must be silent until the end of the Speech, and then speak; but you spoke when I had not said above four words: hold your peace, and I'le begin again.

Lady, your Beauty shineth like a blazing-Star, whereon Men gaze, and in their Minds do wonder at the sight; but the effects are not alike; your Beauty strikes them not with fear, but Love; your frowns and smiles are Destiny and Fate, either to kill or cure.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: What Language is this, French or Dutch, or Welch, or Irish, or Scotch!

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, it is Greek and Hebrew.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Speak to me so, as I may understand you; otherwise, I cannot answer you.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Joan, thy face shines like a Sea-coal fire.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Why, doth it look red?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, thy Nose appears like a burning coal, rak'd over with black ashes, but all thy face else appears like the outside of a roasted Pig.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You are a roasted Ass, for saying my face appears like the outside of a roasted Pig; my face is a face of God's own making, and not a Pig's face.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, I know your face is a Sow's face; but I say the colour of your face is like the Coat of a roasted Pig.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My face is as good a face as your own, without any dispraise to the party.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Which party? the Fools party, or the Sluts party?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Well, for saying my face is like a Pig's Coat, i'faith when I roast a Pig again, you shall not have any part of it; and let me give you warning, you come not into the Kitchin; for if you do, I will fling a Ladle full of Drippings upon your Fools Coat.

div.stage: Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: O wo is me! I shall lose many a hot bit; but Master and Lady, this is your fault to make Joan and I fall out.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: We did not make you fall out.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: You commanded me to Court Joan, and she doth not understand Courtships in words; for Joan is used to be kiss'd, and not wooed; but I will go and promise Joan a kiss, although I never pay it her; for the more hungry she is, the better she'l feed me. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Facil, Monsieur Adviser, and Monsieur Take-pleasure.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Take-pleasure.
sp.p: FAcil, I am come to fetch thee to the Horn-Tavern, for there be a number of Good-fellows that want thy Company.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Stay, stay; I must go and make a Cuckold first.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Thou hast made a Hundred in thy time.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But I must go and make one to day; for I am going to meet a young beautiful Wife in private.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Put off thy Meeting until another time.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: That I cannot, I am so engaged; besides, she is a Lady of Honour.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Of Title you mean; for Ladies of Honour, or Honourable Ladies, do not use to have private Meetings with such wild deboist Men as thou art; and if she be a Wife, as you say she is, it will be no great honour for her Husband.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: You speak as if you were a Married Man, and were sensible of a Husbands disgrace.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: The truth is, I find I have a Commiseration and Compassion for Married Men.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But not when you are to lie with any of their Wives.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: I seldom make love to Married Wives; for they are not worth the trouble and danger which a Man must pass through before they can be enjoyed; besides, a Man loses a great deal of time in Wooing them, not but that they are as yielding, nay, more yielding then Maids; but they are more fearful to venture, lest their Husbands should know it.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p:
Faith, Maids are more troublesome and chargable then Wives; for they are apt to claim Marriage,
or to sue for maintenance at least; besides, their lying in, and Christening, breeding and bringing up of their Children, is an intollerable Charge; which charge is sav'd with Married Wives; and for their Husbands, they are contented to wink, not willing to see their disgraces, at least not to divulge them.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Not all; for some will look with more eyes then their own, setting spies to watch them.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Those are old-fashioned Husbands, and not Mode-Husbands.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Indeed, I observe, that Mode-Husbands do not love their Wives, unless other Men Court them; and if your Mistress's Husband is such a one, you shall not need to meet in private.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I think my Mistress's Husband is not so much of the French fashion, although my Mistress is Frenchified.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: What, has she the French Pox?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I hope not; for Ladies of her Quality have not that foul infectious Disease; but I mean my Mistress is in the French Fashion, not in the French Disease: But farwell, for I must be gone; otherwise, I shall slip my time.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Prithee go along with me.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p:
I'le leave you, my friend here; for my self I must go, otherwise I should prove my self a Fool, to lose the time I have spent in Wooing, the Money I have given in bribing, the Sleeps I have mist with watching,
the Protestations and Vows I have made in swearing, and my word that is past in promising, if I should not meet her and enjoy her; but when I am parted from her, I will come to you.

sp.speaker: Take-pleas.
sp.p: Well, I am content to spare thee so long; for I would not have thee a loser, although my faith tells me, you will not gain much: But remember the meeting at the Horn-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I shall not forget that sign of any sign; wherefore, doubt not of my Company. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Lady Vertue and Mimick.

sp.speaker: Lady Vertue.
sp.p: MImick, to my sight you appear dull, since you are Married!

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Faith, I do not find my self so lively as I was before I Married; for a Wife is a clog to a Man's heels, and a cloud in a Man's mind; but your Ladyship seems more lively since you were Married, then you did before.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The reason is, That a good Husband is a light to a Woman's life, a friend to a Woman's Vertue, and a Crown to a Woman's honour.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: And an ill Wife is a Horn to a Man's head, a Plague to a Man's life, and a death to a Man's wit.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed your Mimick-Wit seems dead since you Married; but yet my Maid Nan, whom you Married, is a good Wife.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Yes, when she is in a good humor.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let me advise you to return to your Mimick-humour, or I will tell your Wife, that you repent your Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: She may perceive that by my cold kindness; howsoever, I'le live like a Batchellor, although I am a Married Man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How can you do so?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Why, I will live Chast.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That will be well for Nan.

div.stage: Enter Sir William Sage.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Wife, I have invited some Strangers to dine with me to morrow; wherefore, I would have you dress your self fine to entertain them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you like me in plain Garments as well as in rich, I care not how Strangers like me.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I would have my Wife appear so handsome to Strangers, as they may approve of my Choice.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Some Men would be afraid if their Wives should be seen by Strangers, least they might like so well their Choice, as to chuse them for their Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But my Wife's Vertue makes me fearless of Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But Vertue is not proved, until it be tryed.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: True love is never inconstant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But true love is not known until it be tryed.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I fear not a trial.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But a trial of Chastity is scandalous; for Overberry in his Characters says, That he comes not near, that comes to be denied.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Then I will entertain the Strangers, and keep you in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I shall so.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Madam, my Master having Strangers to morrow, pray let me add one dish to the Feast.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: VVhat Dish is that, a dress'd Lady?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No; for my skill in Physick doth plainly prove, that Ladies are unwholsome meat, they will give a Man a Surfeit; besides, they are not tastable, unless they be very tender and young; also, they are very chargable in dressing, they require so many Ingrediences and garnishings to set them off, and so much sauce to make them relish well, as would undo a poor Man; besides, much art is required in the Dressing: So all considered, they are not worth the charge, labour and time, being but a faint, weak and sickly meat at the best, but I have thought of other meat, which will be tastable meat to a great Monarch.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: VVhat meat is that?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: An Hodge-podge.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: It seems it is for a Dutch Monarch; but let us know how you will make it?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
First, I will take VVidows dissembling
Tears, Maids dissembling Modesty, VVives dissembling Chastity, Curtisans dissembling Virginity, Puritanical Sisters dissembling Piety, Autumnal Ladies dissembling Beauty; and mixing all these Ingrediences together, I will put them into a Mystical pot, and set it on a heatless fiery Meteor a stewing, and after it has stew'd some time, I'le put these Ingrediences to them, The Pride of Favourites, the Vanity of Courtiers, the Jugling of Statesmen, the Fears of Cowards, the mischiefs of Tumults, the Extortion of Magistrates, the Covetousness of Usurers, the Retards of Judges, the Quirks of Lawyers, the Opiniateness of Schollars, the Jealousie of Lovers, the Deceit of Tradesmen, the Brags of Soldiers, the Oaths of Gamesters, the Prodigality of young Heirs, the Diseases of Drunkards, the Surfeits of Gluttons, and the dishonour of Cuckolds; Likewise, I will put in a Fool's Brain, a Liers Tongue, a Traiterous Heart, and a Thieves Hand; VVith which I'le stir all together, and after they have been well stew'd and stir'd together, I'le take this Hodg-podg and put it into a large dish of Infamy, and garnish it with the dotgae of Age, the follies of Youth, the superstition of Idolaters, and the expectation of Chymists, and then serve it up to Pluto's Table.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
For once I will try my Huswifry to Cook a dish of meat, which shall be a Bisk: First, I will take the Truth of Religion, the Piety of Saints, the Chastity of Nunns, the Purity of Virginity, the Constancy of
true Love, the Unity of Friendship, the Innocency of Infants, the Wit of Poets, the Eloquence of Orators, the Learning of Scholars, the Valour of Soldiers, the Knowledg of Travellers, and Time's Experience; And put all these into a pot of Renown, and set it on a Coelestial fire a stewing; after it has stew'd some time, I'le put in these Ingredients, Wholsome Temperance, strengthning Fortitude, comfortable Justice, and savory Prudence; also, I'le add the bowels of Compassion, the Heart of Honesty, the Brain of Wisdom, the Tongue of Truth, and the Hand of Generosity; and stir them well together, then I'le take them off, and put them into a dish of Happiness, and garnish it with the Plenty of Prosperity, the Ease of Rest, the Delight of Beauty, and the Tranquillity of Peace, and so serve it up to Jove's Table. Thus I am a Cook-maid for the gods; but you are a Cook-man for the Devil, and all the meat you Cook, is burnt.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p:
I confess, Hell's fire is great and scorching, and Hell's Kitchin is very hot; but howsoever, my Master the Devil loves his meat thoroughly roasted, and tenderly stew'd; but your Master Jove loves all his meat cold and raw; for there is not any fire in Heaven, and that is the reason you chuse to be a Servant to the gods; because you would not burn your face, lest it should spoile your Complexion; for Ladies are more careful of their Faces then their Souls; besides, the cool and temperate air, and the cold diet of the gods,
which breeds flegm, makes them patient; whereas, the Devil is dwelling in a Torrid Region, and eating dry roasted meat, which breeds Choller, makes him furious; in so much, as he tortures his Servants with grievous pains.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why do you serve him then?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Because, he gives great wages; I serve him for necessity, but some serve him for worldly honour, and some for worldly wealth, and some for worldly power, and some for one thing, and some for another; for none serves him for love, neither do the Servants of the gods serve them for love but for some reward.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: Let me perswade you to change your Service.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: So I will, when I am old, and can serve the Devil no longer, then I will leave his Service, and serve the gods.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: But the gods will not then accept of your Service.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: But they will; for the gods refuse not any that offer their service; The truth is, the gods cannot get Servants enough to serve them, so as they are forced to take any that will but serve them; for the gods have but the Devils leavings and refusals, as those that are so old as to be past sin; or so sickly, as they cannot act sin; or those that are so young, as not to know sin; for most of the gods Servants are aged and weak persons, or young Children.

sp.speaker: Sir W. Sage.
sp.p: I perceive you will wear out sin, before you serve the gods.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: No, sin shall wear out me, before I serve them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are a sinful Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: All Mankind is so, more or less, even your Lordship; the gods bless you, and have mercy upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, to punish you for your Sins, you shall eat no other meat but what your Poetical Fancy dresses.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I shall be starved then. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Courtly, and Monsieur Adviser.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Adviser.
sp.p: COurtly! 'tis strange to see you in this humour, as dying for the love of one Woman, when as I thought you had taken a surfeit of all Womenkind!

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I have Courted some Women, and many Women have Courted me; but I did never truly love any Woman but this Woman, which I cannot enjoy.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Have you no hopes to linger your life a little time longer?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Faith, I believe my life will continue, but my hopes are buried in despair.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: If you had but the opportunity to Court this Lady, you are so madly in love with, at any time, I am confident you may gain her good will; for Women are as various in their denials and consentings to their Lovers, as they are in their fashions and garments; for they will love and hate, and hate and love one and the same, many several times; as now love, then hate, now hate, then love; for Ladies affections change like the Seasons, or the Weather, as sometimes hot, and sometimes cold, and sometimes luke-warm.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: The affections of the Lady I love, are at all times cold, even to numness; for she is insensible towards me, and to all Lovers else, for any thing I can perceive.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Is she such a frozen Lady?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes faith; for I think she is composed of Ice, or a statue made of Snow.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: If she be composed of Ice or Snow, I dare assure you, she may be melted.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why, be you in the Torrid Zone of Mode, in Speech, Behaviour and Accoustrements, and let your Garments be so rich, as to shine in Gold and Silver, whose glistering rayes will cast a glorious splendor; then address your self in Poetical flames, and being a hot Lover, you will thaw her into your arms, and melt her unto your desire: Thus a Western Lover, and a Northern Lady may meet in Conjunction together.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: But cold Chastity has congealed and cry-stallined this Lady, in so much, as the hottest Lover with all his Poetical flames, and splenderous rayes of Youth, Beauty, Title, Wealth or Bravery, has not power to change or alter her worth and honour; for like a durable Diamond she is, and will remain.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: Who is the Owner of this rich Jewel?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir W. Sage, who is a wise, valiant man, and will not part from her, nor suffer any Man to take her from him; for he wears her in his heart, and she is the delight of his Life, and the Crown of his Honour, in which he takes more Glory, pride and pleasure, then to be Crowned Emperor of the whole VVorld.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: He hath reason; for a Man may sooner conquer the VVorld, then find such another Chast VVoman as she is.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: VVell, since I cannot obtain my desire, I will travel.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: That is the best for you to do, for so you may tire out Love.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Or Love tire out me.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, you are tir'd out of Courtship, and if you can tire out Love, you will do well; but before you go to Travel, you must go to a dancing-meeting of Ladies and Gentlemen. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Longlife, and Aged.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p:
Mr. Longlife, I am come to tell you, That your Son Mercury hath stoln away my Daughter
Fancy, and as I hear, they are gone to Apollo's Church to be Married.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Mr. Aged, I am sorry for it, and wish he had stoln a Challenge, when he stole your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: And I wish my Daughter had Married an Ass, rather then Marry your Son.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Well, if they be Married, as sure they are, if they have any Children we will endeavour to breed them Fools.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: We will so.

div.stage: Enter the Married Couple: They kneel down.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: We desire your Blessing.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Well, since you are Married, God bless you; But Son and Daughter in Law, I desire and command you in the name of a Father, that you will leave Versifying, Rhyming, Similizing, and the like, but study the Politicks, and that will abate your Wit.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: They may study Virgils Georgicks, for that treats of good Husbandry.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Yes, brother Aged, but it is in Verse, and whatsoever they get in Husbandry, they will lose by the Rhyme.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: By the Mass you say true, Brother Longlife.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Well Brother, although they have Married against our consent, yet we will celebrate their Marriage with Feasting, Mirth, and Musick.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Musick Sir, is a part of Poetry, and belongs to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but not such Musick as we will have, two or three Scraping Fidlers, that plays neither tune nor time.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Fancy as a Bride, and Sir Mercury Poet as Bridegroom; and all the Ladies and Gentlemen that were Guests at the first Wedding.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Brother Longlife, we are not for these active sports, our dancing-days are done.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: You say true, brother Aged; but in our younger years we were as agil as the best of them all.

div.stage: A young Lady takes out Longlife to dance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, although you be old, you may walk a grave measure, as a Paven.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: Say you so, my Girl; and i'faith I will try what my old legs will do; here brother Aged you shall hold my staff whil'st I dance.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: Nay, b'r'lady, your staff brother Longlife will help to prop up your weakness; and since a young Lady hath chose you to dance with, I will chuse out a Lady to dance with me; but the Musicians must play slow, or we shall not keep time; wherefore, Musicians let not your Fiddles go faster then our Legs, nor your Tunes to be younger then our years, but an old Paven.

stage.hi: The Old Men dance with two Young Ladies, they dance softly, but right, and keep time.

div.stage: The Young Men smile.

sp.speaker: Aged.
sp.p: You young Men smile, but we could have danced as nimbly as you can now.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You will teach us a sober pace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Longl.
sp.p: No Son, Time must teach you that, to which we will leave you, and my Brother and I will rest our Legs whil'st you tire your Legs: Come brother Aged, let us leave them to their Mirth, Musick, and Youth.

list.item:
Bridemen.
Monsieur Take-pleasure,
Monsieur Adviser,
Monsieur Facil.
Monsieur Courtly.
Sir Mercury Poet, and the Lady Fancy his Bride.
Sir William Sage, and the Lady Vertue his Bride.
Sir John Amorous, and the Lady Coy his Bride.

div.head: THE Convent of Pleasure. A COMEDY.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: First Gentleman.
sp.p: TOM, Where have you been, you look so sadly of it?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I have been at the Funeral of the Lord Fortunate; who has left his Daughter, the Lady Happy, very rich, having no other Daughter but her.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: If she be so rich, it will make us all Young Men, spend all our Wealth in fine Clothes, Coaches, and Lackies, to set out our Wooing hopes.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: If all her Wooers be younger Brothers, as most of us Gallants are, we shall undo our selves upon bare hopes, without Probability: But is she handsome, Tom?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Yes, she is extream handsome, young, rich, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Faith, that is too much for one Woman to possess.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Not, if you were to have her.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: No, not for me; but in my Opinion too much for any other Man. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Happy, and one of her Attendants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: MAdam, you being young, handsome, rich, and virtuous, I hope you will not cast away those gifts of Nature, Fortune, and Heaven, upon a Person which cannot merit you?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Let me tell you, that Riches ought to be bestowed on such as are poor, and want means to maintain themselves; and Youth, on those that are old; Beauty, on those that are ill-favoured; and Virtue, on those that are vicious: So that if I should place my gifts rightly, I must Marry one that's poor, old, ill-favoured, and debauch'd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven doth not only allow of it, but commands it; for we are commanded to give to those that want.

div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator to the Lady Happy.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: Surely, Madam, you do but talk, and intend not to go where you say.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Yes, truly, my Words and Intentions go even together.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: But surely you will not incloyster your self, as you say.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Why, what is there in the publick World that should invite me to live in it?

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: More then if you should banish your self from it.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p:
Put the case I should Marry the best of Men, if any best there be; yet would a Marry'd life have more crosses and sorrows then pleasure, freedom, or happiness: nay Marriage to those that are virtuous is a greater restraint then a Monastery. Or, should I take delight in Admirers? they might gaze on my Beauty, and praise my Wit, and I receive nothing from their eyes, nor lips; for Words vanish as soon as spoken, and Sights are not substantial. Besides, I should lose more of my Reputation by their Visits, then gain by their Praises. Or, should I quit Reputation and turn Courtizan, there would be more lost in my Health, then gained by my Lovers, I should find more pain then
Pleasure; besides, the troubles and frights I should be put to, with the Quarrels and Brouilleries that Jealous Rivals make, would be a torment to me; and 'tis only for the sake of Men, when Women retire not: And since there is so much folly, vanity and falshood in Men, why should Women trouble and vex themselves for their sake; for retiredness bars the life from nothing else but Men.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: O yes, for those that incloister themselves, bar themselves from all other worldly Pleasures.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: The more Fools they.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: Will you call those Fools that do it for the gods sake?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p:
No Madam, it is not for the gods sake, but for opinion's sake; for, Can any Rational Creature think or believe, the gods take delight in the Creature's uneasie life? or, Did they command or give leave to Nature to make Senses for no use; or to cross, vex and pain them? for, What profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men or Women wear coarse Linnen or rough Woollen, or to flea their skin with Hair-cloth, or to eat or sawe thorow their flesh with Cords? or, What profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men eat more Fish then Flesh, or to fast? unless the gods did feed on such meat themselves; for then, for fear the gods should want it, it were fit for Men to abstein from it: The like for Garments, for fear the gods should want fine Clothes to adorn themselves, it
were fit Men should not wear them: Or, what profit or pleasure can it be to the gods to have Men to lie uneasily on the hard ground, unless the gods and Nature were at variance, strife and wars; as if what is displeasing unto Nature, were pleasing to the gods, and to be enemies to her, were to be friends to them.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: But being done for the gods sake, it makes that which in Nature seems to be bad, in Divinity to be good.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: It cannot be good, if it be neither pleasure, nor profit to the gods; neither do Men any thing for the gods but their own sake.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: But when the Mind is not imployed with Vanities, nor the Senses with Luxury; the Mind is more free, to offer its Adorations, Prayers and Praises to the gods.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p:
I believe, the gods are better pleased with Praises then Fasting; but when the Senses are dull'd with abstinency, the Body weakned with fasting, the Spirits tir'd with watching, the Life made uneasie with pain, the Soul can have but little will to worship: only the Imagination doth frighten it into active zeal, which devotion is rather forced then voluntary; so that their prayers rather flow out of their mouth, then spring from their heart, like rain-water that runs thorow Gutters, or like Water that's forced up a Hill by Artificial Pipes and Cisterns. But those that pray not unto the gods, or praise them more in prosperity then
adversity, more in pleasures then pains, more in liberty then restraint, deserve neither the happiness of ease, peace, freedom, plenty and tranquillity in this World, nor the glory and blessedness of the next. And if the gods should take pleasure in nothing but in the torments of their Creatures, and would not prefer those prayers that are offer'd with ease and delight, I should believe, the gods were cruel: and, What Creature that had reason or rational understanding, would serve cruel Masters, when they might serve a kind Mistress, or would forsake the service of their kind Mistress, to serve cruel Masters? Wherefore, if the gods be cruel, I will serve Nature; but the gods are bountiful, and give all, that's good, and bid us freely please our selves in that which is best for us: and that is best, what is most temperately used, and longest may be enjoyed, for excess doth wast it self, and all it feeds upon.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: In my opinion your Doctrine, and your Intention do not agree together.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: You intend to live incloister'd and retired from the World.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but not from pleasures; for, I intend to incloister my self from the World, to enjoy pleasure, and not to bury my self from it; but to incloister my self from the incumbred cares and vexations, troubles and perturbance of the World.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: But if you incloister your self, How will you enjoy the company of Men, whose conversation is thought the greatest Pleasure?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Men are the only troublers of Women; for they only cross and oppose their sweet delights, and peaceable life; they cause their pains, but not their pleasures. Wherefore those Women that are poor, and have not means to buy delights, and maintain pleasures, are only fit for Men; for having not means to please themselves, they must serve only to please others; but those Women, where Fortune, Nature, and the gods are joined to make them happy, were mad to live with Men, who make the Female sex their slaves; but I will not be so inslaved, but will live retired from their Company. Wherefore, in order thereto, I will take so many Noble Persons of my own Sex, as my Estate will plentifully maintain, such whose Births are greater then their Fortunes, and are resolv'd to live a single life, and vow Virginity: with these I mean to live incloister'd with all the delights and pleasures that are allowable and lawful; My Cloister shall not be a Cloister of restraint, but a place for freedom, not to vex the Senses but to please them.

lg.l: For every Sense shall pleasure take,
And all our Lives shall merry make:
Our Minds in full delight shall joy,
Not vex'd with every idle Toy:
Each Season shall our Caterers be,
To search the Land, and Fish the Sea;
To gather Fruit and reap the Corn,
That's brought to us in Plenty's Horn;
With which we'l feast and please our tast,
But not luxurious make a wast.
Wee'l Cloth our selves with softest Silk,
And Linnen fine as white as milk.
Wee'l please our Sight with Pictures rare;
Our Nostrils with perfumed Air.
Our Ears with sweet melodious Sound,
Whose Substance can be no where found;
Our Tast with sweet delicious Meat,
And savory Sauces we will eat:
Variety each Sense shall feed,
And Change in them new Appetites breed.
Thus will in Pleasure's Convent I
Live with delight, and with it die.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Take-pleasure, and his Man Dick.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Take-pleasure.
sp.p: DIck, Am I fine to day?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, as fine as Feathers, Ribbons, Gold, and Silver can make you.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Dost thou think I shall get the Lady Happy?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Not if it be her fortune to continue in that name.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Because if she Marry your Worship she must change her Name; for the Wife takes the Name of her Husband, and quits her own.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Faith, Dick, if I had her wealth I should be Happy.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: It would be according as your Worship would use it; but, on my conscience, you would be more happy with the Ladies Wealth, then the Lady would be with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Why should you think so?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Because Women never think themselves happy in Marriage.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: You are mistaken; for Women never think themselves happpy until they be Married.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p:
The truth is, Sir, that Women are always unhappy in their thoughts, both before and after
Marriage; for, before Marriage they think themselves unhappy for want of a Husband; and after they are Married, they think themselves unhappy for having a Husband.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Indeed VVomens thoughts are restless.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Facil, and Monsieur Adviser, to Monsieur Take-pleasure; all in their Wooing Accoustrements.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I perceive you are all prepared to Woo.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Yes faith, we are all prepared to be Wooers. But whom shall we get to present us to the Lady Happy?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: We must set on bold faces, and present our selves.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Faith, I would not give my hopes for an indifferent portion.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: The truth is, We are all stuft with Hopes, as Cushions are with Feathers.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Courtly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: O Gentlemen, Gentlemen, we are all utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why, the Lady Happy hath incloister'd her self, with twenty Ladies more.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: The Devil she hath?

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: The gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Whether it was the devil or the gods that have perswaded her to it, I cannot tell; but gone in she is.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: I hope it is but a blast of Devotion, which will soon flame out.

div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: O Madam Mediator, we are all undone, the Lady Happy is incloister'd.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: Yes, Gentlemen, the more is the pitty.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Is there no hopes?

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: Faith, little.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Let us fee the Clergy to perswade her out, for the good of the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: Alas Gentlemen! they can do no good, for she is not a Votress to the gods but to Nature.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If she be a Votress to Nature, you are the only Person fit to be Lady Prioress; and so by your power and authority you may give us leave to visit your Nuns sometimes.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p:
Not but at a Grate, unless in time of Building, or when they are sick; but howsoever, the Lady Happy is Lady-Prioress her self, and will admit none of the Masculine Sex, not so much as to a Grate, for she will suffer no grates about the Cloister; she has also Women-Physicians, Surgeons and Apothecaries, and she is the chief Confessor her self, and
gives what Indulgences or Absolutions she pleaseth: Also, her House, where she hath made her Convent, is so big and convenient, and so strong, as it needs no addition or repair: Besides, she has so much compass of ground within her walls, as there is not only room and place enough for Gardens, Orchards, Walks, Groves, Bowers, Arbours, Ponds, Fountains, Springs and the like; but also conveniency for much Provision, and hath Women for every Office and Employment: for though she hath not above twenty Ladies with her, yet she hath a numerous Company of Female Servants, so as there is no occasion for Men.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: If there be so many Women, there will be the more use for Men: But pray Madam Mediator, give me leave, rightly to understand you, by being more clearly informed: you say, The Lady Happy is become a Votress to Nature; and if she be a Votress to Nature, she must be a Mistress to Men.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, she declares, That she hath avoided the company of Men, by retirement, meerly, because she would enjoy the variety of Pleasures, which are in Nature; of which, she says, Men are Obstructers; for, instead of increasing Pleasure, they produce Pain; and, instead of giving Content, they increase Trouble; instead of making the Femal-Sex Happy, they make them Miserable; for which, she hath banished the Masculine Company for ever.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p:
Her Heretical Opinions ought not to be
suffer'd, nor her Doctrine allow'd; and she ought to be examined by a Masculine Synod, and punish'd with a severe Husband, or tortured with a deboist Husband.

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: The best way, Gentlemen, is to make your Complaints, and put up a Petition to the State, with your desires for a Redress.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Your Counsel is good.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: We will follow it, and go presently about it. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Happy, with her Ladies; as also Madam Mediator.

sp.speaker: Lady Happy.
sp.p: LAdies, give me leave to desire your Confession, whether or no you repent your Retirement.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Most excellent Lady, it were as probable a repentance could be in Heaven amongst Angels as amongst us.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Now Madam Mediator, let me ask you, Do you condemn my act of Retirement?

sp.speaker: Mediat.
sp.p: I approve of it with admiration and wonder, that one that is so young should be so wise.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p:
Now give me leave to inform you, how I have order'd this our Convent of Pleasure; first, I
have such things as are for our Ease and Conveniency; next for Pleasure, and Delight; as I have change of Furniture, for my house; according to the four Seasons of the year, especially our Chambers: As in the Spring, our Chambers are hung with Silk-Damask, and all other things suitable to it; and a great Looking-Glass in each Chamber, that we may view our selves and take pleasure in our own Beauties, whilst they are fresh and young; also, I have in each Chamber a Cup-board of such plate, as is useful, and whatsoever is to be used is there ready to be imployed; also, I have all the Floor strew'd with sweet Flowers: In the Summer I have all our Chambers hung with Taffety, and all other things suitable to it, and a Cup-board of Purseline, and of Plate, and all the Floore strew'd every day with green Rushes or Leaves, and Cisterns placed neer our Beds-heads, wherein Water may run out of small Pipes made for that purpose: To invite repose in the Autumn, all our Chambers are hung with Gilt Leather, or Franchipane; also, Beds and all other things suitable; and the Rooms Matted with very fine Mats: In the Winter our Chambers must be hung with Tapestry, and our Beds of Velvet, lined with Sattin, and all things suitable to it, and all the Floor spread over with Turkie Carpets, and a Cup-board of Gilt Plate; and all the Wood for Firing to be Cypress and Juniper; and all the Lights to be Perfumed Wax; also, the Bedding and Pillows are ordered according
to each Season; viz. to be stuft with Feathers in the Spring and Autumn, and with Down in the Winter, but in the Summer to be only Quilts, either of Silk, or fine Holland; and our Sheets, Pillows, Table-Clothes and Towels, to be of pure fine Holland, and every day clean; also, the Rooms we eat in, and the Vessels we feed withal, I have according to each Season; and the Linnen we use to our Meat, to be pure fine Diaper, and Damask, and to change it fresh every course of Meat: As for our Galleries, Stair-Cases, and Passages, they shall be hung with various Pictures; and, all along the Wall of our Gallery, as long as the Summer lasts, do stand, upon Pedestals, Flower-pots, with various Flowers; and in the Winter Orange-Trees: and my Gardens to be kept curiously, and flourish, in every Season of all sorts of Flowers, sweet Herbs and Fruits, and kept so as not to have a Weed in it, and all the Groves, Wildernesses, Bowers and Arbours pruned, and kept free from dead Boughs Branches or Leaves; and all the Ponds, Rivolets, Fountains, and Springs, kept clear, pure and fresh: Also, we will have the choisest Meats every Season doth afford, and that every day our Meat, be drest several ways, and our drink cooler or hotter according to the several Seasons; and all our Drinks fresh and pleasing: Change of Garments are also provided, of the newest fashions for every Season, and rich Trimming; so as we may be accoutred properly,
and according to our several pastimes: and our Shifts shall be of the finest and purest Linnen that can be bought or spun.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: None in this World can be happier.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Now Ladies, let us go to our several Pastimes, if you please. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: MAdam, how do you, since you were Married?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: I am not so well as I wish I were.

div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator to them.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Ladies, do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: What News?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Why there is a great Foreign Princess arrived, hearing of the famous Convent of Pleasure, to be one of Nature's Devotes.

sp.speaker: L. Amor.
sp.p: What manner of Lady is she?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: She is a Princely brave Woman truly, of a Masculine Presence.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But, Madam Mediator, Do they live in such Pleasure as you say? for they'l admit you, a Widow, although not us, by reason we are Wives.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p:
In so much Pleasure, as Nature never
knew, before this Convent was: and for my part, I had rather be one in the Convent of Pleasure, then Emperess of the whole World; for every Lady there enjoyeth as much Pleasure as any absolute Monarch can do, without the Troubles and Cares, that wait on Royalty; besides, none can enjoy those Pleasures They have, unless they live such a retired or retreated life free from the Worlds vexations.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: Well, I wish I might see and know, what Pleasures they enjoy.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: If you were there, you could not know all their Pleasure in a short time, for their Varieties will require a long time to know their several Changes; besides, their Pleasures and Delights vary with the Seasons; so that what with the several Seasons, and the Varieties of every Season, it will take up a whole life's time.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But I could judg of their Changes by their single Principles.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: But they have Variety of one and the same kind.

sp.speaker: L. Vertue.
sp.p: But I should see the way or manner of them.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: That you might. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Adviser, Courtly, Take-pleasure, and Facil.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Courtly.
sp.p: IS there no hopes to get those Ladies out of their Convent?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: No faith, unless we could set the Convent on fire.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: For Jupiter's sake, let us do it, let's every one carry a Fire-brand to fire it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, and smoak them out, as they do a Swarm of Bees.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Let's go presently about it.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Stay, there is a great Princess there.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but when that Princess is gone, we will surely do it.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Yes, and be punish'd for our Villany.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: It will not prove Villany, for we shall do Nature good service.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why, so we do Nature good service, when we get a Wench with Child, but yet the Civil Laws do punish us for it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: They are not Civil Laws that punish Lovers.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: But those are Civil Laws that punish Adulterers.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Those are Barbarous Laws that make Love Adultery.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: No, Those are Barbarous that make Adultery Love.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Well, leaving Love and Adultery, They are foolish Women that vex us with their Retirement.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, although we rail at the Lady Happy for Retiring, yet if I had such an Estate as she, and would follow her Example; I make no doubt but you would all be content to encloister your selves with me upon the same conditions, as those Ladies incloister themselves with her.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Not unless you had Women in your Convent.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: Nay, faith, since Women can quit the pleasure of Men, we Men may well quit the trouble of Women.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But is there no place where we may peak into the Convent?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: No, there are no Grates, but Brick and Stone-walls.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Let us get out some of the Bricks or Stones.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Alas! the Walls are a Yard-thick.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: But nothing is difficult to Willing-minds.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: My Mind is willing; but my Reason tells me, It is impossible; wherefore, I'le never go about it.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p:
Faith, let us resolve to put our selves in
Womens apparel, and so by that means get into the Convent.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: We shall be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: Who will discover Us?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: We shall discover our Selves.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: We are not such fools as to betray our Selves.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: VVe cannot avoid it, for, our very Garb and Behaviour; besides, our Voices will discover us: for we are as untoward to make Courtsies in Petticoats, as VVomen are to make Legs in Breeches; and it will be as great a difficulty to raise our Voices to a Treble-sound, as for VVomen to press down their Voices to a Base; besides, VVe shall never frame our Eyes and Mouths to such coy, dissembling looks, and pritty simpering Mopes and Smiles, as they do.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But we will go as strong lusty Country-VVenches, that desire to serve them in Inferiour Places, and Offices, as Cook-maids, Landry-maids, Dairy-maids, and the like.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: I do verily believe, I could make an indifferent Cook-maid, but not a Laundry, nor a Dairy-maid; for I cannot milk Cows, nor starch Gorgets, but I think I could make a pretty shift, to wash some of the Ladies Night-Linnen.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p:
But they imploy Women in all Places in their Gardens; and for Brewing, Baking and making all sorts of things; besides, some keep their Swine, and
twenty such like Offices and Employments there are which we should be very proper for.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: O yes, for keeping of Swine belongs to Men; remember the Prodigal Son.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Faith, for our Prodigality we might be all Swin-heards.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Also we shall be proper for Gardens, for we can dig, and set, and sow.

sp.speaker: Takepl.
sp.p: And we are proper for Brewing.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: We are more proper for Drinking, for I can drink good Beer, or Ale, when 'tis Brew'd; but I could not brew such Beer, or Ale, as any man could drink.

sp.speaker: Facil.
sp.p: Come, come, we shall make a shift one way or other: Besides, we shall be very willing to learn, and be very diligent in our Services, which will give good and great content; wherefore, let us go and put these designes into execution.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Content, content.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Nay, faith, let us not trouble our Selves for it, 'tis in vain. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter the Princess, and the Lady Happy, with the rest of the Ladies belonging to the Convent.

sp.speaker: Lady Happy.
sp.p: MAdam, Your Highness has done me much Honour, to come from a Splendid Court to a retired Convent.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Sweet Lady Happy, there are many, that have quit their Crowns and Power, for a Cloister of Restraint; then well may I quit a Court of troubles for a Convent of Pleasure: but the greatest pleasure I could receive, were, To have your Friendship.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: I should be ungrateful, should I not be not only your Friend, but humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I desire you would be my Mistress, and I your Servant; and upon this agreement of Friendship I desire you will grant me one Request.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Any thing that is in my power to grant.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why then, I observing in your several Recreations, some of your Ladies do accoustre Themselves in Masculine-Habits, and act Lovers-parts; I desire you will give me leave to be sometimes so accoustred and act the part of your loving Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: I shall never desire to have any other loving Servant then your Self.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Nor I any other loving Mistress then Your-Self.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: More innocent Lovers never can there be, Then my most Princely Lover, that's a She.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Nor never Convent did such pleasures give, Where Lovers with their Mistresses may live.

div.stage: Enter a Lady, asking whether they will see the Play.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: May it please your Highness, the Play is ready to be Acted.

div.stage: The Scene is opened, the Princess and L. Happy sit down, and the Play is Acted within the Scene; the Princess and the L. Happy being Spectators.
Enter one drest like a Man that speaks the Prologue.
div.l: Noble Spectators, you shall see to night
A Play, which though't be dull, yet's short to sight;
For, since we cannot please your Ears with Wit,
We will not tyre your limbs, long here to sit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Two mean Women.

sp.speaker: First Woman.
sp.p: O Neighbour well met, where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: I have been with my Neighbour the Cobler's Wife to comfort her for the loss of her Husband, who is run away with Goody Mettle the Tinker's Wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: I would to Heaven my Husband would run away with Goody Shred the Botcher's Wife, for he lies all day drinking in an Ale-house, like a drunken Rogue as he is, and when he comes home, he beats me all black and blew, when I and my Children are almost starved for want.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: Truly Neighbour, so doth my Husband; and spends not only what he gets, but what I earn with the sweat of my brows, the whilst my Children cry for bread, and he drinks that away, that should feed my small Children, which are too young to work for themselves.

sp.speaker: 1. Woman.
sp.p: But I will go, and pull my Husband out of the Ale-house, or I'le break their Lattice-windows down.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: Come, I'le go and help; for my Husband is there too: but we shall be both beaten by them.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p:
I care not: for I will not suffer him to be
drunk, and I and my Children starve; I had better be dead. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter a Lady and her Maid.

sp.speaker: LAdy.
sp.p: Oh, I am sick!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You are breeding a Child, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have not one minutes time of health. Ex.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Two Ladies.

sp.speaker: First Lady.
sp.p: WHy weep you, Madam?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Have I not cause to weep when my Husband hath play'd all his Estate away at Dice and Cards, even to the Clothes on his back?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: I have as much cause to weep then as you; for, though my Husband hath not lost his Estate at play, yet he hath spent it amongst his Whores; and is not content to keep Whores abroad, but in my house, under my roof, and they must rule as chief Mistresses.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p:
But my Husband hath not only lost his own Estate, but also my Portion; and hath forced me with threats, to yield up my Jointure, so that I
must beg for my living, for any thing I know as yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: If all Married Women were as unhappy as I, Marriage were a curse.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: No doubt of it. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter a Lady, as almost distracted, running about the Stage, and her Maid follows her.

sp.speaker: LAdy.
sp.p: Oh! my Child is dead, my Child is dead, what shall I do, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You must have patience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Who can have patience to lose their only Child? who can! Oh I shall run mad, for I have no patience.

div.stage: Runs off the Stage. Exit Maid after her.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter a Citizen's Wife, as into a Tavern, where a Bush is hung out, and meets some Gentlemen there.

sp.speaker: Citizen's Wife.
sp.p: PRay Gentlemen, is my Husband, Mr. Negligent here?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: He was, but he is gone some quarter of an hour since.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: Could he go, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Yes, with a Supporter.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: Out upon him! must he be supported? Upon my credit Gentlemen, he will undo himself and me too, with his drinking and carelesness, leaving his Shop and all his Commodities at six's and seven's; and his Prentices and Journey-men are as careless and idle as he; besides, they cozen him of his Wares. But, was it a He or She-Supporter, my Husband was supported by?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: A She-supporter; for it was one of the Maid-servants, which belong to this Tavern.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: Out upon him Knave, must he have a She-supporter, in the Devil's name? but I'le go and seek them both out with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Pray, let us intreat your stay to drink a cup of Wine with us.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: I will take your kind Offer; for Wine may chance to abate Cholerick vapours, and pacifie the Spleen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: That it will; for Wine and good Company are the only abaters of Vapours.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: It doth not abate Vapours so much as cure Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: In truth, I find a cup of Wine doth comfort me sometimes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: It will cheer the Heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Yes, and enlighten the Understanding.

sp.speaker: Cit. Wife.
sp.p: Indeed, and my understanding requires enlightening. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter a Lady big with Child, groaning as in labour, and a Company of Women with her.
div.p: OH my back, my back will break, Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Is the Midwife sent for?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: Yes, but she is with another Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh my back! Oh! Oh! Oh! Juno, give me some ease. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Enter two Ancient Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1 LAdy.
sp.p: I have brought my Son into the World with great pains, bred him with tender care, much pains and great cost; and must he now be hang'd for killing a Man in a quarrel? when he should be a comfort and staff of my age, is he to be my ages affliction?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: I confess it is a great affliction; but I have had as great; having had but two Daughters, and them fair ones, though I say it, and might have matched them well: but one of them was got with Child to my great disgrace; th' other run away with my Butler, not worth the droppings of his Taps.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Who would desire Children, since they come to such misfortunes? Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter one Woman meeting another.

sp.speaker: 1 VVOman.
sp.p: Is the Midwife come, for my Lady is in a strong labour?

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: No, she cannot come, for she hath been with a Lady that hath been in strong labour these three days of a dead child, and 'tis thought she cannot be delivered.

div.stage: Enter another Woman.

sp.speaker: 3 Woman.
sp.p: Come away, the Midwife is come.

sp.speaker: 1 Woman.
sp.p: Is the Lady deliver'd, she was withall?

sp.speaker: 3 Woman.
sp.p: Yes, of life; for she could not be delivered, and so she died.

sp.speaker: 2 Woman.
sp.p: Pray tell not our Lady so: for, the very fright of not being able to bring forth a Child will kill her. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter a Gentleman who meets a fair Young Lady.

sp.speaker: GEnt.
sp.p: Madam, my Lord desires you to command whatsoever you please, and it shall be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare not command, but I humbly intreat, I may live quiet and free from his Amours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: He says he cannot live, and not love you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But he may live, and not lie with me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: He cannot be happy, unless he enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I must be unhappy, if he should.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: He commanded me to tell you that he will part from his Lady for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, I should part Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Lady, he will be divorced for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heaven forbid I should be the cause of a Divorce between a Noble Pair.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You had best consent; for, otherwise he will have you against your will.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will send his Lordship an answer to morrow; pray him to give me so much time.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I shall, Lady. Exit Gentleman.

div.stage: Lady Sola.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must prevent my own ruin, and the sweet virtuous Ladies, by going into a Nunnery; wherefore, I'le put my self into one to night:
sp.l: There will I live, and serve the Gods on high,
And leave this wicked World and Vanity.

div.stage: Exeunt.
One enters and speaks the Epilogue.
div.l: Marriage is a Curse we find,
Especially to Women kind:
From the Cobler's VVife we see,
To Ladies, they unhappie be.

sp.speaker: L. Happy to the Prin.
sp.p: Pray Servant, how do you like this Play?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: My sweet Mistress, I cannot in conscience approve of it; for though some few be unhappy in Marriage, yet there are many more that are so happy as they would not change their condition.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: O Servant, I fear you will become an Apostate.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Not to you sweet Mistress. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: There is no hopes of dissolving this Convent of Pleasure.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Faith, not as I can perceive.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: We may be sure, this Convent will never be dissolved, by reason it is ennobled with the company of great Princesses, and glorified with a great Fame; but the fear is, that all the rich Heirs will make Convents, and all the Young Beauties associate themselves in such Convents.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: You speak reason; wherefore, let us endeavour to get Wives, before they are Incloister'd.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Lady Happy drest as a Shepherdess; She walks very Melancholy, then speaks as to her self.
div.p: MY Name is Happy, and so was my Condition, before I saw this Princess; but now I am like to be the most unhappy Maid alive: But why may not I love a Woman with the same affection I could a Man?
div.l: No, no, Nature is Nature, and still will be
The same she was from all Eternity.
div.stage: Enter the Princess in Masculine Shepherd's Clothes.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: My dearest Mistress, do you shun my Company? is your Servant become an offence to your sight?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: No, Servant! your Presence is more acceptable to me then the Presence of our Goddess Nature, for which she, I fear will punish me, for loving you more then I ought to love you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Can Lovers love too much?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Yes, if they love not well.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Can any Love be more vertuous, innocent and harmless then ours?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Then let us please our selves, as harmless Lovers use to do.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: How can harmless Lovers please themselves?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why very well, as, to discourse, imbrace and kiss, so mingle souls together.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: But innocent Lovers do not use to kiss.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Not any act more frequent amongst us Women-kind; nay, it were a sin in friendship, should not we kiss: then let us not prove our selves Reprobates.

div.stage: They imbrace and kiss, and hold each other in their Arms.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: These my Imbraces though of Femal kind,
May be as fervent as a Masculine mind.

div.stage: The Scene is open'd, the Princess and L. Happy go in. A Pastoral within the Scene.
The Scene is changed into a Green, or Plain, where Sheep are feeding, and a May-Pole in the middle.
L. Happy as a Shepherdess, and the Princess as a Shepherd are sitting there.
Enter another Shepherd, and Wooes the Lady Happy.

sp.speaker: Shepherd.
sp.l: FAir Shepherdess do not my Suit deny,
O grant my Suit, let me not for Love die:
Pity my Flocks, Oh save their Shepherd's life;
Grant you my Suit, be you their Shepherd's Wife.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.l: How can I grant to every ones request?
Each Shepherd's Suit lets me not be at rest;
For which I wish, the Winds might blow them far,
That no Love-Suit might enter to my Ear.

div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator in a Shepherdess dress, and another Shepherd.

sp.speaker: Sheph.
sp.l: Good Dame unto your Daughter speak for me.
Perswade her I your Son in Law may be:
I'le serve your Swine, your Cows bring home to Milk;
Attend your Sheep, whose Wool's as soft as Silk;
I'le plow your Grounds, Corn I'le in Winter sow,
