Then reap your Harvest, and your Grass I'le mow;
Gather your Fruits in Autumn from the Tree.
All this and more I'le do, if y' speak for me.

sp.speaker: Shepherdess.
sp.l: My Daughter vows a single life,
And swears, she n're will be a Wife;
But live a Maid, and Flocks will keep,
And her chief Company shall be Sheep.

div.stage: The Princess as a Shepherd, speaks to the Lady Happy.

lg.l: My Shepherdess, your Wit flies high,
Up to the Skie,
And views the Gates of Heaven,
Which are the Planets Seven;
Sees how fixt Stars are plac'd,
And how the Meteors wast;
VVhat makes the Snow so white,
And how the Sun makes light;
VVhat makes the biting Cold
On every thing take hold;
And Hail a mixt degree,
'Twixt Snow and Ice you see
From whence the VVinds do blow;
VVhat Thunder is, you know,
And what makes Lightning flow
Like liquid streams, you show.
From Skie you come to th' Earth,
And view each Creature's birth;
Sink to the Center deep,
Where all dead bodies sleep;
And there observe to know,
What makes the Minerals grow;
How Vegetables sprout,
And how the Plants come out;
Take notice of all Seed,
And what the Earth doth breed;
Then view the Springs below,
And mark how Waters flow;
What makes the Tides to rise
Up proudly to the Skies,
And shrinking back descend,
As fearing to offend.
Also your Wit doth view
The Vapour and the Dew,
In Summer's heat, that Wet
Doth seem like the Earth's Sweat;
In Winter-time, that Dew
Like paint 's white to the view,
Cold makes that thick, white, dry;
As Cerusse it doth lie
On th' Earth's black face, so fair
As painted Ladies are;
But, when a heat is felt,
That Frosty paint doth melt.
Thus Heav'n and Earth you view,
And see what's Old, what's New;
How Bodies Transmigrate,
Lives are Predestinate.
Thus doth your Wit reveal
What Nature would conceal.
My Shepherd,
All those that live do know it,
That you are born a Poet,
Your Wit doth search Mankind,
In Body and in Mind;
The Appetites you measure,
And weigh each several Pleasure;
Do figure every Passion,
And every Humor's fashion;
See how the Fancie's wrought,
And what makes every Thought;
Fadom Conceptions low,
From whence Opinions flow;
Observe the Memorie's length,
And Understanding's strength
Your Wit doth Reason find,
The Centre of the Mind,
Wherein the Rational Soul
Doth govern and controul,
There doth she sit in State,
Predestinate by Fate,
And by the Gods Decree,
That Sovereign She should be.
And thus your VVit can tell,
How Souls in Bodies dwell;
As that the Mind dwells in the Brain,
And in the Mind the Soul doth raign,
And in the Soul the life doth last,
For with the Body it doth not wast;
Nor shall VVit like the Body die,
But live in the VVorld's Memory.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: May I live in your favour, and be possest with your Love and Person, is the height of my ambitions.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: I can neither deny you my Love nor Person.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: In amorous Pastoral Verse we did not Woo.
As other Pastoral Lovers use to doo.

sp.speaker: L. Ha.
sp.l: Which doth express, we shall more constant be,
And in a Married life better agree.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: VVe shall agree, for we true Love inherit,
Join as one Body and Soul, or Heav'nly Spirit.

div.stage: Here come Rural Sports, as Country Dances about the Map-Pole: that Pair which Dances best is Crowned King and Queen of the Shepherds that year; which happens to the Princess, and the Lady Happy.

sp.speaker: L. Happy to the Princ.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Servant, that our Custome is to dance about this May-Pole, and that Pair which Dances best is Crown'd King and Queen of all the Shepherds and Shepherdesses this year: VVhich Sport if it please you we will begin.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Nothing, Sweetest Mistress, that pleases you, can displease me.

div.stage: They Dance; after the Dancing the Princess and Lady Happy are Crowned with a Garland of Flowers: a Shepherd speaks.

lg.l: YOu've won the prize; and justly; so we all
Acknowledg it with joy, and offer here
Our Hatchments up, our Sheep-hooks as your due,
And Scrips of Corduant, and Oaten pipe;
So all our Pastoral Ornaments we lay
Here at your Feet, with Homage to obay
All your Commands, and all these things we bring
In honour of our dancing Queen and King;
For Dancing heretofore has got more Riches
Then we can find in all our Shepherds Breeches;
Witness rich Holmby: Long then may you live,
And for your Dancing what we have we give.

div.stage: A Wassel is carried about and Syllibubs.
Another Shepherd speaks, or Sings this that follows.

lg.l: THe Jolly Wassel now do bring,
With Apples drown'd in stronger Ale,
And fresher Syllibubs, and sing;
Then each to tell their Love-sick Tale:
So home by Couples, and thus draw
Our selves by holy Hymen's Law.

div.stage: The Scene Vanishes.
Enter the Princess Sola, and walks a turn or two in a Musing posture, then views her Self, and speaks.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What have I on a Petticoat, Oh Mars! thou God of War, pardon my sloth; but yet remember thou art a Lover, and so am I; but you will say, my Kingdom wants me, not only to rule, and govern it, but to defend it: But what is a Kingdom in comparison of a Beautiful Mistress? Base thoughts flie off, for I will not go; did not only a Kingdom, but the World want me. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Happy Sola, and Melancholy, and after a short Musing speaks.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.l: O Nature, O you gods above,
Suffer me not to fall in Love;
O strike me dead here in this place
Rather then fall into disgrace.

div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: What, Lady Happy, solitary alone! and Musing like a disconsolate Lover!

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: No, I was Meditating of Holy things.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Holy things! what Holy things?

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: Why, such Holy things as the Gods are.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: By my truth, whether your Contemplation be of Gods or of Men, you are become lean and pale since I was in the Convent last.

div.stage: Enter the Princess.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Come my sweet Mistress, shall we go to our Sports and Recreations?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Beshrew me, your Highness hath sported too much I fear.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Why, Madam Mediator, say you so?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Because the Lady Happy looks not well, she is become pale and lean.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Madam Mediator, your eyes are become dim with Time; for my sweet Mistress appears with greater splendor then the God of Light.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: For all you are a great Princess, give me leave to tell you,
sp.l: I am not so old, nor yet so blind,
But that I see you are too kind.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Well, Madam Mediator, when we return from our Recreations, I will ask your pardon, for saying, your eyes are dim, conditionally you will ask pardon for saying, my Mistress looks not well.

div.stage: Exeunt.

The Scene is opened, and there is presented a Rock as in the Sea, whereupon sits the Princess and the Lady Happy; the Princess as' the Sea-God Neptune, the Lady Happy as a Sea-Goddess: the rest of the Ladies sit somewhat lower, drest like Water-Nymphs; the Princess begins to speak a Speech in Verse, and after her the Lady Happy makes her Speech.

lg.l: I Am the King of all the Seas,
All Watry Creatures do me please,
Obey my Power and Command,
And bring me Presents from the Land;
The Waters open their Flood-gates,
VVhere Ships do pass, sent by the Fates;
VVhich Fates do yearly, as May-Dew,
Send me a Tribute from Peru,
From other Nations besides,
Brought by their Servants, Winds and Tides,
Ships fraught and Men to me they bring;
My Watery Kingdom lays them in.
Thus from the Earth a Tribute I
Receive, which shews my power thereby:
Besides, my Kingdom's richer far
Then all the Earth and every Star.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.l: I feed the Sun, which gives them light,
And makes them shine in darkest night,
Moist vapour from my brest I give,
Which he sucks forth, and makes him live,
Or else his Fire would soon go out,
Grow dark, or burn the World throughout.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.l: What Earthly Creature's like to me,
That hath such Power and Majestie?
My Palaces are Rocks of Stone,
And built by Nature's hand alone;
No base, dissembling, coz'ning Art
Do I imploy in any part,
In all my Kingdom large and wide,
Nature directs and doth provide
Me all Provisions which I need,
And Cooks my Meat on which I feed.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.l: My Cabinets are Oyster-shells,
In which I keep my Orient-Pearls,
To open them I use the Tide,
As Keys to Locks, which opens wide,
The Oyster-shells then out I take;
Those, Orient-Pearls and Crowns do make;
And modest Coral I do wear,
VVhich blushes when it touches air.
On Silver-Waves I sit and sing,
And then the Fish lie listening:
Then sitting on a Rocky stone,
I comb my Hair with Fishes bone;
The whil'st Apollo, with his Beams,
Doth dry my Hair from wat'ry streams.
His Light doth glaze the Water's face,
Make the large Sea my Looking-Glass;
So when I swim on Waters high,
I see my self as I glide by:
But when the Sun begins to burn,
I back into my Waters turn,
And dive unto the bottom low:
Then on my head the Waters flow,
In Curled waves and Circles round;
And thus with Waters am I Crown'd.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.l: Besides, within the Waters deep,
In hollow Rocks my Court I keep;
Of Amber-greece my Bed is made,
Whereon my softer Limbs are laid,
There take I Rest; and whil'st I sleep,
The Sea doth guard, and safe me keep
From danger; and, when I awake,
A Present of a Ship doth make.
No Prince on Earth hath more resort,
Nor keeps more Servants in his Court;
Of Mare-maids you're waited on,
And Mare-men do attend upon
My Person; some are Councellors,
Which order all my great Affairs;
Within my wat'ry Kingdom wide,
They help to rule, and so to guide
The Common-wealth; and are by me
Prefer'd unto an high degree.
Some Judges are, and Magistrates,
Decide each Cause, and end Debates;
Others, Commanders in the War;
And some to Governments prefer;
Others are Neptun's Priests which pray
And preach when is a Holy-day.
And thus with Method order I,
And govern all with Majesty;
I am sole Monarch of the Sea,
And all therein belongs to me.

div.stage: A Sea-Nymph Sings this following SONG.

lg.l: WE Watery Nymphs Rejoyce and Sing
About God Neptune our Sea's King;
In Sea-green Habits, for to move
His God-head, for to fall in love.
That with his Trident he doth stay
Rough foaming Billows which obay:
And when in Triumph he doth stride
His manag'd Dolphin for to ride.
All his Sea-people to his wish,
From VVhale to Herring subject Fish,
With Acclamations do attend him,
And pray's more Riches still to send him.

div.stage: Exeunt.
The SCENE Vanishes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter the Princess and the Lady Happy; The Princess is in a Man's Apparel as going to Dance; they Whisper sometime; then the Lady Happy takes a Ribbon from her arm, and gives it to the Princess, who gives her another instead of that, and kisses her hand. They go in and come presently out again with all the Company to Dance, the Musick plays; And after they have Danced a little while, in comes Madam Mediator wringing her hands, and spreading her arms; and full of Passion cries out.
div.p: O Ladies, Ladies! you're all betrayed, undone, undone; for there is a man disguised in the Convent, search and you'l find it.
div.stage: They all skip from each other, as afraid of each other; only the Princess and the Lady Happy stand still together.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: You may make the search, Madam Mediator; but you will quit me, I am sure.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: By my faith but I will not, for you are most to be suspected.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: But you say, the Man is disguised like a Woman, and I am accoustred like a Man.

sp.speaker: M. Mediator.
sp.p: Fidle, fadle, that is nothing to the purpose.

div.stage: Enter an Embassador to the Prince; the Embassador kneels, the Prince bids him rise.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: What came you here for?

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.p: May it please your Highness, The Lords of your Council sent me to inform your Highness, that your Subjects are so discontented at your Absence, that if your Highness do not return into your Kingdom soon, they'l enter this Kingdom by reason they hear you are here; and some report as if your Highness were restrained as Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: So I am, but not by the State, but by this Fair Lady, who must be your Soveraigness.

stage.hi: The Embassador kneels and kisses her Hand.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: But since I am discover'd, go from me to the Councellors of this State, and inform them of my being here, as also the reason, and that I ask their leave I may marry this Lady; otherwise, tell them I will have her by force of Arms. Exit Embassador.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: O the Lord! I hope you will not bring an Army, to take away all the Women; will you?

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: No, Madam Mediator, we will leave you behind us. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Madam Mediator lamenting and crying with a Handkerchief in her hand.
div.p: O Gentlemen, that I never had been born, we're all undone and lost!

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Matter? nay, I doubt, there's too much Matter.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: How, never such a Mistake; why we have taken a Man for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: Why, a Man is for a Woman.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Fidle fadle, I know that as well as you can tell me; but there was a young Man drest in Woman's Apparel, and enter'd our Convent, and the Gods know what he hath done: He is mighty handsome, and that's a great Temptation to Virtue; but I hope all is well: But this wicked World will lay aspersion upon any thing or nothing; and therefore I doubt, all my sweet young Birds are undone, the Gods comfort them.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: But could you never discover it? nor have no hint he was a Man?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: No truly, only once I saw him kiss the Lady Happy; and you know Womens Kisses are unnatural, and me-thought they kissed with more alacrity then Women use, a kind of Titillation, and more Vigorous.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: Why, did you not then examine it?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Why, they would have said, I was but an old jealous fool, and laught at me; but Experience is a great matter; If the Gods had not been merciful to me, he might have faln upon me.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Why, what if he had?

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Nay, if he had I care not: for I defie the Flesh as much as I renounce the Devil, and the pomp of this wicked World; but if I could but have sav'd my young sweet Virgins, I would willingly have sacrificed my body for them; for we are not born for our selves but for others.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: 'Tis piously said, truly, lovingly and kindly.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Nay, I have read the Practice of Piety; but further they say, He is a Foreign Prince; and they say, They're very hot.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Why, you are Madam Mediator, you must mediate and make a Friendship.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Ods body what do you talk of Mediation, I doubt they are too good Friends; Well, this will be news for Court, Town and Country, in private Letters, in the Gazette, and in abominable Ballets, before it be long, and jeered to death by the pretending Wits; but, good Gentlemen, keep this as a Secret, and let not me be the Author, for you will hear abundantly of it before it be long.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: But, Madam Mediator, this is no Secret, it is known all the Town over, and the State is preparing to entertain the Prince.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: Lord! to see how ill news will fly so soon abroad?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Ill news indeed for us Wooers.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: We only wooed in Imagination but not in Reality.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p: But you all had hopes.

sp.speaker: Advis.
sp.p: We had so; but she only has the fruition: for it is said, the Prince and she are agreed to Marry; and the State is so willing, as they account it an honour, and hope shall reap much advantage by the Match.

sp.speaker: M. Mediat.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; but there is an old and true
Saying, There's much between the Cup and the Lip.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter the Prince as Bridegroom, and the Lady Happy as Bride, hand in hand under a Canopy born over their heads by Men; the Magistrates march before, then the Hoboys; and then the Bridal-Guests, as coming from the Church, where they were Married.
All the Company bids them joy, they thank them.

sp.speaker: Madam Mediator.
sp.p: ALthough your Highness will not stay to feast with your Guests, pray Dance before you go.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: We will both Dance and Feast before we go; come Madam let us Dance, to please Madam Mediator.

div.stage: The Prince and Princess Dance.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Now, Noble Friends, Dance you; and the Princess, and I, will rest our selves.

div.stage: After they have Danced, the Lady Happy, as now Princess, speaks to the Lady Vertue.

sp.speaker: L. Happy speaks to L. Vertue.
sp.p: Lady Vertue, I perceive you keep Mimick still.

sp.speaker: L. Happy to the Princ.
sp.p: Sir, this is the Mimick I told you of.

sp.speaker: L. Happy to Mimick.
sp.p: Mimick, will you leave your Lady and go with me?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I am a Married Man, and have Married my Ladies Maid Nan, and she will keep me at home do what I can; but you've now a Mimick of your own, for the Prince has imitated a Woman.

sp.speaker: L. Happy.
sp.p: What you Rogue, do you call me a Fool?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Not I, please your Highness, unless all Women be Fools.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Is your Wife a Fool?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: Man and Wife, 'tis said, makes but one Fool.

div.stage: He kneels to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: I have an humble Petition to your Highness.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Rise; What Petition is that?

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: That your Highness would be pleased to divide the Convent in two equal parts; one for Fools, and th' other for Married Men, as mad Men.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: I'le divide it for Virgins and Widows.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: That will prove a Convent of Pleasure indeed; but they will never agree, especially if there be some disguised Prince amongst them; but you had better bestow it on old decrepit and bed-rid Matrons, and then it may be call'd the Convent of Charity, if it cannot possibly be named the Convent of Chastity.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: Well, to shew my Charity, and to keep your Wife's Chastity, I'le bestow my bounty in a Present, on the Condition you speak the Epilogue. Come, Noble Friends, let us feast before we part.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Mimick Solus.

sp.speaker: Mimick.
sp.p: An Epilogue says he, the devil an Epilogue have I: let me study.

I have it, I have it; No faith, I have it not; I lie, I have it, I say, I have it not; Fie Mimick, will you lie? Yes, Mimick, I will lie, if it be my pleasure: But I say, it is gone; What is gone? The Epilogue; When had you it? I never had it; then you did not lose it; that is all one, but I must speak it, although I never had it; How can you speak it, and never had it? I marry, that's the question; but words are nothing, and then an Epilogue is nothing, and so I may speak nothing; Then nothing be my Speech.

div.head: He Speaks the EPILOGUE.
div.l: NOble Spectators by this Candle-light,
I know not what to say, but bid, Good Night:
I dare not beg Applause, our Poetess then
Will be enrag'd, and kill me with her Pen;
For she is careless, and is void of fear;
If you dislike her Play she doth not care.
But I shall weep, my inward Grief shall show
Through Floods of Tears, that your my Eyes will flow.
And so poor Mimick he for sorrow die.
And then through pity you may chance to cry:
But if you please, you may a Cordial give,
Made up with Praise, and so he long may live.

list.item: Monsieur Take-pleasure, and Dick his Man.
A distracted Lady, and her Maid.
A Gentleman and a Young Lady.

argument.head: Advertisement to the Reader.
argument.p: THe Reader is desir'd to take notice, That the following Fragments are part of a Play which I did intend for my Blazing-World, and had been Printed with it, if I had finish'd it; but before I had ended the second Act, finding that my Genius did not tend that way, I left that design; and now putting some other Comedies to the Press, I suffer this Piece of One to be publish'd with them.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Puppy Dogman, and Monsieur Ass.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy Dogman.
sp.p: MOnsieur Ass, you are the only person in the whole World, I am ambitious to be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: I am your thrice humble servant, Sir Puppy.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p:
I am informed you are the best drolling,
gulling, and Libel-wit in this Kingdom.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: I confess my Genius hath been happy that way.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: That Genius would I learn, for it is the only Genius that is in fashion amongst the Mode-Wits; and it is reported, that you are the friend, and a confident to the Mode-Wits.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: I confess that I am not only a friend and a confident, but a head of the Company of the Mode-Wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: They cannot be better headed then by an Asse's head; and therefore I desire to be one of the Company; but pray you, inform me, Monsieur Ass, what gulling-Wit is? for I am but newly come out of the Country, and am unacquainted with the Wit of the Town.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: Gulling-Wit is lying Wit; and I will assure you, Sir, it expresses much fancy to make lies.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: Are those Poetical Fancies?

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: Hang Poetical Fancies, for they are Pictures of Ideas in the Mind; but gulling-lies are to abuse the Generality, by making of News, and several reports of Peace, Wars, State-affairs of great Monarchs, and their Councils, and so of all things, and of particular persons.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: And what is drolling and raillery Wit?

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: That sort of Wit is to rail of, and abuse particular persons, under the pretence of Jesting.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: Then what is Libel-Wit?

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: Libel-Wit is to defame great and Noble Persons.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: Monsieur Ass, you have infinitely obliged me with your informations, for which I shall be your eternal Servant.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: I am your Slave, Sir Puppy Dogman.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the Lady Eagle, Lady Sparrow, Lady Titmous, Lady Woodcock, Lady Hornet, Lady Chaffer, the Lady Cricket, and Others.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Is the Lady Phoenix come to Town?

sp.speaker: Woodcock.
sp.p: No; but it is reported, that she is coming to Town in such splendor, as the World never saw the like.

sp.speaker: Sparrow.
sp.p: Lord! how much splendor?

sp.speaker: Woodcock.
sp.p: So much as will astonish all her Spectators.

sp.speaker: Titmous.
sp.p: I cannot perceive what splendor she can appear in to astonish all that behold her.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: I desire if any one of the Town know her, to describe her to me.

sp.speaker: Cricket.
sp.p: There are many that pretend to know her, but I observe, they give such different Characters of her, that makes me believe they do not know her?

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Who are those that pretend to know her?

sp.speaker: Cricket.
sp.p: Sir Blind-Buzzard is one, and the Lady Wasp is another.

div.stage: Enter Sir Blind-Buzzard and the Lady Wasp.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: You are welcome; I was sending for you, for 'tis said you two know the Lady Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: We never saw her, but we have seen them that have seen her.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: I am told, that she is coming to this City in such splendour, as the World never saw.

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: Your Ladiship is truly informed, for she is clothed all with light, and the beams issuing from that light, makes her train many miles long, which is held up by the Planets; also, she is perfumed with all the Spices in the East-Indies; her Chariot is made of air, in the fashion of a Ship, and that airy Ship is gilded with the Sun; She hath numerous Attendants, those that usher her, are Blazing-Stars, and those that follow her, are fiery Meteors.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Doth the Ship hold all her Attendants?

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: Yes; for the Ship is bigger then the Great-Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: But the Great-Soveraign cannot hold all the Planets.

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: Why, not as well as Noah's Ark all sorts of Beasts?

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Of what diet is she of?

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: She feeds only upon Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cricket.
sp.p: Pray, Sir Blind-Buzzard, give me leave to tell you one thing, that if her train be many miles long, no House can contain the length.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: But she hath an art to contract her beams when she will.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: I desire much to see this Lady.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: When you see her, you will all dislike her.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Why shall we all dislike her?

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: By reason none of the Female Sex can endure to see any thing fairer then themselves.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Monkey.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Lady Monkey, did you ever see the Lady Phoenix?

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: No, Madam, but I hearing of a wonderful Lady coming to this City, whose train spread so far and long, as out of one Kingdom into another, came as speedily as I could to this Company to know the truth.

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: The truth is, her Train is but some few miles long.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, Sir Blind-Buzzard, I did not see you; it seems you know this Lady.

sp.speaker: Buzzard.
sp.p: I do not know her, but I have heard of her.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: So have I, which made me come hither to know if the report was true, for all reports are not true.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Ass.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Monsieur Ass, did you ever see the Lady Phoenix?

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: No, but I am credibly informed, that she is as proud as Lucifer, she despises her Superiors, and scorns her Inferiors.

div.stage: Enter Sir Puppy Dogman.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: But Sir Puppy Dogman can inform you what she is.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: What who is?

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: The Lady Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: Hang her, for she is not Company for a Dog.

sp.speaker: Hornet.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: No, but I have heard of her.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Worm-man.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.p: But Mr. Worm-man hath seen her; did you never see the Lady Phoenix, Mr. Worm-man?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: No truly, I did never see her; but one Mrs. Dormouse, that serves the Lady Leverit, is well acquainted with her, for she did serve her.

div.stage: Enter Madam Leverit, and her Maid Dormouse.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Madam Leverit, we are informed that your Maid Dormouse hath served the Lady Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Dormouse.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I served her many years.

sp.speaker: Eagle.
sp.p: Of what Nature, Disposition and Conversation is she?

sp.speaker: Dormouse.
sp.p:
She is of a studious nature, in a retired life, ever retireing from much Company, and of a careless humour, not regarding what the World says, or doth; in Company she is of a free Disposition, and an airy Conversation; she is civil to strangers, kind to acquaintances, bountiful to her servants, and charitable to the poor; also, she is humble to those that are respectful,
but severe to those that are rude.

sp.speaker: M. Ass.
sp.p: Surely Mrs. Dormouse, you slept all the time you serv'd her; for certainly she is the proudest Creature alive.

sp.speaker: Dormouse.
sp.p: She may chance to seem proud to an Ass, and vain to a Buzzard; but otherwise, she is as one of her quality ought to be. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Lord Bearman, and the Lady Monkey.

sp.speaker: Lord Bearman.
sp.l: DEar Lady Monkey, I come to present
My loving heart, without a Complement;
Let me embrace thee in my Amorous Arms,
Which makes a Circle of all loving Charms.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.l: Your first encounter is too rude and bold
To offer in your Arms me to infold.

sp.speaker: Bearman.
sp.l: Yet give me leave, dear Lady, to admire,
Your agil Motions, VVit, and your Attire.
And wish with all my heart you may love me,
For I with heart and soul will still love thee.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.l: I love a Lord, yet I would have him woo
In Courtly Language, as Lovers use to do;
And his Address, Behaviour, Speech and Clothes
All a la mode, not a la mode his Oaths;
And such a Lover I will entertain,
But Lovers out of fashion I disdain.

sp.speaker: Bearman.
sp.l: I do confess I want those rules and arts
As such Men have that are nam'd Men of Parts.
But such Men as these are not natural,
For all Mode-Gallants are artificial;
But for your sake, I will go to Mode's School
To learn Mode's fashions for to play the Fool.

div.stage: Exit the Lord Bearman.
Enter Sir Puppy Dogman.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.l: Dear Lady Monkey, I am come here to play
An hour or two to pass the time away;
To run, to skip, to dance, and so to woo
In lively pastimes, as Lovers us'd to do.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.l: You are deceived, Mode-Lovers woo not so,
But cringe and creep, being afraid to go,
Or stir, or speak, but only with eye-glances,
He to his Mistress love, his heart advances;
Besides, your Garments are to mean and base,
And such a Lover would be a disgrace
To a fair Lady; wherefore, come not neer,
Unless you like a Gallant do appear.

sp.speaker: Sir Puppy.
sp.l: I will go to a Taylor for to make
Me a rich Suit for my dear Ladies sake.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Politick Fox-man, Solus.
div.p: THe Lady Leverit is a rich Widow, but a dull Melancholy Lady; which humour is best befitting, and most agreeable to a studious Politician; but let her humour be merry or sad, I care not, for 'tis her Riches that I covet.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Worm-man.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: O dear friend, Mr. Worm-man! have you made any enquiry about the rich Widow, the Lady Leverit?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: I have not only enquired, but I have spied out another Lover of hers, which is Monsieur Satyr.

sp.speaker: Foxman.
sp.p: A Pox on Monsieur Satyr; but surely she will never entertain a Satyr.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: That may be a question; for though Satyrs for the most part wooes in a crabed, and harsh stile; yet for the most part they are well beloved of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: But do you think she will marry him?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: I cannot judge, because many Women, especially Widows, marry, as you would marry, for Interest, not for Love; besides, many Women have Lovers for their use, and marry Husbands for their abuse.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: But when I am married, I will keep her from abusing me.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: If you have that Art, it is an Art that only you, and no other man, hath as yet found out; but the best way is to woo her, and then wed her if you can.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: I shall take your Counsel; but pray you advise me whether I should woo her in Verse, or in Prose?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Certainly the best way is to woo her in Prose; for I never heard that ever a subtle Politician was ever a good Poet.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Well, your advice, dear friend, I will follow: But let me ask your advice once more, which is, Whether I shall first present my affection in a Letter, before I speak to her in person.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Truly, my advice is, That you shall send her a Letter; for Ladies take great delight to read Love-Letters; besides, it proves you will be constant, when your affections are declared under your hand and seal: But why do you, a Politician, ask advice?

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Because Politicians require information; But how shall my Letter be delivered?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: I am well acquainted with Mrs. Dormouse her Maid, and I will deliver the Letter to her, and she'l present it to her Lady.

div.stage: Exit Mr. Worm-man.
Enter the Lord Bear-man, all Accoutred in the mode, and all in the mode, careless, and with Congies.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Sir Politick Fox-man, my dear and obliging friend, how do I love thee! for thou art the most meritorious person in the whole World.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: I am your Lordships most humble servant; and I wish it was in my power to serve so great a person as you are; I perceive your Lordship is for the Court to day, you are so accoutred.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Although I am not for the Court, yet I am for Courtship.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: I perceive your Lordship is a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: I should be otherwise out of the mode; but the Ladies do so flock about me, since I have put my self into the mode, and do so Court me, as I cannot have time to make a particular Courtship.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Your Lordship is a happy man.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Faith, if happiness be to have the love of many Ladies, I am happy; but I have one Lady that I value and love above all the rest, and I hope she will love me now I am in the mode.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Surely your Lordship cannot be more modified then you are.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Not for Clothes; but I fear I have not the right Mode in behaviour and speech; but I will go and visit my Mistress, and see if she approves of me.

div.stage: Exit the Lord Bear-man
Enter Sir Puppy Dogman all in Mode-Accoutrements

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: O Sir Politick Fox! I have a quarrel with you.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: With me, Sir Puppy! it cannot be, for I am your vassal, your slave, and do study all the ways to serve you; and assure your self you shall find me as faithful in all your employments, or concerns, as any friend you have.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: I cannot but believe you, if I be in the Mode, which is to be a self-conceited Puppy: But prithee tell me, am I not a Mode-Gallant?

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: No doubt but you out-mode all the Gallants in the Town, as far as I see, in behaviour and accoutrements.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: Yes, but I am more modified then so; for I have been at a Coffee-house, and a Tavern, and have entertained a Mistress, and in a short time I hope I shall be able to brag, not only of several Lady-Mistresses, but that I have the Pox.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: These modes I fear will be both chargable and unhealthful.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: They are no Moders that regard health, or expences; but I will tell you, that there is another Mode that I must learn, which is to defame great Ladies, not only in private discourse, but in publick Lampoons, or else I shall not, when I am poor, get young Puppys like my self to pay my score, or for my lodging; nor shall I borrow one peny, neither shall I be cry'd up for a Wit.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: But these Modes are Modes for inferior persons, not such persons of quality as you are.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: Nay faith, in this age there is no difference between the noble and base; but if there be, 'tis to the advantage of the mean and base persons; but fare you well, for I must go to a Mistress and dissemble in Complements, and then I shall be an absolute Mode-gallant; for there is no art so much practised in this age, amongst all sorts and degrees of men, as dissembling.

div.stage: Exit Sir Puppy Dogman.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Lord! Lord! what an age is this for Fools!

div.stage: Enter Worm-man.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: What makes your quick return?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: A quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Have you deliver'd my Letter?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Yes, and have brought you an answer.

body.head: LETTER.
body.p: I have received your affectionate Letter, and I shall willingly hear your Suit, and if it be reasonable, grant your request, being more then an ordinary friend and your humble Servant,

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Dear friend, this Letter is more then I could hope for, in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Now she is in a wise humour, towards a wise Politician, go immediately and woo her.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: I will take your Counsel, dear friend.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Puppy Dogman to the Lady Monkey, drest in the Mode, and as he is coming into the Room, trims and dresses himself; then stands a little time, and leers about, and then creeps, cringes, and riggles his breech, and then speaks.

sp.speaker: Sir Puypy Dogman.
sp.p: LAdy, I should have come sooner to have sacrificed my self and all my fortunes to your service; but that I had lent my Coach and six Horses to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: He was not your Friend if he kept you from your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: I confess I was infinitely displeased, in being hindred from the Coelestial prospect of your beauty.

div.stage: Enter the Lord Bear-man all drest in the mode, and comes boldly up to the Lady, and kisses her hand; Dogman frowns and grins.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Madam, are you for a Play? or Court? or High-Park to day? if you be, I, as the humblest of your Servants, will attend upon you.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: I have offer'd the Lady Monkey my Coach and six Horses before you came.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p:
It was your duty so to do; but yet my Coach and six Horses is to be prefer'd before yours,
being a Lords Coach, and six Horses; neither ought such as you to have a Coach and six Horses.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: A Gentleman is as good as a Lord; and so I am as good as you.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Go, go, and enquire of the Herauld of our Pedigrees.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: No, a Herauld cannot decide our quarrel, but this Sword shall maintain my honour, and decide the dispute.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Pray do not fight here in my house, to fright me with your quarrels.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Do not fear our fighting; but if we did not quarrel in the presence of our Mistress, we should not be right in the Mode.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: But I shall call your Lordship to a strict account.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Pray be friends; for it is the Mode for many Lovers to agree, and be dear and loving friends.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: That Mode of many Lovers is a Matrimonial Mode, as the Lovers of a Married Wife; but not the lovers of a young and virtuous Virgin.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: My Lord Bear-man tells you true; wherefore, we must fight.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: I desire you, as you love me, not to fight.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: 'Tis against the Laws of Nature, for a Bear-man and a Dogman to be friends.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p:
Bears seldom assault the Dogs, but Dogs assault the Bears; and for the most part have the worst;
for many Dogs are kill'd by one Bear, but seldom a Bear is kill'd, although assaulted by many Dogs at once; wherefore, I pray Sir Puppy do not fight.

sp.speaker: Puppy.
sp.p: I shall obey you, dear Madam; and being so infinitely obliged, give me leave to kiss your hand.

div.stage: Kisses her Hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Madam, you have given a just cause both to quarrel and fight.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Pray have patience; for 'tis the Mode amongst Ladies to give their hand to one man, and their heart to another man. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Worm-man, and Sir Politick Fox-man.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Now you have been with the rich Widow, pray tell us the success of your Wooing, or Courtship?

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Faith, I have had as good success as I could desire; for she hath entertained me civilly, and hath promised me kindly to grant all my reasonable desires.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: But reason is seldom regular in Lovers.

sp.speaker: Bear-man.
sp.p: Yes, when in cases of Interest, but not in cases of Appetite.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: But Appetite is for the most part prevalent with ignorant Virgins, but not with experienced Widows.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Satyr, leading Madam Leverit, upon which sight Sir Politick Fox-man runs into a hole behind the Hangings, and the while Monsieur Satyr is whispering in the ear of Madam Leverit, and kissing her hand, the Fox-man peeps out, and shakes his head; but after these Lovers were out of sight, the Fox-man comes out of his hole, and speaks to the Worm-man.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Ill luck go with them.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: They might have had some misfortune, for it was in your power to have disturbed their Courtship.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: How could have I disturbed them?

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Why, you might have fought with him, and have shew'd your valour to your Mistress, and perchance have been revenged of your Rival, by killing him.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: So I should have proved my self a Fool, instead of a Politician, for there is hazard in fight, whether to kill or be kill'd; and if I be kill'd, I shall be soon forgotten, and my enemy will have the reputation to be the more skilful, and valianter Dueller; and if I kill my opposite, I may lose my estate; besides, it was never heard nor known, that great and subtil Politicians were valiant, and seldom that ever any Politician did fight, were it upon necessity, which the greatest Cowards will do.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: Then Politicians will never get a Mistress from a Heroick Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: I confess it were a difficult business if Politicians had not more subtilty to get, then valour to fight: But give me leave to tell you, That Politicians undermine Valour, as you do a tall and magnificent Tree, or a sweet flower; wherefore, I make no question but to undermine the sweet Lady and her Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Worm-man.
sp.p: I wish you may; but if your policy fails, you will lose the rich Widow.

sp.speaker: Fox-man.
sp.p: Never fear. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lady Monkey, and Squirrel her Maid, as in a visit to the Lady Leverit.

sp.speaker: Leverit.
sp.p: Lady Monkey, you have prevented me, for I was going to visit your Ladiship, I only stay'd for Monsieur Satyr to usher me.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: I hear Monsieur Satyr is your Servant, and that there is an intended match between you.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: I desire your advice in the choice of a Husband, for I have many Suiters, but the number confounds my Choice, wherefore I desire your assistance, to help me in my Choice.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: I shall give the best advice I can, if you declare to me, who are your Suiters.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: My Suiters are Sir Politick Fox, Monsieur Satyr, Monsieur Ass, and Sir Puppy Dogman.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Is Sir Puppy Dogman your Suiter?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Yes, and so earnest a Suiter he is, that he will not let me rest in quiet.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: It seems Sir Puppy Dogman is a false dissembling man, for he Courts me with as many professions of love, as any man in the World can do.

sp.speaker: Squirrel.
sp.p: If it please your Honour, that is usual with Mode-Gallants to Court all the Ladies they discourse with, and not only the Ladies, but the Ladie's Maids.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Did he ever Court you?

sp.speaker: Squirrel.
sp.p: As much as your Ladiship, for when you are out of the way, he hunts me from room to room.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: I do believe Mrs. Squirrel, for I have heard my Maid Dormouse say, That Monsieur Satyr would not let her sleep in quiet.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: If Mode-Gallants be of such a various humour, I will never marry a Mode-Gallant.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Then your Honour will not have a Mode-Husband.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Why, do Mode-Husbands love Variety?

sp.speaker: Squirrel.
sp.p: I know not whether they love Variety, but they Court many Women; for Mode-Husbands are for the most part Wittals, and they Court many Women to hide their disgrace.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Mrs. Squirrel speaks true, for my Husband Sir Horn-buck, was a Wittal, and he would court all the heard of Females he met with; and the truth is, that Mode-Husbands are the best Husbands, by reason they suffer their Wives to be Courted.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Then surely Mr. Ass will be an excellent Husband.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: I am of your opinion, Squirrel.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Then I will leave the Satyr, Foxman, and Dogman, and chuse Monsieur Ass.

sp.speaker: Squirrel.
sp.p: In truth Monsieur Ass is a fine Gentleman, and is the greatest Wit in the Town.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Ass.

sp.speaker: Leverit.
sp.p: You are welcome Monsieur Ass, we were speaking of you.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: It is an honour for me to be mentioned by fair Ladies; and if you please sweet Ladies to let me usher your splendorous Beauties to a Play, I shall account my self the happiest Man alive.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Can you usher our Beauties without our Persons, Monsieur Ass.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: No Madam, for your Beauties and Persons are inseperably joyn'd together.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: The Fates forbid that my Person should last no longer then my Beauty, for then I am sure to have but a short life: But what Play is it that you would usher us to?

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: To a Mode-Play.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: Mode-Plays are all Rhime, and no reason, or all Action and no Wit.

sp.speaker: Ass.
sp.p: To tell you the truth Lady, I am the Author the Play that is acted to day.

sp.speaker: Monkey.
sp.p: If you be the Author, Monsieur Ass, surely the Play is an excellent Play; wherefore, Lady Leverit let us go and see this Play, that is of Monsieur Ass's making.

sp.speaker: Leverit.
sp.p: Content.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: The Names of the Actors of the foregoing Piece of a Play.

list.item:
Both Suiters to the Lady Monkey.
Lord Bear-man,
Sir Puppy Dog-man,

Both Suiters to the Lady Leviret.
Sir Politick Fox,
Monsieur Satyr,
Mr. Worm-man, A Friend to Sir Politick Fox.
Sir Blind-Buzzard A Gamster, and a Servant to Ladies.
The Lady Eagle, and many other Ladies; as Lady Woodcock, Sparrow, Titmouse, Chaffer, and others;
The Lady Monkey, Mrs. Squirrel her Maid.
Lady Leviret. Mrs. Dormouse her Maid.

div.p: THe following Names were fitted for a Farse, intended to have been after the Play in the Blazing-World; But the Play being never finish'd, for the Reasons mention'd in the Front of the Piece of that Play; The Farse was not so much as begun.

list.item: Eagle Flyman, A Piper, a Lover to Spider's Wife.
Dig Worm-man, A Miner for Mettal.
Gib Cat-man, One of the Watch.
